In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: wWhan that April with his shouris sote
The drought of March hath ꝑpercid to þe Rote
And bathid euery veyne in such licour
Of which vertu engendrid is the flour
Whan zephirus eke with his swete brethe
Enspirid hath in euery holt and hethe
The tendir croppis and the yong Sūnne .
Hath in the Ramme his half course y ronne .
And smale foulis maken melodie .
That slepen alle the nyght with open eye
So priketh hem nature in her coragis
Than longen folk to go on pilgrimagis
And palmers forto seche straunge londis
To ferne halowis couthe in sundry strondis
And specialy from euery Shiris ende .
Of Englond / to Cauntirbury they wende
The holy blisful martir forto seke
That hem hath holpen whan that they wer seke .
¶ Befille þat in that seasou on a day .
In Suthwerk at the Tabard as I lay
Redy to wende on my pilgrimage
To Cauntirbury with ful deuout corage .
At nyght were comen into that hostery
Welle nyne and twenty in a cpany
Of sundry folk by auenture y le
In felaship and pilgrimes were they alle .
That toward Cauntirbury wolden ride
The chambre and the Stablis weren wide .
And wele we weren easid at the best
And shortly whan the Sune was to r
So had I spoken with hem euerichone
That I was of her felaship anone
And made forward erly forto rise
To take oure wey ther as I you diuise .
¶ But natheles while I haue time ⁊ space
Or that I further in this tale pace
Me thinke it accordaunt to reasou
To telle you alle the condiciou
Of eche of hem so as it semed me .
Of which they were / and of what degre
And eke in what array that they were in
And at a knyght than wille I first begyn .
A Knyght ther was and that a wurthy man
That fro the tyme that he first beganne .
To ride out / he loued cheualrye .
Trouth honour fredam and curtesy
Ful wurthy was he in his lordis werre
And therto had he riden noman more ferre .
As wel in cristendome as in hethenesse
And euer honourid for his wurthinesse
¶ At Alizaundre he was whan it was wonne
Ful ofte he had the boord begonne
Abouen alle nacions in Pruce
In lettow hadde he ben and in Ruce
No cristenman so ofte of his degre .
In Gernade at the Sege eke had he be .
Of Algazir / and riden in Belmarye .
At lieys was he and atte Satalye .
Whan they were wonne / ⁊ in the gret See .
At many a noble armee hadde he be
At mortal batailes had he ben fiftene
And fouȝt for oure feith at Tramyssene
In listis thries / and ay slayn his fo .
This ilke wurthy knyght had ben also
Sumtime with the lord of palatye
Ageyn anothir hethen in Turkye .
And euꝰermore he had souereyn price .
And though that he were wurthy he was wise
And of his port as meke as is a mayde
He neuer yit no vilany ne seid
In al his ltime vnto no wight .
He was a eray parfit gentle knight
But forto telle you of his array
His hors were good but he nas nat gay
Of fustian he werid a gipou
Al besmotird with his haubergeou
For he was late y come from his viage
And went forto do his pilgrimage
¶ With him ther was his son a yong Squyer
A lovyer and a lusty Bachiller
With lockis curle as they were leid in presse
Of twenty yere of age he was as I gesse
Of his stature he was of euen length
And wondirly delyuer and of gret strength
And he had ben sumtime in Chiuachy
In Flaundirs in Artoys and in picardy
And born him wel as of so litle space .
In hoop to stond in his ladyes grace .
Enbroudid was he as it were a mede .
Alle ful of fressh flouris white ⁊ rede .
Synging he was or floiting al the day
He was as fressh as is the moneth of May
Short was his goun with sleues long ⁊ wide
Wel couth he sitte on hors and feire ride
He coude songis make and wel endite
Iuste and eke daunce and wel purtrey ⁊ write
So hote he loued that be nyghtirtale
He slept no more than doth a nyghtingale .
Curteis he was louly and ꝸseruisable
And carf beforn his fadir at the table .
A yeman had he and ꝸseruauntis no mo
At that time / for he lust to ride so .
And he was cladde in cote and hood of grene .
A Shef of pecoc arowis bright and kene .
Vndir his belt he bare fulle thriftily
Wel coude he dresse his tacle yomanly
His arrowis droupid not with fethirs low
And in his hand he bare A mighty bow .
A notte hede had he with a broun visage
Of wodecraft wel coude he alle the usage .
Vpon his arme he bare a gay bracere .
And by his side a Swerd and a bokeler
And on that othir side a gay Daggere .
Harneysid wel and sharp as point of Spere .
A xpofir on his brest of siluer shene
An horn he bare the baudrik was of grene
A Forster was he sothely as I gesse .
Ther was also a Nonne a prioresse .
That of hir smyling was ful simple ⁊ coy
Hir grettist othe was but by seint loy
And she was clepid madame Eglantine
We Ful wel she song the ꝸseruice diuine
Entuned in hir nose fulle semely
And frenssh she spake ful feir and fetisly
Aftir the Scole of Stratteford at bowe
For frensshe of Paris was to hir vnknow
At mete wel taught was she withalle .
She lete no morcelle from hir lippis falle
Ne wette hir fingirs in hir sauce depe .
Wel coude she cary a morcelle and wel kepe
That no drope fille upon hir brest
In curtesy was sette ful mochil hir list
Hir ouꝰerlippe wipid she so clene
That in hir cuppe ther nas no ferthing sene
Of grece / whan she drunken had hir draught
Ful semely aftir hir mete she raught
And sicurly she was of gret disport
And ful plesaunt ⁊ amyable of port
And peyned hir to countirfete chere
Of court / and to be statly of manere
And to be holden digne of reuerence
But forto speke of hir conscience
She was so cheritable and so pitous
She wold wepe if that she saugh a mouse
Caught in a trappe / if it were dede or bledde
Of smale houndis had she þat she fedde
With rostid flessh or mylke and wastle brede
But sore wept she if any of hem were dede
Or if men smote it with a yerde smert
And al was conscience and tendir hert
But semely hir wimple pinchid was
Hir nose streite hir eyen grey as glas
Hir mouthe ful smalle and þerto soft ⁊ rede
But sicurly she had a feire forhede .
It was almost a spanne brode I trow
For hardily she was nat vndirgrowe
Ful fetice was hir cloke as I was ware
Of smalle coral about hir arme she bare
A peire of bedis gaudid al with grene
And theron hyng a broche of gold ful shene
On which ther was first writen a crouned . A .
And aftir amor vincit omnia .
Anothir nonne with hir had she
Þat was hir chapleyn and prestis thre
A monke ther was a feir for the maistry
An outryder that loued venery
A manly man to be an abbot able
Ful many a deynte hors had he in stable
And whan he rode men myght his bridil here .
Gynglyng in a whistling winde as clere
And eke as loude as doth the chapel belle
There as this monke was keper of the Selle .
The rule of seint Maure or of seint Benet
Because that it was olde ⁊ sumdele streite
This ilke monke lete olde thingis pace
And held aftir the new world the space
He yaue not of that text a pulled henne
That seith that hunters be not holy menne
Ne that a monk whan that he is recheles
Is likned to a fisshe watirles .
Þis is to sey A monk out of his cloistꝰer
But thilk text held he not wurth an oystꝰer .
And I seid his oppiniou was good .
What shuld he studie ⁊ make him selue wode .
Vpon a book in cloistir alwey to poure
Or swink with his handis and laboure .
As Austine bid / hough shal the world be ꝸserued .
Lat Austine haue his ovne swink to him reꝸserued
Therfore he was a pricasour aright
Grehoundis he had as swift as foul in fliȝt
Of priking and of hunting for the hare
Was his lust for no cost wold he spare .
I saugh his sleues purfild at the hond
With grey and that the finest of a lond
And forto festen his hood vndir his chyn
He had of gold wrought a fulle curious pyn
A loue knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His hede was ballid that shone as any glas .
And eke his face . as it had ben enoynt
A was a lord ful fatte and in good point
His eyen stepe ⁊ rolling in his hede .
That stemed as a fourneux of lede
His botis souple his hors in gret estate
Now certeinly he was a feire prelate
He nas nat pale as a forpined gost
A fatte Swan loued he best of any rost .
His palfrey was as broun as any bery .
A Frere ther was a wantou ⁊ a mery
A lymitour a fulle solempne man .
In alle þe Ordres foure is none that can .
So moch of daliaunce and of feire langage
He had made fulle many a mariage
Of yong women at his ovne cost
Vnto his ordre he was a noble post
And welbeloued and familiar was he
With frankleynes ouer alle in his cuntre
And with wurthy women of the toun
For he had power of confessioun
As seid himselue more than a Curat
For of his ordre he was licenciat
Ful swetely herd he confessioun
And plesaunt was his absoluciou .
He was an esy man to geue penaunce
Ther as he wist to haue good pitaunce .
For vnto a poure ordre forto yeue
Is signe that a man is wel y shryue
For if he yaue he durst make auaunt
He wist that a man was repentaunt
For many a man so hard is of hert
He may not wepe al though him sore smert
Therfore in stede of weping and prayers
Men mut yeue siluer to the poure freris
His tippet was ay farcid fulle of knyues
And pynnes forto yeue yong wyues .
And certeinly he had a mery note .
Wel coude he syng and pley on a Rote
Of yeddingis he bare vttirly the price
His necke white was as the flouredelice
Therto he strong was as a champioūn
He knew the tauꝰernes wel in alle the toun
And euery hostiller and Tapstere .
Bettir than a lazar or a begster .
For vnto such a wurthy man as he
Accordid not as by his facultee .
To haue with seke lazars acqueyntaūnce .
It is not honest it may not avaunce .
Forto dele with no such pouraile
But alle with riche and sellers of vitail
And ouer alle there as profit shuld arise
Curteis he was and louly of seruice
Ther nas no man nowher so vertuous
He was the best begger in his house
For though a wedow had not a sho .
So plesaunt was his in principio .
Yit wold he haue a ferthing or he went
His purchace was bettir than his rent
And rage he coude as it were a whelpe
In louedaies ther coude he mochil helpe
For ther he nas not like a Cloystrere
With a threde bare cope as is a pore scoler
But he was like a maistir or a pope
Of double wurstede was his semycope
That roundid as a belle out of the presse
Sumwhat he lipsid for his wantounesse
To make his englissh swete upon his tunge
And in his harping whan that he had sunge
His eyen twinclid in his hede aright
As done the sterris in the frosty night
This wurthy limitour was clepid huberd .
A mꝰerchaunt was ther with a forkid berd
In motley / and high on hors he satte
Vpon his hede a flaundrissh beuer hatte
His botis clapsid feire and fetisly
His resons he spake fulle solempnely
Sovnyng alwey thencrece of his wynnyng
He wold the See were kept for any thing
Betwene Middilburgh and Orewelle
Wel coude he in eschaunge Shildis selle .
This wurthy man ful wel his witte besette
Ther wist no wight that he was in dette
So statly was he of his gouernaunce
With his bargeyns ⁊ with his cheuysauce
Forsothe he was a wurthy man withall .
But sothe to sey I note hough men him calle
A Clerc ther was of Oxenford also
That vnto logic long hadde y go
And lene was his hors as is a Rake
And he nas not right fatte I vndirtake
But lokid holow and therto soburly
Ful thredebare was his ouꝰerest courtpye
For he had goten him yit no benefice
Ne was so worldly forto haue office
For him was leuꝰer haue at his beddis hede .
Twenty bokis cladde in blacke or rede .
Of Aristotle and his philosophie .
Than Robis riche or fidil or gay Sautry
But albe that he was a philosophir
Yit had he but litle gold in cofre .
But alle that he might of his frendis hent
On bokis and on lernyng he it spent
And bisily gan for the soulis preye
Of hem that gaue him wherwith to scoley
Of studie toke he most cure ⁊ most hede .
Not one wurd spac he more than was nede .
And that was seid in fourme ⁊ reuꝰerence .
And short and quyk and fulle of high sentence
Sovnyng in moral vertu was his speche
And gladly wold he lerne and gladly teche
A Sergeant of the law both ware and wise
That often hadde ben atte Parvise
Ther was also fulle riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of gret reuerence
He semed such his wurdis weren so wise
Iustice he was fulle ofte in assise .
By patent and by playn Comissiou
For his sentence and for his high renoun
Of fees and Robis had he many one
So gret a purchasour was nowher none
Alle was fee simple to him in effecte
His purchacing myght not be infecte
Nowher so bisy a man as he ther nas
And yit he semed bisier than he was
In termes had he case and domes alle
That fro the time of king william was fall .
Therto he coude endite ⁊ make a thing
Ther coude no wight pynche at his writing .
And euery Statute coude he playne by rote
He rode but homely in a medley cote
Gyrt with a seint of silk with barris smale
Of his array telle I no lenger tale
A Frankleyn was in his cumpany
White was his berd as is the dayesye
Of his complexion he was sanguine
Wel loued he by the morou a soppe in wine
To lyue in delyte was euer his wonne .
For he was Epicorus ovne song sonne
Þat held oppinion that playne delite
Was veray felicite parfite
An housholder and that a gret was he .
Seint Iulian he was in his cuntre
His brede his ale was alwey aftꝰer one
A bettir envined man was neuer none
Without bake mete was neuer his house
Of fressh fisshe and flessh and that so plenteuo9us
It sned his hous of mete and drinke .
Of alle deintees that men coude bethinke
Aftir the sundry sesons of the yere
So chaungid he his mete and his soupere
Fulle many a fatte partrich had he in Mue
And many a breme ⁊ many a luce in Stue
Wo was his Cook but if his sauce were
Poynant and sharp and redy alle his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle alwey
Stode redy couꝰered alle the long day
At Sessions there was he lord and sire
Ful oftyme he was knight of the Shire
A gipser alle of clene Silke
Hyng at his belt as white as eny milke
A Shireve had he ben and Comitour
Was nowher such a wurthy vauesour
An haburdassher and a Carpintere
A webbe a Dyer and a Tapicere
Alle they were clothid in one lyuꝰere
Of a solempne and a gret fraternite
Ful fressh and new her gere y pikid was
Her knyues were chapid nought with bras .
But alle with siluer wrought ful clene ⁊ wele
Her girdilles and her pouchis euerydele
Wel semed eche of hem a feir Burgeys
To sitte in a yild halle on a Deys .
Euꝰerych for the wisdam that he can
Was shaply to ben an Aldirman
For catelle had they enough and rent
And eke her wyues wold it alle assent
And ellis certeyn they were to blame
It is fulle feir to be y clepid madame
And go to vigiles alle beforne .
And haue a Mantell riallich y born
A Cook they had with hem for the nones
To boile the chekyns with the mary bones
And poudir mꝰerchant tart and galingale
Wel coude he know a draught of london ale .
He coude roste and sethe boyle and frye .
Make mortruse and wel bake a pye
But gret harme was it as thought me
That on his Shynne a mormal had he
For blankmanger that made he with the best
A Shipman was ther / wonyng ferre by west
For ought I wote he was of Dertmouthe
He rode upon a Rounsy as he couthe
In a goun of falding to the knee
A dagger hanging on a lace had he
About his necke on his arme a doun
The hoot Somer had made his hue al broun
And certenly he was a good felaw .
Ful many a draught of wine had he draw .
From Burdeuxward whils the chapman slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
If that he fought and had the higher hond
By watir he sent hem home to euery lond
But of his craft to reken wel his tides
His stremes and his daungiers him besides
His herborou his mone and his lodemenage
Ther nas none such from hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was and wise I vndirtake
With many a tempest had his berd be shake
He knew alle the havens as they were
From Scotlond to the cape of Fymistere
And euery cryke in Brytaigne and in Spayn
His barge y clepid was the Maudelayn
¶ With vs ther was a Doctour of Phisik
In alle the world ne was ther one him lyke
To speken of phisic and of Surgery
For he was y groundid in Astronomye .
He kept his pacient a fulle grete dele
In his houres by his magic naturelle
Wel coude he fortunen the ascendent
Of his ymagis for his pacient
He knew the cause of euery maladye
Were it hete or cold moiste or drye
And where it engendrid and of what humorur .
He was a veray parfite practisour
The cause y knowen and of his harm þe rote
Anone he yaue the Sekeman his bote
Ful redy had he his Appoticaryes
To send him his dreggies and his letuaries .
For eche of hem made othir forto wynne
Her frendship was not newe to begynne
Wel knew he the olde Esculapius
And Discorides and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras . haly and Galien
Serapien Raris and Auicen
Auerrois dammastica ⁊ Constantine
Bernard and Gatisten and Gilbertine
Of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑperfluite
But of gret norisshyng and digestible
His studie was but litle on the Bible
In Sanguine and in pers he clad was alle
Y lyned with taffata and with Sendalle
And yit he was but easy of dispence
He kept that he wanne in the pestilence
For gold in phisic is a cordialle
Therfore he loued gold in especiall

l.hi: A good wif ther was besides Bathe

div.l: But she was sumdele deef and that
Of clothe making she had such an haunt
She passid hem of ypirs and of Gaunt
In alle the parissh wif was ther none
That to offring beforn hir shuld gone
And if ther did certeyn so wroth was she
That she was out of alle charite
Hir couꝰerchevis ful fine were of grounde
I durst swere they weyden ten pounde
That on a Sunday were upon hir hede .
Hir hosen were of fine scarlet rede
Ful streight y teyed / and Shoes ful moist ⁊ new
Bold was hir face and feyre and rede of hue .
She was a wurthy woman alle hir lyve
Husbondes at the church dore she had fyue
Without othir cumpany in youthe .
But therof nedith not to speke as nouthe
And thryes hadde she ben at Ierusalem
She had passid many a strong streme
At Rome she had ben and at Boleyn
In Gales at seint Iame and at Coleyn
She couth moch of wandring by the wey
Gattothid was she sothely forto sey
Vpon an Ambuler easily she satte
Y wimpild wel / and on hir heed an hatte
As brood as is a bokeler or a targe
A foot mantel about his hippis large
And on hir fete a peire of sporis sharp
In felaship wel coude she laugh ⁊ carp
Of remedies of loue she couthe ꝑperchaūnce
For she couthe of that art the olde daunce
¶ A good man ther was of Religioun
He was a pore parson of a tovne
But riche he was of holy thought ⁊ werke
He was also a lerned man a clerk
That cristis gospel truly wold preche .
His parisshen deuoutly he wold teche
Benyngne he was and wundir diligent
And in aduersite fulle pacient
And such he was proued ofte sithis
Ful lothe were hym to curse for his tithis
But rathir wold he yeue it out of dout
Vnto his pore parisshens alle about
Of his offring and eke of his substaūnce
He coude in a litle thing haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parissh and housis ferre a sundre
But lette not for reyne ne for thundre
In sekenesse or in mystheve to visite
The ferrist of his parissh moch ⁊ lite
Vpon his fete . and in his hand a staff
This noble ensample vnto his Shepe he yaf
That first he wrought and aftirward he taught
Out of the gospel he the wurdis caught
And this figure he hadde therto
That if gold rust what shuld yren do
For if a prest be foule on whom we trust
No wundir is a lewde man to rust
Shame it is and if a prest toke kepe
A shitten Shepherd and a clene Shepe
Wel ought a prest ensample forto yeue
By his clennesse hough that a Shepe shuld lyue
He sette not his benefice to hire
And leve his Shepe encumbrid in the myre
And renne to londou vnto seint poules

But what they were nothing he ne wote
This Duke his coursour with the sporis smote
And at a stert he was betwix hem two
And pullid out a swerd and cryed ho
Nomore vpon payne of lesing of your hede
By mighty Mars he shal anone be dede
That smytith any stroke that I may se
But tellith me what mystir men ye be
That ben so hardy for to fighten here
Withouten Iuge or othir officere
As it were in listis royally
This Palamon ansuerd hastily
And seid sir what nedith wurdis mo
We haue the deth deꝸserued both two
Two woful wrecchis ben we two caityues
That ben encumbrid of oure ovne lyues
And as thou art a rightful lord and Iuge
Ne yeue us neithir mercy ne refuge
But sle me first for seint charite
And sle my felou eke as wel as me
Or sle him first for though thou know him lite
This is thy mortal fo this is Arcite
That fro thy lond was banyssht on payn of his hede
For which he hath ꝸserued to be dede
For this is he that cam vnto thy gate
And seid his name was callid Philostrate
Thus hath he iapid thee ful many a yere
And thou hast made him thy chef Squyer
And this is he that loueth Emelye
For sith the day is come that I shal dye
I make plainly my confession
That I am that wofulle Palamon
That hath thy prison broken wickidly
I am thy mortal fo and it am I
That loueth so Emely the bright
That I wold dye present in hir sight
Therfore I ax deth and my Iuwyse
But sle my felaou in the same wise
For both haue we deꝸserued to be slayne
This wurthy Duke answerd thus agayn
And seid this is a short conclusion
Your owne mouth by your owne confession
Hath dampned you / and I wil it recorde
It nedith not to pyne you with the corde
Ye shulle be dede be myghty Mars the rede
The quene anone for veray womanhede
Gan for to wepe and so did Emelye
And alle the ladies in the cumpanye
Gret pite was it as it thought hem alle
That euer such a chaunce shuld falle
And nothing but for loue was this debate
For gentilmen they were of gret estate
And saugh her blody woundis wyde and sore
And alle they cried both lasse and more
Haue mercy lord upon vs women alle
And on their bare knees adoun they falle
And wold haue kist his fete ther as he stood
Til at last aslakid was his mode
For pite renneth sone in gentle hert
And there he first for Ire quoke and stert
He hath considird shorthly in a clause
The trespas of hem both and eke the cause
And though that his Ire their gilt accusid
Yit in his reson he hem both excusid
As thus he thought wel that euery man
Wil help himselue in loue if that he can
And eke delyueꝰer himselue out of prison
And eke in his herte he had compassion
Of the women that wepen euꝰer in one
And in his gentle hert he thought anone
And ofte vnto himselue he seid fy
Vpon a lord that nyl haue no mercy
But be a leon both in wurd and dede
To hem that be in repentaunce ⁊ drede
As wel as to a proude dispitous man
That wil mayntene that he first began
That lord hath litle of discrecion
That in such case can no diuision
But weyeth pride and humblesse aftꝰer one
And shortly when his Ire is thus agone
He gan to loke up with eyen light
And spak thees same wurdis al on hight
The god of loue a benedicite
Hough mighty and hough gret a lord is he
Ageyn his myght ther gayneth none obstacles
He may be clepid a god for his miracles
For he can make at his ovne gyse
Of euery hert as that him lust diuise
Lo here this Arcit and this Palamon
That quyt were out of my prison
And myght haue lyued in Thebes rially
And woten I am her mortal enemy
And that her deth lith in my might also
And yit hath loue maugre her eyen two
Y brought hem hidir both for to dye
Now loke is not that an high foly
Who may be a fole but if he loue
Behold for goddis sake that sitte aboue
Se hough they bleed be they not wel arrayed
Thus hath their lord the god of loue hem payed
Her wagis and her fees for her ꝸseruice
And they wene that they ben ful wise
That ꝸseruen loue for ought that may befall
But this is yit the best game of alle
That she for whom thattheythatey haue this Iolite
Conneth hem as much thank as me
She wote nomore of al this hoot fare
By god no more then woot a cucco of an hare
But al must been assayed hote and cold
A man must be fole or yong or olde
I woot it by myselue ful long agone
For in my tyme a ꝸseruaunt was I one
And therfore sith I know of loues peyn
And wote hough sore it can a man distreyn
As he that hath ben caught ofte in his lace
I you foryeue as hoolly your trespace
At request of my quene that knelith here
And eke of Emely my sustir dere
And ye shul anone both vnto me swere
That neuer more ye shul my cuntrey dere
Ne make werre upon me nyght ne day
But be my frendis in alle that euꝰer ye may
I you foryeue this trespace euerydele
And they him swore his axyng feire ⁊ wele
And him of lordship and of mercy preyd
And he hem grauntid grace and thus he seid
To speke of rialle lynage and of richesse
Theygh that she were a quene or a pirincesse
Eche of you both is wurthy doutlesse
To wedde whan tyme is but nathelesse
I speke as for my suster Emelye
For whom ye haue this strife and Ielousye
Ye wote yourselue she may not wedde two
Attones / though ye fighten euer moo
That one of you al be him lothe or lefe
He mut go pipe in an Ivy leef
This is to sey she may not now haue bothe
Alle ye neuer so ielous and so wrothe
And for thy I you putte in this degre
That eche of you shal haue his destinee
As him is shapen / and herken in what wise
Lo here your ende of that I shalle diuise
My wille is this for platte conclusion
Without any maner replicacion
If that you liketh take it for the best
That eche of you shal go wher him lest
Frely without raunson outhir daunger
And this day fifty wekis ferre ne nere
Eche of you shal bring an hundrid knyghteꝭes
Armed for the listis vp at alle rightis
Al redy to darreyne hir by bataile
And thus bihote I you withouten faile
Vpon my trouth / and as I am a knyght
That whethir of you both that hath myght
This is to sey that whethir he or thou
May with his hundrid knyghtꝭes as I spak now
Sle his contrary or out of listis dryue
Him shal I yeue Emely to wyue
To whom that Fortune yeueth so feir a grace
The listis shal I make in this place
And god so wisly on my soule rue
As I shal euen Iuge be and true
Ye shul none othir ende with me make
That one of you shal be dede or take
And if you think this is wele seid
Seyeth your avise and hold you wel payd
This is your ende and your conclusion
Who lokith light now but Palamon
Who springith up for ioye but Arcite
Who coude telle or who coude it endite
The ioye that is made in that place
Whan Theseus had done so feir a grace
But doun on knees went euery maner wight
And thankid him withalle her hert and myght
And namely the Thebans often sithe
And thus with good hoōmp and hert blithe
They take her leue ⁊ homward ride
To Thebes ward with olde wallis wide

l.hi: Explicit pars pirima ⁊ incipit ꝑpers secunda

div.l: x trow men wold it deme neccligence
If I forgete to telle the dispence
Of Theseus that goth bisily
To make up the listis rially
That such a noble Theatre as it was
I dar wel sey in this world ther nas
The circuite a myle was about
Wallid with stone and dichid wel about
Round was the shappe in maner of compace
Fulle of degrees the hight of sixty pace
That whan a man was set in one degre
He lettid not his felou for to se
Estward ther stode a gate of Marble white
Westward right suc anothir in thopposite
And shortly forto conclude such a place
Was none in erth as in so litel a space
For in that lond ther nas no crafty man
That Geometry or Ars metric can
Ne purtreyour ne keruer of ymagis
That Theseus ne yaf mete and wagis
The Theatre forto make and forto devise
And forto do his rite and sacrifice
He Estward hath upon the gate aboue
In wurship of venus goddesse of loue
Do make an Auter and an oratorye
And on the westward in the memorye
Of Mars / he make hath right such anothir
That largely cost of gold a fothir
And Northward in a turrette of the walle
Of Alabastir white and rede Coralle
An oratory riche forto se
In wurship of Diane goddesse of chastite
Hath Theseus do wrought in noble wise
But yit had I forgete forto diuise
The noble keruyng and the purtratures
The shappe the contenaunce and the figures
That were in the oratoryes thre
First in the temple of Venus maistow se
Wroght on the walle fulle pitous to bihold
The broken slepis and the sighis cold
The salt teeris and the weymenting
The firy strokis of the desiring
That loues ꝸseruauntꝭes in this lif enduren
The othis that her couenauntꝭes assuren
Plesaunce and hoop desire ⁊ fool hardinesse
Beaute and youth baudrye richesse
Charmes and fors lesingis flatry
Dispence bisinesse and Ielousye
That werid of yelow gooldis a garlond
And a Cucco sittyng on her hond
Festis . Instrumentis . carollis dauncis
Iustis and array and al the circumstancꝭes
Of loue / which that I rekend ⁊ reken shalle
By ordre were peintid on the walle
And mo than I can make of mencion
For sothely al the Mount of Citheron
Ther Venus hath hir principalle duelling
Was shewid on the walle in purtreying
With alle the gardine and the lustinesse
Nought was forgeten the porters idilnesse
Ne Narcisus the feire / of long agon
Ne yit the foly of king Salomon
Ne yit the gret strength of Ercules
Þenchanntmentꝭes of Medea and Circes
Ne of Turnus the hard courage
The riche Cresus caitius in ꝸseruage
Thus may ye se that wisdom ne richesse
Beaute ne sleight strength ne hardinesse
Ne may with venus hold champartie
For as hir lust the world then may she gye
Lo al this folk so caught were in hir lace
Til they for wo ful often seid alas
Sufficith her ensamples one or two
And though I couth reken a thousand moo
The statue of Venus glorious vuto see
Was nakid fleting in the large See
And from the nauel doun al couꝰered was
With wawis grene as bright as eny glas
A Citil in hir right hand hadde she
And on hir hede fulle semely vnto se
A rose garland fressh and wele smelling
Aboue hir hede hir her douvis flikering
Beforn hir stode hir sonne Cupido
Vpon his shuldres wingis had he two
And blinde he was as it is often sene
A bow he bare and Arrowis bright ⁊ kene
Why shuld I not as wel eke telle you alle
The purtrature that was upon the walle
Withun the temple of mighti Mars þe rede
And peintid was the walle in length ⁊ brede
Like to the estirs of the grisly place
That hight the gret temple of Mars in Trace
And in this colde frosty Region
Ther as Mars hath his souꝰereyn mansion
First on the walle was peintid a Forest
In which ther duellid neithir man ne best
With knotty knarry bareyn trees olde
Of stubbis sharpe and hidous to biholde
And downward from an hille vndir a bent
Ther stode a temple of Mars Armipotent
Wrought of bourned stele of which the entre
Was long and streit and grisly vnto se
And therout cam a rage and such a feze
That it made alle the gate forto rese
The Northirn light in at the doris shone
For window on the walle was ther none
Thurgh which men might any light discern
The doris were alle Athemauntis etern
Y clenchid ouꝰerthwart and endlong /
With Iren tough / ⁊ forto make it strong
Euery piler the temple to sustene
Was tonne gret / of Iren bright ⁊ shene
Ther saugh I first the derk ymagenyng
Of felony / and alle the cumpassing
The cruel Ire rede as eny glede
The pike purs and eke the pale drede
The smyler with the knyf vndir the clook
The shipne brennyng with the blak smoke
The treson of the morthering in the bedde
The open werris with woundis al be bledde
Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
Alle fulle of chirking was that sery place
The sleer of himselue yit saugh I there
His hert blood hath bathid alle his here
The nayle y dryue in the shade a nyght
The cold deth with mouthe gaping vpright
Amyddis of the temple sate myschaunce
With discumfort and sory countenaunce
Yit saugh I woodnesse laughing in his rage
Armed compleint outesse and fers outrage
The bareyn in the bussh with throte y corue
A thousand slayn and not with qualme y storue
The tirant of his prey with force y rafte
The toun distroied ther nas nothing laft
Yit saugh I brent the shippis hopsteris
The hunt stranglid with the wilde beris
The Sowe frete the child right in the Cradil
The Cook scallid for alle his long ladil
Nought was forgeten by the Infortune of Mart
The Carter ouꝰer riden with his Cart
Vndir the whele ful lowe he lay adoun
Ther were also of Martis diuision
The Barbour the Bochour and the Smyth
That forgith sharp swerdis on his stith
And al aboue depeintid in a toure
Saugh I Conquest sitting in gret honour
With the sharp swerd ouer his hede
Hanging by a subtile twynes threde
Depeintid was ther the slauȝtir of Iulius
Of gret Nero and of Anthonius
Al be that time they were vnborn
Yit was their deth depeintid ther biforn
By manacyng of Mars right by figure
So was it shewid in that purtrature
As is depeintid in the Sterris aboue
Who shal be slayne or ellis dede for loue
Sufficith one ensample in stories olde
I may not reken hem alle if that I wold
The Statue of Mars upon a Cart stood
Armed / and lokid grymme as he were wood
And ouer his hede thershyne two figures
Of sterris / that ben clepid in Scriptures
That one Puella that othir Rubeus
This god of armis was arrayed thus
A wulf ther stode beforn him at his fete
With eyen rede and of a man he ete
With subtile pensil was depeintid this storye
In redoyting of Mars and of his glorye
Now to the temple of Diane the chast
As shortly as I can I wil me hast
To telle you alle the discripcion
Depeintid ben the wallis vp and doun
Of hunting and of shamefast chastite
Ther saw . I . hough wofulle Calistope
Whan that Diane agreued was with hir
Was turned from a woman to a Bere
And aftir was she made the lode sterre
Thus was it peintid I can sey you no ferre
Hir sonne is eke a sterre as men may se
Ther saugh I Dane y turned vnto a tre
I mene not the goddesse Diane
But Penneus doughtir which þat hight Diane Dane
There saugh I . Attheon an hert ymaked
There saugh I. many anothir wundir story
The which me list not drawe to memorye
This goddesse ful high on an hert sete
With smale houndis al about hir fete
And vndirneth hir fete she had a mone
Wexing it was and shuld wane sone
In gaudy grene hir statue clothid was
With bowe in hand and arrowis in a cace
Hir eyen cast she ful lowe adoun
Ther Pluto hath his derk Regioun
A woman trauailyng was hir beforn
But for hir child so long was vnborn
Fulle pitously lucina gan she calle
And seid help for thou mayst best of alle
Wel coude he peinte lyuely that it bought
With many a Florine he the th hues bought
¶ Now ben thees listis made and Theseus
That at his gret cost arrayed thus
The templis and the Theatire euꝰery dele
Whan it was done him liked wondir wele
But stint I wil of Theseus a lyte
And of Palamon wil I speke and of Arcite
The day approchith of her retournyng
That eche shuld an hundrid knightis bring
The batail to darreyn as I you told
And to Athenes her couenaunt forto hold
Hath eche of hem brought an hundrid knyghtꝭes
Wel armed for the werre atte alle rightis
And sicurly ther trowid many a man
That neuer syn that the world began
As forto speke of knighthode of her hond
As ferre as god hath made see and lond
Nas of so few so noble a cumpany
For euery wight that loued cheualry
And wold his thankes haue a passant name
Hath preyed he might be of that game
And wele was him that therto chosen was
For if ther fil tomorou such a caas
Ye know wel that euery lusty knight
That loueth ꝑperamours and hath his myght
Were it in Englond or ellis where
They wold her thankis willen to be there
To fight for a lady . o . bndicite
It were a lusty thing vnto se
And right so ferd they with Palamon
With him ther went knightis many one
Sum wold be armed in an haubergeon
And in a Brest plate and in a light gipon
And sum wil haue a peire of platis large
And sum wil haue a Pruce shild or a targe
Sum wil be armed on his leggis wele
And haue an Axe and sum a Mase of stele
Ther nys no new gise that it nas olde
Armed were they as I haue you tolde
Eche aftir his ovne oppinion
Ther maystow se comyng with Palamon
Ligurge himselue the gret kyng of Trace
Blak was his berd ⁊ manly was his face
The cerclis of his eyen in his hede
They glouden betuyx yelow and rede
And like a griffon lokid he about
With kempe heris on his browis stout
His lymmes gret his brawnes hard ⁊ strong
His shuldirs brood his armes rounde ⁊ long
And as the gise was in his cuntre
Ful high upon a Chare of gold stode he
With foure white Bolis in the trays
In stede of Cotearmure ouer his harnays
With nayles yelou and bright as any gold
He hadde a Bereskyn cole blak for olde
His long here was kembid behinde his bakke
As any Ravens fethir it shone for blacke
A wrethe of gold arme gret of huge wight
Vpon his hede sette ful of stones bright
Of fine Rubies and of diamauntis
About his Chare ther wenten white Alantꝭes
Twenty and mo as gret as any stere
To hunt at the leoun or at the dere
And folowid him with mozel fast ybond
With colers of gold and touretis ful rond
An hundrid lordis had he in his rout
Armed ful wel with hertis stern ⁊ stout
With Arcit in stories as men finde
The gret Emetreus the king of Inde
Vpon a Stede bay ytrappid in stele
Couerid with cloth of gold and diapird wele
Cam riding like the god of Armes Mars
His cotearmure was of cloth of Tars
Couchid with perlis white rounde ⁊ grete
His sadil was of brent gold new y bete
A Mantillet upon his shulder hanging
Bret ful of Rubies rede as fire sparclyng
His crispe here like ringis was y ronne
And that was yelou ⁊ glittring in the son
His nose was high his eyen bright Citrine
His lippis rounde his colour was sanguine
A few fraclis in his face y spreint
Betwix yelou and sumdel blac y meynt
And as a leon he his lokyng cast
Of fyue and twenty yere his age I cast
His berd was wel begūnne forto spring
His voice was as a trumpe thundring
Vpon his hede he werid of laurer grene
A garlond fressh and lusty forto sene
Vpon his hand he bare for his deduyte
An Egle tame as any lily white
An hundrid lordis had he with him ther
Alle armed sauf her handis in alle her ger
Ful richely in alle maner thyngis
For trustith wel that Erlis dukis kingis
Were gaderid in this noble cumpany
For loue and encrece of cheualry
About this kyng ther ranne on euery part
Ful many a tame leon and leopart
And in this wise thees lordis alle ⁊ some
Ben on the Sunday to the Cite come
About pirime / and in the toun alight
This Theseus this duke this wurthy knight
Whan he had brought hem into that Cite
And Inned echone aftir his degre
He festith hem and doth so gret labour
To ease hem and do hem alle honour
That yit men wene that no mannes witte
Of none estate ne coude amende it
The Mynstrelcy the ꝸseruice and the feste
The gret yiftis to the most and lest
The riche array of Theseus Paleice
Ne who sate first ne last upon the deyce
What ladies feirist ben and best dauncing
Or which of hem can best daunce or syng
Ne who most felingly spekith of loue
What haukis sitten upon perch aboue
What houndis lyen on the flore adoun
Of al this make I now no mencion
But al theffect that thinkith me the best
Now cometh the point and herken if ye lest
¶ The Sonday nyght or day began to spring
Whan Palamon herd the lark syng
Although it were not day by houres two
Yit sang the lark / and Palamon right tho
With hool hert and with an high corage
He roos to wende upon his pilgremage
Vnto the blisful Citheria benyngne
I mene Venus honurable and digne
And in hir houre he walkith furth a pace
Vnto the listis ther ther hir temple was
And doun he knelith with an humble cher
And hert sore / and seid as ye shul here
Feirist of feir O lady myne Venus
Doughtir of Ioue and spouse of vlcanus
Thou glader of the mount of Citheron
For that loue thou haddist to
Haue pite on my bittir teris smert
And take myn humble preyer at thine hert
Alas I naue no langage forto telle
Theffectis and the tormentis of myn helle
Myn hert may myn harmes not bewreye
I am so confuse that I can not seye
But mercy lady bright that knowist wele
My thought / and seest what harme I fele
Considre alle this and rue vpon my sore
As wisly as I shalle euermore
Enforce my myght thy true ꝸseruant to be
And hold werre alwey with chastite
That make I myn avow so ye me help
I kepe not of armes forto yelp
Ne I ne aske to morou forto haue victory
Ne renoun in this caas ne veinglory
Of price of armes blown up and doun
But I wole haue fully possessioun
Of Emely / and dye in hir seruice
Fynde þe the maner hough ⁊ in what wise
I recche not / but it may bettir be
To haue victory of hem or they of me
So that I haue my lady in myn armis
For by Mars that is god of armys
Your vertue is so gret in heuen aboue
That if you list I shal wel haue my loue
Your temple wil I wurship euꝰermo
And on your Auter whethir I ride or go
I wil do sacrifice and firis bete
And if ye wil not so my lady swete
Than prey I you to morou with a spere
That Arcit me thurgh the hert bere
Than recche I not whan I haue lost my lif
Though that Arcit wynne hir to his wif
This is theffect and ende of my preyere
Yeue me my loue my blissid lady dere
¶ And whan the orison was don of Palamon
His sacrifice he did and that anon
Fulle pitously with alle circumstancis
Al telle I not as now his obꝸseruauncis
But at last the Statue of Venus shook
And made a signe wherby that he took
That his preyer accept was that day
For though the signe shewid a delay
Yit wist he wel that grauntid was his bone
And with glad hert he went home ful sone
The third hour in equale that Palamone
Began to Venus temple forto gone
Vp rose the Snne and up rose Emely
And to the temple of Diane gan she hye
The maidens that she thider with hir hadde
Ful redy with hem the fire they ladde
Thencence the clothis and the remenant all
That to the sacrifice longen shalle
The hornes ful of Methe as was the gise
Ther lackid nought to do hir sacrifice
Smokyng the temple ful of clothis fair
This Emely with hert debonair
Hir body wissh with watir of a welle
But hough she did hir rite I dar not telle
But it be any thing in generalle
And yit were a game to here it alle
To him that meneth wel it wer no charge
But it is good a man be at his large
Hir bright here was kembid vntressid all
A corone of a grene Oke serialle
Vpon hir hede was sette ful feir ⁊ mete
Two firis on the Auter gan she bete
And did hir thingis as men may beholde
In Stace of Thebes and thees bokis olde
Whan kyndlid was the fire with pitous cher
Vnto Diane she spake as ye may here
O chast goddesse of the woodis grene
To whom bothe heuen and erth and See is sene
Quene of the reame of Pluto derke and lowe
Goddesse of maidens that myn hert hast knowe
Ful many a yere / and wost what I desire
As kepe me fro thy vengeaunce and thyn Ire
That Atheon abought fulle cruelly
Chast goddesse wel wostou that I
Desire to be a maide alle my life
Ne neuer wold I be loue ne wife
I am the wurst yit of thy cumpany
A maide and loue hunting and venery
And forto walke in wodis wilde
And not to be a wife and haue a childe
Nought wil I know of cumpany of man
Now help me lady sith ye may and can
For the thre fourmes that thou hast in thee
And Palamon that such loue hath to me
And eke Arcite that loueth me so sore
This grace I pray thee withoute more
And send loue and pece betuene hem two
And fro me turne awey her hertis so
That al her hote loue and desire
And al her bisy torment and her fire
Be queynt or turned in anothir place

That was not wont to se the snne bright
Ne hough the fire was couchid first with stree
And than with drie stickis clove a thre
And than with grene wood and spicery
And than with clothe of gold and with perry
And gerlondis hanging with ful many a flour
The Mirre thencence with alle swete odour
Ne hough Arcit lay among alle this
Ne what riches about his body is
Ne hough that Emely as was the gise
Put in the fire of funeral seruice
Ne hough she swowyth whan men made was þe fire
Ne what she spak ne what was hir desire
Ne what Iuelles men in this fire cast
Whan the fire was hoot and brent fast
Ne hough sum cast her shild and sum her sper
And of her vestimentis which that they were
And cuppis fulle of wine milke and blood
Into the fire that brent as it were wood
Ne hough the Grekis with An huge rout
Thries ridde the fire alle about
Vpon the lift hand with loude shouting
And thries with her speris clatring
And thries hough the lady gan crye
And hough that homward ladde was Emely
Ne hough Arcite is brent vnto Asshen colde
Ne hough that liche wake was y hold
Alle that nyght / ne hough that the grekis pley
The wake pleyes ne kepe I not to sey
I wil not telle alle hough they gone
Home to Athenes whan the pley is done
But shortly to the point than wil I wende
And maken of my long tale an ende
¶ By processe and by length of certen yeris
Al stynt is the mournyng and the teris
Of Grekis / by one generalle assent
Than semed me ther was a ꝑperlement
At Athenes upon a certein point ⁊ caas
Among which pointis y spoken was
To haue with certen cuntrees alliaunce
And haue fulli of Thebans obeisaunce
Furth which this noble Theseus anon
Lete send aftir gentle Palamon
Vnwist of him what was the cause why
But in his blake clothis soroufully
He come at his comaundement in hye
Than sent Theseus for Emely
Whan they were sette and hussht was al þe place
And Theseus abiden hath a space
Or any wurd cam from his wise brest
His eyen sette he there as was his lest
And with a sadde visage he sighid stille
And aftir that right thus he seid his wille
The first mever of the cause aboue
Whan he first made the feire cheyn of loue
Grete was theffect and high was his entent
Wel wist he why and what therof he ment
For with that cheyne of loue he bond
The fire the Ayer the watir and the lond
In certen boundis that thei may not fle
That same Prince and that mever coth he
Hath stablisst in this wrechid world adon
Certeyne dayes of enduracion
To alle that ben engendrid in this place
Ouer the which day they may not pace
Al may they yit the daies abregge
Ther nedith none auctorite to allegge
For it is ꝓproued by veray experience
But that me lust declare my sentence
Than may men wel by this ordre discern
That thilk mever stable is and eterne
Wel may men know but it be a fool
That euery partie is diriued from his hool
For nature hath not taken his begynnyng
Of no partie of the cāntelle of a thing
But of a thing that parfit is and stable
Descending so til he be corrumpable
And therfore this wise purueaunce
Hath so wele bisette his ordinaunce
That spacis of thingis and ꝓprogressions
Shul endure by successiouns
And not eterne withouten any lye
This maistou vndirstond and se at eye
Lo the oke that hath so long a norisshing
Fro the time that it gynneth first to spryng
And hath so long a life as ye may se
Yit at last wastid is the tree
Considre eke hough that the harde stone
Vndir oure foot on which we trede ⁊ gone
Yit wastith it as it lith by the wey
The brode Ryuer sumtime waxith drie
The gret townes se we wast and wende
Than ye se that al this thing hath ende
Of men ⁊ women se we welle also
That nedes in one of the termes two
This is to sey in youthe or ellis age
He must be dede the kyng as shal a page
Sum in his bedde sum in the depe see
Sum in the large feld as ye may se
Ther helpith not alle goth that ilke wey
Than may I sey that al this thing must deye
What makith this but Iubiter the kyng
That is Prince and causer of alle thing
Coueiting alle vnto his ꝓpropre wille
From which it is derreyued soth to telle
And here ayens no creature on lyue
Of any degre auailith forto stryue
Than is it wisdom as it thinkith me
To maken vertue of necessite
And take it wel that we may not eschue
And nameli that to us alle is due
And who so grucchith ought he doth foly
And rebelle is to him that alle may guye
And certenli a man hath most honouer
To dye in his excellence and in his flour
Whan he is secur of his good name
Than hath he done his frendis ne him shame
And gladder aught his frendis be of his deth
Whan with honuer yolden is his brethe
Than whan his name appallid is for age
For al forgeten is his vessellage
Than is it best as for a wurthy fame
To dye whan he is best of name
The contrary of al this is wilfulnesse
Why grucche we why haue we heuynesse
That good Arcit of cheualry the floure
Departid is with duete and honoure
Out of this foule prison and this life
Why grucchen here his cosin ⁊ his wife
Of his welfare that loued hem so wele
Conneth he hem thank nay god woot neuꝰer a dele
That both his soule and eke hem offende
And yit they may her lustis not amende
What may I conclude of this long sery
But aftir sorou I rede us to be mery
And thank Iubiter of alle his grace
And or we depart from this place
I rede we make of sorwis two
One parfite Ioye lasting euꝰermo
And loke now where most sorou is her In
Ther wil I first amend and begynne
Sustir coth he this is my fulle assent
With alle thavise here of my parlement
That gentle Palamon your owen knight
That ꝸserueth you with wille and hert ⁊ myght
And euer hath done sith ye first hym knew
That ye shul of your grace upon him rue
And take him for husbond and for lord
Lene me your hand for this is oure accord
Lat se now of your womanly pite
He is a kingis brothir sone parde
And though he were a pore Bachiller
Sith he hath ꝸserued you so many a yer
And hadde for you so grete aduersite
Hit must be considrid levith me
For gentle merci aught to passe right
Than seid he thus to Palamon the knight
I trow ther nedith litle sermonyng
To make you assent to this thing
Cometh nere and take your lady by þe hand
Betwene hem anone was made the band
That hight matrimoiyn or mariage
By alle the counseil and the Baronage
And thus with alle blis and melody
Hath Palamon weddid Emely
And god that alle this world hath wrouȝt
Send him his loue that it dere hath bought
For now is Palamon in alle wele
Lyuyng in blisse in richesse and in hele
And Emeli him loueth so tendirly
And he hir serueth so gentilly
That was ther no wurd hem bitwene
Of Ielousy or any othir tene
Thus endith Palamon and Emely
And god saue alle this feir cumpany

l.hi: Here begynneth the prolog of the Miller

div.l: wHan þat the knight had þus his tale told
In al the cumpany nas þer yong ne old
Þat he ne seid it was a noble storye
And wurthy forto be drawe in memorye
And namely the gentiles euerichone
Oure host lough and swere so mot I gone
This goth aright vnbokild is the male
Lat se now who shal telle anothir tale
For truli the game is wel bignne
Now telle ye syr Monk if that ye kune
Sumwhat to quyte with the knightis tale
The Milner that for drunke was al pale
So that vnnethe upon his hors he satte
He wold auale neithir hood ne hatte
Ne abide no man for no curtesy
But in pilatis voice he gan to crie
And swore by armes blood and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
With the which I wil quite the knightꝭes tale
Oure host saugh that he was drunk of ale
And seid abide Robyn leve brothir
Sum bettir man shal telle us first anoþꝰer
Abide and lat vs wurch thriftily
Be goddis soule coth he that wil not I
For I wil speke or ellis go my wey
Oure host answerd telle on a xxtiri deuel wey
Thou art a fole thy witte is ouer com
Now herken qd the Milner al and sum
But first I make a protestacioun
Þat I am drunk I know it be my soun
And therfore if I mysspeke or sey
Wite it the ale of Suthwerk I you prey
For I wil telle a legend and a life
Both of a Carpinter and of his wif
Hough that a Clerc sette a carpinters cappe
The Reve answerd and seid stint thy clappe
Lat be thy lewde drunken harlotrye
It is a synne and eke grete foly
To appeyre any man or him diffame
And eke to bring wyues in such blame
Thou maist enough of othir thingis seyn
This drunken Milner spak ful sone ageyn
And seid leue brothir Oswold
Who hath no wife is no cokewold
But I sey not therfore that thou art one
Ther ben ful good wyues many one
Why artow angry with my tale now
I haue a wif parde as wel as thou
Yit wold I not for the oxen in my plough
Take upon me more than enough
And to deme on my selue þat I wer one
I wil bileue that I am none
An husbond shuld neuer be inquisitif
Of goddis priuite ne of his wif
For so he finde goddis fuson ther
Of the remenaunt nedith not to enquer
B What shuld I more sey but this Milner
He nold for noman his wurdis forbere
But told his cherlis tale in this maner
Me forthink that I shalle where it her
Wherfore euꝰery gentle wight I prey
Demeth not for goddis loue that I sey
Of euel entent / but that I must rehers
Theyr talis / albe they bettir or wers
Or ellis falsen sum of my matire
And therfore whoso lust it not to here
Turne ouer the leef and seche anoþꝰer tale
For ye shul finde enow gret and smale
Of storial thing that touchith gentilnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blameth not me though þat ye chese amys
The Milner is a cherle ye know wel this
So was the Reue eke and othir mo
And harlotrie they tolden both two
Auisith you and putte me out of blame
And eke men shuld not make ernest of game
wHilom ther was duelling in Oxenford
A riche gnoffe that gestis held to bord
And of his craft he was a Carpentꝰer .
With him ther was duelling a Scoler
Had lernid Art but alle his fantasie
Was turned to lern Astrologie
And coude a certeyn of conclusione
To deme by Interrogacions
If that men askid him in certein houris
Whan that men shuld haue drought or shourꝭes
Or if men askid him what shuld befalle
Of euery thing I may not reken alle
Or if men askid
And therto he was right sligh and pirivee .
And like a maiden vnto se .
This clerc was clepid hend Nicholas
Of derne loue he coude and of solace
A chambre had he in that hostery
Allone without any cumpany
Ful fetisly dight with herbis sote
And he him selue as swete as is the rote
Of licorice or of any Setwale
His almagist and bokis gret ⁊ smale
His Astrelabur longing for his art
His Augrym stones lyen feir appart
On h Shelues couchid at his beddis hede
His presse couꝰered with a falding rede
And al above ther lay a gay Sautry
On the which he made on nyghtis melodie
So swetely that alle the chambre rong
And angelus ad virginem was his song
And aftir that he sang the kingis note
Ful often was blissid his mery throte
And thus this swete clerc his time spent
Aftir his frendis finding and aftꝰer his rent
This Carpintꝰer had weddid a new wif
Whom that he loued as his lif
Of xviij yere she was of age
Ielouse he was and held hir narrow in cage
For she was yong and wilde and he was olde
And demed himselue to ben a cocolde
He knew not Catou for his witte was rude
That badde man wedde his similitude
Men shuld wedde aftir their estate
For youth and age is often at debate
But sithen he was falle in the snare
He must endure as othir folk don her care
Faire was this yong wif and therwithall
As any wesil hir body gentle and smalle
A Seint she werid y barrid al of Silke .
A barme cloth as white as any milke
And upon hir lendis sate many a gore
White was hir smokke and broudid al bifore
And eke behinde on hir coler about
Of cole blac silke withyn and eke without
The tapis of hir white volupere
Were of the same sute with hir coler
Hir fillet brood of silke and sette ful hie .
And sicurli she hadde a licorous eye
Ful smal y pullid wer hir browis two .
And they were bent and blac as any slo
She was more blisfulle forto se
Than is the new pere Ienet tre
And softer than is the wulle of a fethir
And by hir cote ther hinge a purse of lethir
Y tassild with silk and perlid with latou
In alle this world to seche up and doun
Ther is noman so wise that couth thenche
So gay a pupplot or such a wenche
For brighter was the shynyng of hir hue
Than in the Toure the noble forgid newe
But of hir song it was so loude and yern
As any Swalou sitting on a Bern
Therto she couth skippe and make a game
As any kidde or Calf folowing his dame
Hir mouthe was swete as any bragot or meth .
Or hord of appuls leid in hony or heth
Winsing she was as is a ioly colt
Long as a maste and upright as a bolt
A broche she bare on hir loue coler
As brood as is the boos of a bokeler
Hir Shoes were lasid on hir leggis hie
She was a primerol a piggisnye .
For any lord to ligge in his bedde .
Or yit for any good yoman to wedde
¶ Now sir and efte sir so bifil the cas .
That on a day this hend Nicholas .
Fille with this yong wif to rage ⁊ pley
Whils that hir husbond was at Osney
And clerkis arn ful subtile and ful queint
And priueli he caught hir by the queint
And seid y wis but if I haue my wille
For dern loue of thee leman I spille
And held hir hard by the haunche bones
And seid leman loue me wel attones .
Or I shal deye so god me saue
And she sprang as colt doth in a trave
And with hir hede she roried fast awey
She seid I nylle not kis the by my fey
Wy labbe coth she labbe Nicholas
Or I wil crie out harrou and alas
Do awey your handis of your curtesy
This Nicholas gan merci forto crie
And spake so fair and ꝓprofird him so fast
That she hir loue graunt him at last
And swore hir othe by seint Thomas of kent
That she wold be at his comaundement .
Whan that she may hir leisour wel aspye
Myn husbond is so fulle of ielousy
That but ye waite wel and be pryvee
I wote right wel I am but dede coth she
Ye must be fulle dern as in this cas .
Nay therof care you not coth hend Nicholas
A Clerc hadde litle besette his while
But if he couthe a Carpinter begile
And thus they were acordid and y sworn
To waite a time as ye han herd biforn
And whan Nicholas had do thus eueridele
And thackid hir about the lendis wele
He kissith hir swete and takith than his Sautry
And pleyeth fast and makith melodie
Than fille it thus that to the parissh church
Cristis ovne werkis forto wurche
This good wif went on an haliday
Hir forhede shone as bright as any day
So was it wassh whan she lete hir werk
Now was ther of that church a parissh clerk
Which that was clepid Absolon
Crullid was his here and as gold it shone
And stroutid as a fanne large and brood
Ful streight and euen lay his ioly shood
His rudde was reed his eyen grey as goos
With poulis windowis corven on his shoos .
In hosen rede he went fulle fetisly
And gird he was ful smalle and ꝓpropirly
And in a cote of light wachette
Ful feir and thicke ben the pointis sette
And therupon he hadde a gay Surplice
White as is the blossum on the Rice
A mery child he was as god me saue
Wel couth he let blood cluppe and shaue
And make a chartre of lond or acquitauce
In twenti maner he couth trippe ⁊ daunce
Aftir the scole of Oxinford thoo .
And with his leggis cast he to and fro
And pley songis many on a Ribible
Therto he sang sumtime a loude quinyble
And as wel couth he pley on a gittern
In al the tovne nas ther bruhous ne tauꝰerne
That he ne uisite with his solace
There as any gay tapster was .
But soth to sey he was sumdel swaymo9us
Of farting and of speche daungerous
This Absolon that ioly was and gay
Goth with a Sencer on the haliday
Sencing the wyues of the parissh fast
And many a louely look on hem cast
And namely on this Carpinters wife
To loke on hir him thought a mery life
She was so ꝓpropre sote and licorous
I dar wel sey and she had ben a mouse
And he a catte he wold hir hent anone
This parissh clerc this ioly Absolou
Hath in his hert such a loue longing
That of no wife toke he offring
For curtesy he seid he wold none
The mone whan it was nyght ful briȝt shone
And Absolon his gittern hath y take
For ꝑperamours he thought forto wake
And furth he goth iolif and amorous
Til he cam to the carpinters hous
A litle aftir the cockis had y crow
And dressid him up by a shot windou
That was upon the carpinters walle
He singith in his voice gentle ⁊ smalle
Now dere lady if your wille be
I pray you that ye wil think on me
Ful wel accordaunt to his gittirnyng
This carpinter awook and herd him sing
And spac vnto his wif and seid anon
What Alison heristou not Absolon
That singith this vndir oure chambr wall .
And she answerd hir husbond ayen withalle
Yis god wote Ion I hereit eueridele
This pas furth what wil ye bett than wele
Fro day to day this ioly Absolon
So wowith hir that him is wo bigon
He wakith al the nyght and al the day
He kembith his lockis and makith him al gay
He wowith hir by meanes and by brocage
And swore he wold be hir owne page
He singith brokingis as a nyghtingale
He sent hir pyment meth and spicid ale
And wafirs piping hoot out of the glede
And for she was of tovne he ꝓprofird hir mede
For sum folk wil wow women with riches
And sum with strokis and sum with gentilnes .
Sumtime to shew his lightnesse ⁊ maistry
He pleyeth herodis vpoūn a scaffold hye
But what auailith it him as in this caas
She loueth so this hende Nicholas .
That Absolou may blow the buckis horn
He nath for his labour but a scorne .
And thus she makith Absolon hir ape .
And alle his ernest turneth to a iape
For true is this ꝓprouerbe it is no lye
Men seyn thus alwey the nygh slye .
Makith the ferre lefe to be lothe .
For though that Absolon be wood or wroth
Because that he was ferre from hir sight
Thus nygh stood Nicholas in his light
But now bere thee wel hende Nicholas .
For Absolon may waile and sing alas
And so befil it on a Satursday .
This carpinter was gon to Osnay
And hende Nicholas and Alisou
Accordid ben to this conclusiou
That Nicholas shal shape him a wile
This celi ielous husbond forto begile
And if so be the game went aright .
She shuld slepe in his armes al nyȝt
For this was his desire and hirs also
And right anon without wurdis mo
This Nicholas no lenger wold tary
But doth ful soft vnto his chambr cary
Both mete and drink for a day or twey
And bad hir to hir husbond seye
If that he askid aftir Nicholas .
That she shuld sey she nyst wher he was
Of al that day she saugh him not wtith eye
She trowid that he was in sum maladye
For for no crie hir maide couth him calle
He nold ansuers for thing that might befalle
This passith furth alle that Saturday
That Nicholas stille in his chambre lay
And ete and slept and did what him lest
Til Sonday that the sune goth to rest
This celi carpinter had gret meruaile
Of Nicholas what thing might him ayle
And seid I am adredde by seint Thomas
It stant nat aright with hend Nicholas
God shilde that he deyed sodeinly
The world is now ful ticle sicurly
I saugh to day a corse born to church
That on monday last I saugh him wurch
Go up coth he vnto his knaue anone
Clepe at his dore or cnocke fast wtith a stone
Loke hou it is and telle me boldili
This knaue goth up fulle sturdily
And at chambre dore whils he stood
He cried and cnockid as he were wood
What how what do ye maistir Nicholay
Hough mai ye slepe al the long day
But al for nought he herd not a wurd
An hool he fond ful low upon a borde
There the catte was wont in forto crepe
And at that hole he lokid in fulle depe
And at last he had of him a sight
This Nicholas sate euer gaping upright
As he had keyked on the new mone
A doun he goth and told his maistꝰer sone
In what array he saugh this ilke man
This carpinter to blis him began
And seid now help us seint Frideswide
A man woot litle what him shal betide
This man is falle with his astronomy
In sum woodnesse or in sum agony
I thought ay wel hough that it shuld be
Men shuld not know of goddis priuite
Ye blissid be alwey a lewde man
That nought but only his bileue can
Right so ferd anothir clerc with astronomy
He walkid in the feldis forto prye
Vpoūn the Sterris what ther shuld befalle
Til he was in a marle pitte y falle
He saugh not that but yit by seint Thomas
Me rueth sore of hende Nicholas
He shal be ratid out of his studying
If that I may by heuen kyng
Gete me a staffe that I may vndirspore
Whils that thou Robyn heuest up the dore
He shal out of his studying I gesse
And to his chambre dore he him dresse
His cnaue was a strong carle for the nones
And by the haspe bare up the dore attones

This Nicholas satte ay as stille as stone
And euer gapid upward to the Eyre
This carpintꝰer wend he were in dispeir
And hent him by his shuldirs mightily
And shook him hard and cried spitously
What Nicholae what hou loke adoun
Awake and thinkon cristis passiou
I crouche thee from elues and fro wickid wiȝtꝭes
Therwith the nyght spelle seid he anone rightꝭes
On foure halues of the hous about
And on the thresshold of the dore without
Ihu crist and seint Benedight
Blisse this hous from euery wickid wight
For the nyghtmere the white pater nostꝰer .
Wher wentistou seint petir sustir
And at last this hende Nicholas
Gan forto sigh sore and seid alas
Shal al the world be lost eftsones now
This carpintꝰer answerd what seistow
What thynk on god as don we men þtat swink
This Nicholas ansuerd now fecche me drink
And aftir wille I speke in priuite
Of certen thingis that touchen the ⁊ me
I wil telle it none othir man certeyn
This carpinter goth doun ⁊ cometh ageyn
And brought of ale a large quarte
And whan that eche man had drunk his ꝑperte
This Nicholas his dore fast shette
And doun the carpinter by him he sette
And seid Iohn myn host leve and dere
Thou shalt upon thine othe swere her
That to no wight thou shalt my couseil wrey
For it is cristis counseil that I sey
And if thou telle it any man thou art forlore
For this vengeaunce shaltou haue therfore
That if thou wrey me thou shalt be wood
Nay crist forbede it for his holy blood
Coth the celi man I am no blabbe
And though I sey it I am not lefe to gabbe .
Sey what thou wilt I shal it neuer telle .
To wife ne child by him that harowid helle .
Now Iohn coth this Nicholas I wil not lye
I haue founde in myne Astrologye .
That now on monday next at quartꝰer nyght
For I haue lokid in the mone so bright

This world he seid in lasse than an hour
Shal al be dreint so hidous is the shour
Thus shal mankinde drench and lese her lif
This carpintꝰer ansuerd alas my wif
And shal she drench alas myn Alisou
For sorou of this he fille almost a doun
And seid is ther no remedy in this case
Why yis for god coth hende Nicholas
If thou wilt wurche aftir lore and rede
Thou maist not wurch aftir thine ovn hede
For thus seith Salomon þat was ful true
Wurch al bi counseil and thou shalt not rue .
And if thou wurch wil by good counseil .
I vndirtake withouten mast or saile
Yit shal I saue hir and me and thee .
Hastow not herd houȝ saued was Noe
Whan that oure lord had warned him beforn
That al the world with watir shuld be lorn
Yis coth this carpintꝰer fulle yore ago .
Hastou not herd coth Nicholas also .
