Me fro the fende and from his clawis kepe
That day that I shal drench in the depe
¶ Victorious tree ꝓproteccion of alle true
That only wrought were forto bere
The king of heuen with his woundis new
The white lambe that hurt was wtith a sper
Flemer of fendis out of lymme ⁊ here
On which thy lymmes feithfulli extenden
Me help and yeue me myght my lif amenden
¶ Yeris and dayes fletith this creature
Thorout the see of Grece vnto the Streyt
Of Marroc as it is hir aduenture
O many sory mele may she bayt
Aftir hir dethe fulle often may she wayt
Or that the wilde wawis wille hir dryue
Vnto the place ther she shalle aryue
¶ Men myghten axe why she was not sleyn
Eke atte fest who might hir body saue
And I answer to þat demaunde ageyn
Who saued Daniel in the horrible Caue
Þat euery wight saues maistir or cnaue
Was with the leons frette or he astert
No wight but god that he bare in his hert
¶ God list forto shew his windirful miracle
In hir / for we shuld se his mighti werkis
Crist that is to euery harme triacle
By certeyn menes ofte as known clerkis
Doth thing for certeyn ende that ful derk is
To mannes witte / that for oure ignorance
Ne can not know his prudent purueance
¶ Now sith she nas atte the feste y slawe
Who kepith hir from drenching in the See
Who kepith Ionas in the fisshis mawe
Til he was spoutid out at Niniue
Wel may men know it nas no wight but he
Þat kepte the people Ebrait from her drenching
With drye fete thorout the See passing
¶ Who badde the foure Spiritis of þe tempest
Þat power han to annoye lond and See
Both North and South and also est and west
Annoyeth neithir See ne lond ne tree
Sothely the comaunder of that was he
Þat from the tempest ay thus woman kept
As wel whan she wook as whan she slept
¶ Where myght this woman mete ⁊ drink haue
Þat thre yere and more hath lastid hir vitayl
Who the Egipcian Marie in the Caue
Or in desert fedde no wight but crist sannfail
Fyue thousand folk it was a gret merueyle
With loouis fyue and fisshis to fede
God sent hir foyson at hir gret nede
¶ She dryueth furth into oure Occian
Þorout oure wilde see til atte last
Vndir an holt that I nempne can
Ferre in Northumbirlond þe wawe hir cast
And in the sond hir shippe stikith fast
Þat thens wold it not in alle a tyde
The wille of crist was that she shuld abide
¶ The Constable of the Castelle doun is fare
To se this wrake / and al the Shippe he sought
And found this wery woman fulle of care
He found also the tresour that she brought
In hir langage she him besought
Þe lif out of hir body to wynne
He to delyuer the wo that hir body was In
¶ A maner of latine corrupt was hir speche
But algat therby was she vndirstond
This Constable when him list no lengꝰer seche
This woful woman brought he to lond
She knelith doun and thankith goddis sond
But what she was she nold to no man sey
For foule ne ferre þouȝ she shuld deye
¶ She seid she was so mazid in the See
Þat she forgat hir mynde be hir trouth
The Constable hath of hir so gret pite
And eke his wif that they wepen for routh
She was so diligent withouten slouth
To ꝸserue and to pleas euerichon in þat place
Þat alle hir loued that loken in hir face
¶ This Constable and dame Hermengild his wif
Were paynems / as þat cuntrey euꝰermore wer
But hermengild loued hir riȝt as hir lif
And Constaunce hath so long soiourned þer
In orisons with many a bittir tere
Til Ihu hath conuertid þurgh his grace
Dame Hermengild Constablesse of þat place
¶ In alle that lond no cristen durst arrout
Al cristen folk ben fledde fro that cuntre
Thurgh Paynems that conquerd alabout
The plagis of the North lond and see
To Walis went the cristianite
Of olde Britons duelling in this Ile
Ther was her refute for the mean while
¶ But they neuer cristen Britons so exilid
Þat ther nere sum that in her priuite
Honourid crist and hethen they begilid
And nygh the Castel such ther duellid thre
Þat one of hem was blinde ⁊ might not se
But if it were with thilk yze of his mynde
With which men se when they be blynde
¶ Bright was the Snne as the Somer day
For which the Constable and his wif also
And Constaunce han taken the right way
Toward the See a furlong wey or two
To pleye and rome to and fro
And in their walk the blynd menmanmean þey mette
Crokid and olde with eyen fast y shette
¶ In the name of Crist cried this blynd Briton
Dame hermengild yeue me my sight ageyn
The lady wex affrayed of the sonn
Lest þat hir husbond shortly forto seyn
Wold hir for Ihu cristis loue slayn
Til Constaunce made hir bold ⁊ bad hir wirch
Þe wille of Crist / as doughtir of holichurch
¶ The Constable wax abasshid of that sight
And seid what amountith al this fare
Constaunce ansuerd and seid it is Cristis miȝt
Þat helpith folke out of þe fendis snare
And so ferfurth she gan the lady declare
Þat she the Constable or that it vaswasıvas eve
Conuertid and on Crist made him bileue
¶ This Constable was nothing lord of þis place
Of which I speke ther as he Constaunce fond
But kept it strongli many wintirs space
Vndir Alla king of Northumbirlond
Þat was fulle wise and wurthy of his hond
Ageyn the Scottis as men may wel here
But turne I wil ageyn to my matier
¶ Sathan that euer us waitith to begile
Saugh of Constaunce alle hir ꝑperfeccion
And cast anone hou he might quite hir while
And made a yong knight þat duelt in þat toun
Loue hir so hoot of foule affeccion
Þat verily him thought he shuld spille
But he of hir might ones haue his wille
¶ He wowith hir but it auailith nought
She wold do no synne by no weye
And for dispite he cumpast in his thouȝt
To make hir on shameful dethe to dye
He waitith whan the Constable was awey
And pryuely upon a nyght he crepte
Into hermengildis chambre while she slept
¶ Wery for wakid in hir orisons
Slepith Constaunce and hermengild also
This knight thrugh Sathanas temptacions
Alle softily is to bedde y go
And cutte the throte of Hermengild atwo
And leid the blody knyf by dame Constance
And went his wey god yeue him meschance
¶ Sone aftꝰer cometh the Constable home ageyn
And eke Alla that king was of that land
And saugh his wif dispitously sleyn
For which ful ofte he wept ⁊ wrang his hand
And in the bedde the blody knyf he fand
By Dame Constaunce alas what miȝt she sey
For veray wo hir witte was al awey
¶ To king Alla was told alle this mischance
And eke the time and where and in what wise
Þat in a shippe was found this Constaunce
As here beforn ye han herd diuise
Þe kingis hert of pite gan agrise
Whan he saugh so benyngne a creatur
Falle in disease and mysauenture
¶ For as the lambe toward his deth is brouȝt
So stant this Innocent bifore the kyng
Þis fals knight that hath this treson wrouȝt
Berith hir on hand that she hath don þis þing
But natheles ther was gret mournyng
Among the peple / and for they can not gesse
Þat she had done so greet a wickidnesse
¶ For they han sene hir euer so vertuous
And louyng Hermyngild right as hishirhisr lif
Of this bare witnesse euerich in þat hous
Saue he that Hermengild slough wtith his knyf
This gentle king hath caught a gret motif
Of this witnesse and þought he wold enquer
Depper in this caas the trouth to lere
¶ Alas Constaunce thou nast no champion
Ne fight canstow not welaway
But he that starve for oure redempcion
And bond Sathan and yit lithe there he lay
So be thy strong champion this day
For but Crist miracle upon the kithe
Withouten gilt thou shalt be slayn as swithe
¶ She sate hir doun on knees and thus she said
Inmortal god that sauedist Susanne
From fals blame / and thou merciful maide
Mary I mene doughtir to Seint Anne
Biforn whos child Aungels sing Osanne
As I am giltles of this felonye
My socour be or ellis shalle I dye
¶ Haue ye nat seyn sumtime a pale face
Among the prees of him þat hath be lad
Toward his deth / wher as him gat no grace
And such a colour in his face hath had
Men myghte knowe his face þat was bistad
Amongis alle the facis in that rout
So stant Constaunce and lokith hir about
¶ O quenes lyuyng in prosperite
Duchessis and eke ladyes euerichone
Haueth sum ruthe of hir aduersite
An Emꝑperoures doughtꝰer stant allone
She hath no wight whom to make hir mone
O blood royal that stondist in this drede
Ferre ben thy frendis at thy gret nede
¶ This Alla kyng hath such compassion
As gentil hert is fulfillid of pite
That from his iyen ranne þe watꝰer don
Now hastily do fecche a book quod he
And if this knyght wil swere hou þat she
Þis woman slough / yit wil we us avise
Whom that we wil that shal be oure Iustice
¶ A Briton book writen with Euangelies
Was fette / and on this book he swore anon
She gilty was / and in the mene whiles
An hand him smote upon the nek bone
þat doun he fille attones as a stone
And both his eyen brest out of his face
In sight of euery body in that place
¶ A voice was herd in general audience
And seid thou hast disclaundird giltles
The doughtꝰer of holichurch in high pꝰersence
Thus hastou done and yit held I my pece
Of this merueil agast was al the prese
As masid folk they stoden euerychone
For drede of wreche sauf Constance allone
¶ Grete was the drede and eke the repentance
Of hem that had wrong suspecion
Vpon this celi Innocent Constaunce
And for this miracle in conclusion
And by Constanncis good mediacion
The king and many anothꝰer in þat place
Conuertid was / thankid be goddis grace
¶ Þis fals knight was slaine for his vntrouth
By Iugement of Alla hastily
And yit Constaunce had of his deþe gret routh
And aftir that Ihus of his mercy
Made Alla wedde fulle solempnely
This holy woman so bright ⁊ shene
And thus hath Crist made Constance a quene
¶ But who was wofulle if I shal not lye
Of this wedding but Domegild ⁊ no mo
The kingis modir fulle of tirannye
Hir thought hir cursid hert brest in two
She wold not hir sonne had done so
She thought a despite that he shuld take
So straunge a creature to his make
¶ Me list not of the chaff or of the stree
Make so long a tale as of the corn
What shuld I telle of the rialte
At mariagis / and which cours goþ biforn
Who blowith best in a trumpe or in an horn
The frute of euery tale is forto sey
They ete and drink sing daunce ⁊ pley
¶ They gon to bedde as it was skille ⁊ right
For though that wyues don ful holy þingꝭes
They must take pacience a nyght
Such maner necessaries as ben plesingꝭes
To folk that han hem weddid with ryngꝭes
And ley a litle her holynesse a side
As for the time / it may not bettꝰer betide
¶ On hir he gatte a manchild anone
And to a busshop and his Constable eke
He toke his wif to kepe whan he is gone
To Scotlondward his fomen forto seke
Now feir Constaunce þat is so humble ⁊ meke
So long is gone with child til that stille
She halt hir chambir abidyng cristis wille
¶ The time is come a manchild she bere
Mauricius at font stone men him calle
This Constable doth furth come a Messagere
And wrote vnto his king that clepid was Alle
Hough that this blisful tiding is bifalle
And other tidingis spedeful forto seye
He tath the lettirs and furth he goþ his wey
¶ This Messager to done his auauntage
Vnto the kingis modir ridith swithe
And salueth hir feir in his langage
Madame quod he ye may be glad and blithe
And thankidodthankigodthankidgod an hundrid thousand sithe
My lady quene hath child without dout
To ioye and blis of this reine about
¶ Lo here the lettris sealid of this thing
That I must bere with al the hast I may
If ye wil ought vnto your son the king
I am your ꝸseruaunt both night and day
Same Domegild ansuerd at this time nay
But here al nyght I wil thou take thy rest
To morou wil I sey thee what me lest
¶ This Messager drank sadly ale ⁊ wyne
And stolen were his lettirs priuely
Out of his box / whils he slept as a swyne
And countirfetid was fulle subtily
Anothir lettir wrought fulle sinfully
Vnto the king direct of this matier
From his Constable as ye shul aftꝰer her
¶ The lettir spac the quene delyuerid was
Of so horrible a fendli creature
That in the Castel none so hardy was
That any while durst theryn endure
The modir was an Elf by auenture
Y comen by charmes or by sorcery
And echman hatith hir cumpany
¶ Wo was the king whan he þis lre had seyn
But to no wight he told his sorowis sore
But of his ovne hand he wrote ageyn
Welcum the sonde of Crist for euꝰer mor
To me that am now lerned in his lor
Lord welcum be thy lust and thy plesaunce
My lust I putte alle in thyn ordinaunce
¶ Kepith this child al be it foule or feire
And eke my wif vnto myn home comyng
Crist whan him list may send me an heir
This lettir he ensealith priuely weping
Which to the Messager was taken sone
And furth he goth ther is no more to done
¶ O. Messager fulfillidwith drunkennesse
Strong is thy breth thy lymmes faltren ay
And thou bewreyest alle secrenesse
Thy mynde is lorn thou ianglist as a Iay
Thy face is turned alle in a new array
Ther drunkenes reigneth in any rout
Ther is no counseil hidde without any dout
¶ O. Domegild I ne haue none englissh digne
Vnto thy malice and thy tirannye
And therfore vnto the fend I thee resigne
Lat him endite of thy traytory
Fy mannyssh fy / oo nay by god I lye
Fy fondly spirit for I dar wel telle
Though thou here walke thy spirit is in helle
¶ This Messagꝰer cometh fro the king ageyn
And at the kingis modir hous he light
And she was of this Messager ful feyn
And pleasid him in alle þat euer she myght
He drank and wele his curtil vndir pight
He slepith and he fnortith in his gise
Al nyght til the snne gan arise
¶ Efte were his lettirs stolen echon
And countirfetid lettirs in this wise
The king comaundith his Constable anon
Vp peyne of hanging and of his In wise
That he ne shuld suffre in no wise
Constance withyn his ream to abide
Thre dayes and a quarter of a tide
¶ But in the same Shippe as he hir fond
Hir and hir yong sonne and alle hir ger
He shuld putte / and croude hir fro the londꝭes
And charge hir that she neuer efte come þer
O. my Constaunce wel may gost haue fer
And sleping in thy dreme haue penaunce
Whan Domegild cast alle this ordinaunce
¶ This Messagꝰer a morou when he awoke
Vnto the Castel held the nexte wey
And to the Constable he the lettirs toke
And whan that he this pitous lettir sey
Ful ofte he seid alas and welawey
Lord crist quod he hough may this world endur
So fulle of synne is many a creatur
¶ O. myghty god if that it be thy wille
Sith thou art rightfulle Iuge hough may this be
That thou wilt suffre Innocentis to spille
And wickid folk reigne in prosperitee
O. good Constaunce alas so wo is me
That I must be thy tormentour or deye
On shames deth / ther is none oþꝰer weye
¶ They Wepen both yong and old in al þe place
Whan that the king this cursid lettꝰer sent
And Constaunce with a dedely pale face
The fourth day toward hir shippe she went
But natheles she takith with good entent
The wille of Crist / and knelith on the Strond
She seid lord ay welcum thy sond
¶ He that me kept from the fals blame
While that I was on the land amongꝭes yow
He can me kepe from harm ⁊ eke fro shame
In the salt see / although I se not how
As strong as euer he was he is right now
In him trust I. and in his modir der
That is to me my Sayle and eke my ster
¶ Hir litle child lay weping in hir arme
And kneling pitously to him she seid
Peas litle sonne I wil do thee none harm
With that the kerchif of hir heed she breyd
And ouꝰer his litle eyen she it leyd
And in hir arme she lullid it ful fast
And into heuen hir eyen up she cast
¶ Modir quod she and mayd bright Mary
Soth is that thurgh womans egment
Mankinde was lorn ⁊ dampned ay to dye
For which thy child was on a cros y rent
Thy blissid eye saugh alle this torment
Then is ther no comparison betwene
Thy wo and any wo man man may sustene
¶ Thou saugh thy child slayn bifore thyn eyen
And yit now lyueth my litil child parfay
Now lady bright to whom al woful crien
Thou glorie of womanhede thou feir may
Thou hauen of refute bright sterre of day
Rue on my child / that of thy gentillesse
Ruest on euery / sinfulle in their distresse
¶ O. litil child alas what is thy gilt
That neuer wroughtist synne as yit parde
Why wille thyn hard fadir haue thee spilt
O. mercy dere Constable quod she
As lat my dere child duelle here wtith thee
And if thou dar not saue him fro blame
So kisse him ones in his fadirs name
¶ Therwith she lokith bakward to the lond
And seid farwel husbond routhles
And up she risith and walkith don þe Strond
Toward the Shippe / hir folowid al þe prees
And euer she preyeth hir child to hold his pees
And takith hir leue with an hool intent
She blissith hir and into Shipp she went
¶ Y vitaild was the Shipp it is no drede
Habundantly for hir fulle long space
And othir necessaries that shulden nede
She had enough / thankid be goddis grace
For winde and weder almighti god purchace
And bring hir home / I can no bettir sey
But in the see she dryueth furth hir wey
¶ Alla the king cometh home sone aftꝰer this
Vnto his Castel of which I told
And axith wher his wif and his child is
The Constable gan about his hert cold
And plainly al the maner he him told
As ye han herd I can telle it no bettir
And shewid the king his Seal and eke his lettꝰer
¶ And seid lord as ye comaundid me
Vp peyn of deth / so haue I don certeyn
This Messagꝰer tormentid was til that he
Must beknow / and told platte ⁊ pleyn
Fro nyght to night in what place he had leyn
And thus witte and sotil enquering
Ymagined was by whom this harm gan spiring
¶ The hand was know that þe lettꝰer wrote
And alle the venym of this cursid dede
But in what wise certeinly I note
Theffect is this that Alla out of drede
His modir slough / that men may plainly rede
For that she traitour was to hir liegaunce
Thus endith olde Domegild with myschance
¶ The sorou that this Alla nyght and day
Makith for his wif and for his child also
Ther is no tunge that it telle may
But now wille I. vnto Constaunce go
That fletith in the See in peyn and wo
Fyue yere and more as likith Cristis sond
Ere that hir shippe approchith to the lond
¶ Vndir an hethen Castelle atte the laste
Of which the name in my text nouȝt I finde
Constaunce and eke hir child the See up cast
Almyghty god that saueth alle mankynde
Haue on Constaunce and on hir child sn mynde
That fallen was in hethen hand eft sone
In point to spille as I shal telle you sone
¶ Doun from the Castel cometh ther many a wiȝt
To gaure on this Shippe and on Constaunce
But shortly from the Castel on a nyght
The lordis Styward god yeue him myschance
A theef that hadde renyed oure creaunce
Came into Shippe allone and seid she shuld
His leman be / whethir she wold or nold
¶ Tho was this wrechid woman wo bigone
Hir child cried and she cride pitously
But blisful Mary hilp hir right anone
For with hir struglyng wel and mightily
The thefe fille ouer the bord alle sodeinly
And in the See he dreynte for vengeaunce
And thus hath Crist vnwemmed kept Constance
¶ O. foul lust of luxurie lo thine ende
Nat only for thou feintist mannes mynde
But verily thou wilt his body shend
The ende of thy werk or of thy lustis blynd
Is complaynyng hou many may men fynd
That not for werk sumtime but for thentent
To do this synne ben eythir slayn or shent
¶ Hough may this weyke woman haue hir strenȝth
Hir to defend ageyn this renegate
O. Golias vnmesurable of lengthe
Hough might Dauid make thee so mate
So yong and of armure so desolate
Hough durst he look upon thy dredful face
Wel may men se it nas but goddis grace
¶ Who yave Iudith corage or hardinesse
To sle him Olifern in his tente
And to delyuer out of wrechidnesse
Þe people of god / I seye for this intent
That right as god Spirit and vigour sent
To hem and saued hem out of myschance
So sent he myght and vigour to Constaunce
¶ Furth goth hir Shipp thorout the narow mouth
Of Iubaltar and Sept dryuyng ay
Sumtime West and sumtime North and South
And sumtime Est ful many a sory day
Til Cristis modir y blissid be she ay
Hath shapen thorou hir endles goodnesse
To make an ende of alle hir heuynesse
¶ Now lat us stint of Constaunce but a throw
And speke we of the Romayn Emꝑperour
That out of Surry hath by lettirs know
The slaughtir of cristen folk and dishonour
Done to his doughtir by a fals traitour
I mene the cursid wickid Soudanesse
That at the fest lete sle both more ⁊ lesse
¶ For the which this Emꝑperour hath sent anone
His Senatour with Ryalle ordinaunce
And othir lordis god woot many one
On Surriens to take high vengeaunce
They brenne slee and bring hem to myschance
Ful many a day / but shortly this is the ende
Homward to Rome they shape hem to wende
¶ This Senatour repairith with victory
To Romeward sailing fulle Roially
And mette the Shippe dryuyng as seith þe Story
In which Constaunce sitte fulle pitously
Nothing knew he what she was ne why
She was in such array / ne she nold sey
Of hir estate / though she shuld deye
¶ He bringith hir to Rome and to his wif
He yaue hir and to his yong sonne also
And with the Senatour she lad hir lif
Thus can oure lady bring out of wo
Woful Constaunce ⁊ many anoþir mo
And long time duellid in that place
In holy wurkis euer as was hir grace
¶ The Senatours wif hir Aunt was
But for alle that she knew hir neuꝰer þe mor
I wille no long lengꝰer tary in this case
But to king Alla which I spak of yore
That for his wif wepith and sighith sore
I wille returne and lete I wil Constaunce
Vndir the Senatoures gouernaunce
¶ Kyng Alla which that had his modir slayn
Vpon a day fille in such repentaunce
Þatif I shortly telle shalle and plaine
To Rome he cometh to receyue his penance
And putte him in the Popis ordinaunce
In high and lowe and Ihu Crist besought
Foryeue his wickid werkis that he wrouȝt
¶ The fame anon thorout the toun is born
How Alla king shal come in pilgrimage
By herbegours that went him beforn
For which the Senatour as was usage
Rode him ageyn and many of his linage
As wel to shew his high magnyficence
As to do any thing a reuerence
¶ Gret chere doth this noble Senatour
To king Alla and he to him also
Eythir of hem doth othir gret Honour
And so bifille that on a day or two
This Senatour is to king Alla y go
To feste and shortly if I shal nat lye
Constauncis sonne went in his cumpany
¶ Sum men wold deme at request of Constance
This Senatour had lad this child to fest
I may nat telle euery circumstaunce
Be as be may ther was he atte lest
But soth it is right at his modirs hest
Beforn Alla during the mete space
The child stode loking in the kingis face
¶ This Alla king hath of this child gret wundir
And to the Senatour he seid anon
Whos is that feir child that stondith yondir
I note quod he be god and be Seint Iohn
A modir he hath but fadir hath he non
That I of wote / but shortly in a stounde
He told Alla hough that this child was fonde
¶ But god woot quod this Senatour also
So vertuous a lyver in my life
Ne saugh I neuer as she ne herd of mo
Of worldly women maiden ne of wif

¶ Now was this child as like vnto Constaunce

¶ Parfay thought he fanton is myn hede

¶ And aftir none home with the Senatour

¶ Whan Alla saugh his wif feir he hir grett

¶ Twise she swoned in his ovne sight

Now god quod he and his halows bright

¶ Long was the sobbing and bittꝰer peine

¶ But finally whan that the sothe is wist

¶ Tho preid she hir husbond mekely

¶ Who can the pitous Ioye telle alle

¶ This king Alla whan he his time seye

Whan passid was a yere as I gesse

Now lat us prey god his soule blesse

¶ To Rome is come this holy creature

Herk eke lo which a sharp wurd for þe nones

But that I ax why the fifte man

Hough many she might haue in mariage

Vpon this nombre diffiniciou
Men may diuine and glose up ⁊ doun

Why shuld men than speke of it vilany
Lo here the wise king Salamon
I trow he had wyues mo than on
And wold god it lefe ful were to me

God woot this noble king as to my witte

With eche of hem so wel was him on lyve
Blissid be god that I haue weddid fyue
Welcum the sext whan þat euer he shal
For sith I wil not kepe me chast in alle

Sum cristenman shal wedde me anon
For than thappostle seith that I am fre
To wedde a goddis halue where it likith me
He seith that to be weddid is no synne

What rechith me þat folk sey vilany

I woot wel Abraham was an holi man

Whan saw ye euer in any maner age
Þat high god defendith mariage

Or where cōmmaundith he virginite
I woot as wel as ye it is no drede
Whan thappostil speke of maydenhede
He seid that precept therof had he none

For had god comaundid maidenhede

And certeyn if ther were no sede y sow

The dart is sette up of virginite

But this wurd is not taken of euery wight

Alle nys but counseilyng vnto virginite
And forto be a wif he yaue me leve

To wedde me if my make dye
Withouten excepciou of bigamye
Al were it good no woman to touche
He ment in his bedde or in his couche
For peril is both fire and towe to assemble
Ye know what this ensample may resemble
This is alle and sum that virginite
More profitith then wedding in freelte

I graunt it wel I haue none enuye
Though maidenhede preferre bigamy
Hem likith to be clene body and gost
Of myn estate I nyl make no bost
For wel I know a lord in his houshold
He hath not euery vesselle of gold
Sum ben of tree and don her lord ꝸseruice
God clepith folk to him in sundry wise
And euerich hath of god a ꝓpropre yifte
Sum this sum that as him likith to shifte
Virginite is a fulle grete perfeccioūn
And continence eke with deuocioūn
But crist that of ꝑperfeccioūn is welle
Badde not euery wight shuld go selle
Alle that he hath and geve to the pore
And in such wise folou him and his steppis for
He spak to hem that wold lyue parfitly
And lordingis by your leue that am not I
I wil bestow the flour of myn age
In tacchis and in frute of mariage
Telle me also to what conclusiou
Were membris y made of generaciou
And for what profit was a wight y wrouȝt

And for none othir cause sey ye no
Experience wote wel it is not so
So that the clerkis be not with me wroth
I seye this that they be made for bothe
That is to seye for office and for ese
Of engendrure / ther we nat god displese
Why shuld men ellis in her bokis sette
Þat a man shal yilde to his wyue his dette
Now wherwith shuld he make his paymēmt
If he ne usid his cely instrument
Than were they made upon a creatur
To purge vrine and for engendrure

Þat hath such harneys as I of told
To go and use hem in engendrure
Then shuld they nat take of chastite cur
Crist was a mayd and shapen as a man
And many a seint sith the world bigan
Yit lyued they euer in parfite chastite
I nyl not enuye no virginite
Lat hem be brede of your whete sede
And lat us wyues ete barly brede
And with barly brede Marc telle can
Oure lord refresshid many a man
In such estate as god hath clepid us
I wil ꝑperseuer / I am not precious
In wyuehode I wil use myn instrument

If I be daungerous god yeue me sorou

An husbond I wil haue I nyl not lette
Which shalbe both my dettour ⁊ my thrall
And haue his tribulaciou therwith alle
Vpon his flessh whils I am his wyve
I haue the power during al my lyue
Vpon his ꝓpropre body and not he
Right thus thappostle told it me
And bad oure husbondis forto loue us wel

¶ Vp stert þe pardonꝰer and that anon

What shuld I it bye on my flessh so dere

¶ Abyde quod she my tale is not begune
Nay thou shalt drynk of anothir tonne
Or that I go shal sauour wurs than ale
And whan that I haue told furth my tale
Of tribulacioūn that is in mariage
Of which I am expert in al myn age
Þis is to sey myselue haue ben the whippe

Bewar of it or thou to nygh approche
For I shal telle ensamples mo þan ten
Whoso wil nat bewar by othir men
By him shul othir men correctid be
This same wurdis writeth ꝓprotholome
Rede it in his Almagest and take it ther
Dame I wil prey if your wil it wer
Seid this pardoner as ye bigan
Telle furth your tale sparith for no man
And teche us yong men of your practike
Gladly sirs sith it may you like
But yit I prey to alle this cumpany
If that I speke aftir my fantasy
As takith it not in greef that I sey
For myn entent is but forto pley
¶ Now sir now wil I telle furth my tale
As euer mot I drink wine or ale
I shal sey soth of husbondis that I hadde
Thre of hem were good and two wer badde
The two men were good and riche and olde
Vnnethe myght they the statute holde
In which that they were bound vnto me
Ye wote wel what I mene of this parde
As help me god I laugh whan I thinke
Hou pitously one nyght I made hem swinke
But be my fey I told of it no store
They had yeue me her lond and tresor
Me nedid neuer no lenger do diligence
To wynne her loue or do hem reuerence
They loued me so wel be god aboue
That I ne told deinte of their loue
A wyse woman wille sette hir euer in one
To gete hir loue ther she hath none
But sith I had hem hooly in myn hond
And sith they had me yeue alle her lond
What shuld I take hede hem forto pleas
But it were for my profit ⁊ myn ease
I sette hem so a werk be my fey
Þat many a night they sang welawey
The bacou was not fette for hem I trow
Þat sum men han in Essex at Donmow
I gouerned hem so wel aftir my law
Þat eche of hem was ful blisful and faw
To bring me gay thing from the feire
They were ful glad whan I spak feire
For god it wote I chidde hem spitously
Now herkenth hough I bare me ꝓpropirly
Ye wise wyues that can vndirstond
Thus shul ye speke and bere hem wrong in hond
For half so boldly can ther no man
Swere and lye as can a woman
I sey not by wyues that ben wise
But if it be whan they hem mys avise
A wise wyf if she can hir good
Shal bere him in hond the cow is wode
And take wittenesse of hir ovne maide
Of hir assent but herkenth hough I said
Sir old caynard is this thine array
Why is my neighbours wyue so gay
She is honourid ouer al ther she goth
I sitte at home I haue no thrifty cloth
What dostow at my neighbours house
Is she so feire and thou so amerouse
What rown ye with oure maidens bndicite
Sir olde lechour lat thy iapis be
And if I haue a gossip or a frend
Withouten gilt thou chidist as a fend
If that I walk or pley vntil his hous
Þou comest home as drunk as a mouse
And prechist on thy benche with ille pref
Þou seist to me it is a grete mischef
To wedde a pore woman for costage
And if she be riche and of parage
Þan seystow it is a tormentry
To suffre hir pride and malencoly
And if she be feir than seystou veray knave
Þou seyst that euery holour wille hir haue
She may no while in chastite abide
That is assailid on euery side
Thou seist þat sum folk desire us for riches

Sum for hir handis and hir armes smale
Þus goth alle to the deuel be thy tale

For as a Spaynel she wil on him lepe

And seist it is an hard thing forto welde

Thou seist lorel whan thou gost to bedde

Þou seist þat we wyues wil oure vicis hyde

Þan seistow we wil oure vicis shew

¶ Lordingis right thus as ye han vndirstond

The noble usage of freris it is this
The wurthy men of hem shal first be ꝸserued
And certeinly he hath it wele diꝸserued
He hath today taught us somuch good
With preching in the pulpet ther he stood
That I may vouchesauf I sey for me
He had the first smelle of fartis thre
And so wold alle his Couent hardily
He berith him so feire and holily
¶ The lord the lady ⁊ eche man save þe frer
Seid that Iankyn spak in this maner
As welle as Emlynd or Protholome
Touching the cherle they seid subtilte
And high witte made him speke as he spak
He nys no fool ne no domyak
And Iankyn hath wonne a new goun
My tale is done we ben almost at the toun
Tho prolog of the Clerk of Oxenford
sir Clerk of Oxford oure host said
Ye ride as stille and coy as doþ a maid
Were new spousid sitting at the bord
This day ne herde I of youre tung a wurd
I trow ye studie about sum Sophym
But Salamon seith that althing hath time
For goddis sake as beth of bettir chere
It is no time forto studye here
Telle vs sum mery tale be your fey
For what man that is entrid into pley
He nedis mot vnto the pley assent
But prechith not as freris don in lent
To make vs for oure synnes wepe
Ne that your tale make vs to slepe
Telle vs sum mery tale of auentures
Your termes youre colours and your figures
Kepe hem in stoor till that ye endite
High stile as when that men to kingis write
Spekith so plaine as this time I you prey
That we may vndirstond what ye sey
This wurthy Clerc benyngly ansuerd
Host coth he I am vndir your yerd
Ye haue of me as now the gouernaunce
And therfore wille I do you obeisaunce
As ferre as reason axith hardily
I wille telle a tale which that I
Lerned at padow of a wurthy clerk
As preueth by his wurd and by his werk
He is now dede and nailed in his chest
I pray to god so geue his soule rest
Fraunceis Petrak the laureat poete
Hight this clerc whos rethorik swete
Enlumined alle ytaile of poetrye
As lynian didde of Philosophie
And lawe / or othir art particulere
But deth that wil not suffre vs duelle here
But as it were a twincling of an iye
Hem both hath slayn for alle shul we dye
But forto telle of this wurthy man
That taught me this as I began
I sey that first he with his stile enditith
Or he the body of his tale writith
A prohemy / in which distriueth he
Pemonnde / and of Saluces the cuntre
And spekith of Apenyne the hillis hye
That ben the boundis of west lumbardy
And of the mount vessulis in specialle
Where as the poo out of a welle smalle
Takith his first springing and his sours
That estward ay encrecith in his cours
To Emelward to Ferer and to venyse
The which a long thing were to diuise
And truly as to my Iugement
Me think it a thing inꝑpertinent
Saue that ye wil conceyue his matierꝰer
But this is the tale which ye may herꝰer
The Clerk of Oxenfordis tale
there is right at westside of ytaile
Doūnn at the root of vessulus þe cold
A lusty plaine habundant of vitaile
Where many a toūnn and toure ye may bihold
That foundid were in time of fadirs olde
And many anothir delitable sight
And Saluces this noble cuntre hight
¶ A . Marqueys whilom was lord of þtat lond
As were his wurthy elders him before
And obeisaunt and redy at his hond
Were alle his lieges the lasse ⁊ the more
Thus in delite he lyueth and hath don yore
Beloued and dradde thurgh fauour of fortune
Both of his lordis and of his comune
¶ Therwith he was to speke of his linage
The gentilist borne of alle lumbardie
A feir persone and yong and strong of age
Fulle of honour and eke of curtesy
Discrete enough his cuntre forto guy
Saue in sum thing he was to blame
And walter was this yong lordis name
¶ I blame him thus he considird nought
In time comyng what might him betide
But on his lust present was al his þouȝt
And forto hauke and hunt on euery side
Wel nygh alle othir cures lete he slyde
And eke he nold that was worst of alle
Wedde no wyue for ought þat might befalle
¶ Only that point his peple bare so sore
That flokmele on a day to him they went
And one of hem that wisist was of lore
Or ellis that the lordis best wold to assent
That he shuld telle him what his peple ment
Or ellis couth he shew such matier
He to the Marqueys seid as ye shulle her
¶ O noble Marqueys your humanite
Assurith us and geueth us hardinesse
As often as time is of necessite
That we to you may shew oure heuynesse
Acceptith lord of youre gentilnesse
Thae with pitous hert to you pleyn
And lat not your eris my voice disdeyn
¶ Alle haue I not to done in this matier
More than anothir here in this place
Yit for asmuch as ye my lord so dere
Haue alwey shewid fauour and grace
I dar the bettir axe of you a space
Of audience / to shewen oure request
And ye my lord to do right as you list
¶ For certis lord so wel we likith you
And alle your werk ⁊ euꝰer haue don þtat we
Ne couth not oure selue diuisen howe
We mighten lyue in more felicite
Saue one thing lord if your wille be
That forto be a weddid man you lest
Than were your peple in souereyn hert9 rest
¶ Bowith your necke vndir þat blisful yocke
Of souꝰereinte and not of ꝸseruice
Which that men clepe spousail or wedlok
And thinkith lord among your thoght9 wise
Hough that oure daies passen in sundry wise
For though we slepe or wake rome or ride
Ay fleeth the time it wil noman abide
¶ For though your grene youth floure as yit
Yit crepith age alwey as stille as stone
And deth manacith euery age and smytte
Eche estate for ther escapith none
And also certein as we knowen echone
That we shulle dye / as vncerteine we alle
Ben of that day / that deth shal on us falle
¶ Acceptith than of us oure true intent
That neuꝰer yit recusid youre heest
And we wil lord if that ye wil assent
Chese you a wyue in short time at leest
Born of the gentillest and the meest
Of alle this land / so that it aught to seme
Honour to god and you as we can deme
¶ Delyuer us than of alle this bisy drede
And take a wyue for high goddis sake
For if it so bifelle as god forbede
That thurgh your deth your linage shuld aslake
And that a straunge successour shuld take
Your heritage / wo were us on lyue
Wherfore we pray you hastily to wyue
¶ Their meke prayer and their pitous chere
Made the Marqueys hert to haue pite
I wille coth he myn owne peple dere
To that I neuer erst thought streyn me
I me reioysid euer of my libertee
That seldentime is found in mariage
Ther I was fre I mut be in seruage
¶ But neuꝰerthelesse I se your true intent
And trust on your witte and haue don ay
Wherfore of my free wille I wille assent
To wedde as sone as euer I may
But ther as ye haue profird me to day
To chese me a wyue / I wille relese
That chois / and pray you of þat ꝓprofre cese
¶ For god woot that children often ben
Vnlike her wurthy hem bifore
Bounte cometh alle of god / not of þe strene
Of which they ben engendrid and y bore
I trust in goddis bounte / and therfore
My mariage and myn estate and rest
I him betake / he may do as him lest
¶ Lat me allone in chesing of my wif
That charge on my bakke I wil endure
But I you pray and charge on your lif
That what wif I take ye shul me assure
To wurship hir while my lif may dure
In word and werk both here and ellis wherꝰer
As she an Emꝑperouris doughtir were
¶ And furthirmore this shul ye swere þat ye
Ageyn my chois shulle neuer grucche ne stryue
For sith I shalle forgo my libertee
At your request / as euer mot I thryue
Ther as myn hert is sette there wil I wyue
And but ye wil assent in such manere
I . pray you speke no more of this matier
¶ With herty wille they sworn and assent
To alle thing ther seid no wight nay
Beseching him of grace or that he went
That he wold graunt hem a certein day
Of his spousail / as sone as euer he may
For yit alwey the peple dredde
Lest that the Marqueys no wif wold wedde
¶ He grauntid hem a day such as him lest
On which he wold be weddid sicurly
And seid he did alle this at her request
And they with humble intent ful buxumly
Kneling on her knees fulle reuerently
Him thanken alle / and thus they haue an ende
Of her intent ⁊ home ayen they wende
¶ And heruppon he toke his officers
And comaundid hem for the fest puruey
And to his pryue knightis and Squyers
Such charge yaue as him list on hem ley
And they to his comaundement did obey
And eche of hem doth alle his diligence
To do vnto the Feste Reuerence
¶ Not ferre from that palaice honurable
Where as the marqueys shoop his mariage
Ther stood a Thorp of sight delitable
In which that poure folk of that village
Had her beestis and her herbigage
And of her labour toke her sustinaunce
Aftir that the erth yaue hem habundaūnce
¶ Among the poure men ther duellid a man
Which that was holden pourist of hem alle
But high god sumtime send canne
His grace into a litle oxis stalle
Ianicle men of that Thorp him calle
A doughtir had he feire enough to sight
And Grisilde this yong maiden hight
¶ But forto speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she one the feirist vndir sonne
Ful pourely fostird up was she
No licorous lust was in hir hert y ronne
Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wold vertu pleas
She knew wel labour but none idle ease
¶ But though this maiden tendir was of age
Yit in the brest of hir virginite
Ther was enclosid sad and ripe corage
And in grete reuerence and charite
Hir olde poure fadir fostird she
A . fewe shepe spynnyng in þe fold she kept
She nold nat be idle tille that she slept
¶ And whan she homward cam[]camshe wold bring
Wort or othir herbis / times ofte
The which she shredde and seeth for hir lyuyng
And made hir bedde hard ⁊ and nothing softe
And ay she kept hir fadir lif on lofte
With euery obeisaunce and diligence
That child may do to the fadirs reuꝰerence
¶ On Grisilde this poure creature
Ful often sithe the Marqueys kest his iye
As he in hunting rood by auenture
And when it fille that he might hir aspye
He nat with wanton folie of loking slye
His iye cast on hir / but in sadde wise
On hir chere he wold him ofte auise
¶ Comending in his hert hir womanhede
And hir vertu passing eny wight
Of so yong age / as wel in chere as dede
For though the peple haue no grete insight
In vertu he considird fulle right
Hir bounte / and disposid that he wold
Wedde hir only if euer he wold[]woldwedde shold
¶ The day of wedding cam but no wight can
Telle what woman that it shuld be
For which merueil wundrith many a man
And seid whan they were in priuite
Wil not oure lord yit leue his vanite
Wil he not wedde alas alas the while
Why wille he himselue and us thus begile
¶ But natheles this Marqueys hath do make
Of Gemmes sette in gold and asure
Brochis and Ringis for Grisildes sake
And of hir clothing took he mesure
Of a maiden like to hir stature
And eke of othir ꝸseruauntis alle
That vnto such a wedding shuld falle
¶ The time of vndern of the same day
Approchid that this wedding shuld be
And alle the palais putte was in array
Both halle and chambirs eche in his degre
Housis of office stuffid with plente
Ther may ye se of deinteuous vitaile
That may be founde as ferre as last ytaile
¶ This rialle Marqueys richely arrayed
Lordis and ladies in his cumpany
The which vnto the fest were y praid
Of his retenue the the Bachillery
With many a soun of sundry melody
Vnto the village of which I told
In this array the right wey haue hold
¶ Grisilde of this god woot right innocent
That for hir shapen was alle this array
To fette watir at a welle is went
And cometh home as sone as euꝰer she may
Ful wele she had herd sey thilk day
Þe Marqueys shuld wedde / ⁊ if she might
She wold faine haue sene sum of þat sight
¶ She thought I wil with othir maidens stond
That ben my felowis in oure dore and see
The Marquyses and therfore wil I fond
To do at home as sone as it may be
The labour that longith vnto me
And then I may at leysour hir bihold
If she the weye vnto the Castelle hold
And as she wold ouer the tresshold gone
The Marqueys cam ⁊ gan hir forto calle
And she sette doun hir watir potte anon
Beside the thresshold of the oxis stalle
And doun on hir knees she gan to falle
And with sadde countinaunce knelid stille
Til she had herd what was his wille
¶ This thoughtful Marqueys spak vnto þe maide
Ful soburly / and seid in this manere
Where is fa[]fayour fadir Gresild he said
And she with reuerence ⁊ humble cher
Ansuerd / lord he is alle redy here
And in she goth without lenger lette
And to the Marqueys she hir fadir fette
¶ He by the hand than took this olde man
And seid thus whan he him had aside
Ianicle I neither may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce of myn hert hide
If that thou vouchesauf what so betide
Thy doughtir wil I take or I hens wend
As for my wyue vnto my lyues ende
¶ Thou louest me I woot it wel certayn
And art my feithful liege man y bore
And alle that likith me I dar wel seyn
It likith thee / and specially therfore
Telle me that point as I haue seid bifore
If that thou wilt vnto that purpos drawe
To take me as for thy sonne in lawe
¶ This sodein case this man astonied so
That reed he wax abasshid ⁊ al quaking
He stood / vnnethe seid he wurdis moo
But only thus my lord coth he my willing
Is as ye wille / not ayens your liking
I wil nothing ye be my lord so dere
This time as ye lust gouern this matier
¶ Yit wille I . coth this marqueys softly
That in thy chambir I . and thou and she
Haue a collacioūn / and wostou why
For I wille ax if it hir wille be
To be my wyue / and rulid aftir me
And alle this shalbe done in thy pꝰersence
I nylle not speke out of thine audience
¶ And in hir chambre while they were about
Their tretice / which as ye shulle aftir here
The peple cam into the hous without
And wundrid hem in hough honest maner
And tentfully she kept hir fadir dere
But veraily wundir they myght
For neuer erst ne saw she such a sight
¶ To No wundir though she wer asstoned
To se so gret a gest come to that place
She neuer was to such gestis woned
For which she lokid with ful pale face
But shortly furth this matier forto chace
Thees arn the wurdis that the Marqueys seid
To this benyngne veray feithful maid
¶ Grisilde he seid ye shul vndirstond
It likith to your fadir and to me
That I yow wedde And eke it may so stond
As I suppoos ye wille that it so be
But this demaunde ax I first coth he
That sith it shal be do in hasty wise
Wil ye therto assent or ellis you avise
¶ I sey this be ye redy with good hert
To alle my lust ⁊ that I frely may
As me best thinkith do you laugh or smert
And neuer ye to grucch it nyght ne day
And eke whan I sey ye ye to sey nat nay
Nouther by wurd ne frounsing countinance
Swere this / and here I suere oure alliance
¶ Wondring on this wurd quaking for drede
She seid lord vndigne and vnwurthy
Am I to that honure that ye me bede
But as ye wil your selue right so wil I
And here I suere that neuere willingly
In werk ne thought I nyl you disobey
Forto be dede though me were loth to dey
¶ This is enough Grisild myn coth he
And furth he goth with a ful sobir cher
Out at the dore and aftir him cam she
And to the peple he seid in this maner
This is my wif coth he that stondith her
Honourith hir and loueth I you prey
Whoso me loueth ther is no more to sey
¶ And for that nothing of hir old gere
She shuld bring into his hous he badde
That women shuld dispoile hem right ther
Of which the ladyes were nothing gladde
To hadill hir clothis wheryn she was cladde
But natheles this maiden bright of hue
From hede to foot they clothid haue alle new
¶ Hir hede[]hedehere haue they kembid that lay vntressid
Ful redily / and with her fingirs smale
A coron on hir hede they haue ydressid
And sette it fulle of ouchis gret ⁊ smale
Of hir array what shal I make a tale
Vnneth the peple hir knew for hir fairnesse
Whan she transuewid was in such richesse
¶ This Marqueys hath hir spousid wtith a Ryng
Bought for the same cause ⁊ than hir sette
On an hors snow white ⁊ wele ambeling
And to his palais or he lenger lette
With ioyful peple that hir ladde ⁊ mette
Conveyed hir / and thus the day they spend
In reuel / til the Sonne gan descende
¶ And shortly furth this tale forto chace
I sey that this newe Marquesesse
God hath ysent fauour of his grace
That it semed not as by liklynesse
That she was born and fedde in rudenesse
As in a coot or in an Oxis stalle
But norisshed in an Emꝑperours halle
¶ To euery wight she woxen is so der
And wurshipful / that folk ther she was bor
And from hir birth knew hir fro yere to yer
Vnneth trowid they but durst haue swore
That to Ianicle of which I spak bifore
She doughtir ne were / but as by cōmiectur
Hem thought she was anothir creature
¶ For that euer uertuous was she
She was encrescid in such excellence
Of thewis sette in high bounte
And so discrete and feire of eloquence
So benyngne and digne of reuerence
And couth peple hertis so embrace
That eche hir loued that lokid in hir face
¶ Not only of Saluce in the towne
Publisshid was the bounte of hir name
But eke beside in many a Regioūnn
If one seid wele anothir seid the same
So spradde of hir bounte the fame
That men and women both yong and olde
Gone to Saluce hir forto beholde
¶ This Walter not lowly but rially
Weddid with fortunate honestee
In goddis peas lyueth wel easily
At home and outward grace enough had he
And for he saugh vndir lowe degre
Was ofte uertu hidde / the peple him helde
A prudent man / and that is sene wel selde
¶ Not only Grisild thus thurgh hir witte
Couth al the fete of wyuely gouꝰernaunce
But eke whan the case requirid it
The comune profit couth she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In alle the land that she ne couth it appeas
And bring hem alle wiseli at rest and eas
¶ Though that hir husbond present wer or none
If gentle men or othir of hir cuntre
Were wroth / she couth bring hem attone
So wise and ripe wurdis had she
And Iugement of so grete equite
That she from heuen was sent as men wend
Peple to saue / ⁊ euery wrong to amende
¶ Not long time aftir that this Grisilde
Was weddid / she a doughtir hath y bore
Al had she leuer haue born a man childe
Glad was the marqueys and his folc therfor
For though a maid child come al bifore
She may to a manchild atteine
By liklihode sith she is not bareyn
¶ Therfore as it fallith times moo
Whan this child hath soukid but a throw
This Marqueys in his hert longith so
To tempt his wyue hir sadnes to know
That he ne might from his hert throw
This meruelous desire his wyue to assay
Natheles god woot he thought hir to affray
He had assaied hir enough tofore
And found hir euꝰer good what nedid it
Hir to torment and alwey more ⁊ more
Though sum men preyse it for a subtil witt
But as for me I sey ful euel it sitte
To assay a wyue whan it is no nede
And put hir in anguissh and in drede
For which this Marqueis wrouȝt in þ9 maner
He cam a night alone ther as she lay
With stern face and with troublous cher
And seid tho / Grisild coth he that day
That I yow took out of your pour array
And putte you in estate of high noblesse
Ye haue not yit forgeten as I gesse
¶ I sey Grisild this present dignite
In which I haue put you as I trow
Makith not you forgetful forto be
Þat I you took in poure estate ful low
For eny thing ye mot your selue know
Th take hede of euery wurd þat I you sey
Ther nys no wight that herith us but we twey
¶ Ye woot wel yourselue hough ye cam here
Vnto this hous / it is not long ago
And though to me ye be leve and dere
Vnto my gentils ye be nat so
They seyn to hem it is gret shame ⁊ wo
Forto be subiect and in seruage
To you that are born of so low linage
¶ And nameli sithen your douȝtꝰer was bore
This wurdes haue they spoken doutles
But I desire as I haue done bifore
To lede my lif with hem in rest ⁊ peas
I may not in this caas be rechilos
I mut do with your doughtir as for þe best
Not as I wold but as my gentils lest
¶ And yit god woot this is wel loth to me
But natheles withouten your witing
I nyl nat do / but this I wille coth he
Þat ye to me assent as in this thing
Shew now your pacience in yorur wurching
Þat ye me behight and swore in your village
Þat day that made was oure mariage
¶ Whan she had herd alle this she was not amevid
Nouthir in wurd chere ne continaunce
For as it semed she was not agreued
She seid lord alle lith in your plesaunce
My child and I . with hertly obeisaunce
Be youris alle / and ye may saue and spille
Your ovne thing whethir that ye wille
¶ Ther may nothing so god my soule saue
Be liking to you that may displeas me
Ne I ne desire nothing forto haue
Ne drede to lese saue only ye
This is in myn hert and ay shal be
No length of tyme or deth it may deface
Neythir chaunge my corage into non oþꝰer place
¶ Gladde was the Marqueis for hir ansuering
But yit he feyned as were nat so
Alle drery was his chere and loking
Whan she shuld out of the chambir go
Sone aftir this / a furlong wey or two
He plainli hath tolde his intent
Vnto a man / which to his wyue he sent
¶ A maner Sergeaunt was this man
The which that feithful oft found he had
In thingis greet and eke such folc wel can
Do execucion of thingis badde
The lord knew wel þat he him loued ⁊ drad
And whan this Sergeaunt wist his lordis will
Into the chambir he stalkid him ful stille
¶ Madame he seid ye mut foryeue it me
Þough I do thing which I am constreined
Ye ben so wise þat wele knowen ye
Þat lordis hestis may not be feined
Þey may wel be wailed ⁊ compleined
But men mut nede vnto their wil obey
And so mut I ther is no more to sey
¶ That child I am comaundid forto take
And spak no more but out þe child he hent
Dispitousli and gan a chere make
As he wold haue slaine it or he went
Grisild mut nede suffre and al concent
And as a lambe she sittith meke ⁊ stille
And lete þis cruel Sergeaunt haue his will
¶ Suspect was the fame of this man
Suspect his fare suspect his wurd also
Suspect the time that he thus began
For hir douȝter that she loued so
She wend he wold haue slaine it riȝt tho
But naþeles she neithir wept ne strikid
Confermyng hir to that the Marqueis likid
¶ And at last to speke she beganne
And mekely vnto the Sergeant preide
So as he was a veraye gentilman
Þat she might kisse hir child or that it deide
And in hir barme this litil child she leid
With ful sadde face and gan the child to blis
And lullid it and aftur gan it kisse
¶ And thus she seid in hur benyngne voice
Far wele my child I shalle thee neuer see
But sith I haue markid the with the crois
Of thilk fadir blissid mut thou be
That for us died upon the rood tree
Thy soule litle child I him betake
For this night shaltou deye for my sake
¶ I trow that a norice in this caas
It had ben hard this routh forto se
Wel might a modir then crie alas
But natheles so sadde and stedfast was she
Þat she endurid alle hir aduersite
And to the Sergeant mekeli she said
Haue here ageyn my litil yong maid
¶ And goth now coth she and doth my lordis hest
And one thing wold I prey you of grace
Þat but my lord forbede you at leest
Bery this litil body in sum place
Þat no bestis ne birdis it to race
But he no wurd to the purpos wold sey
But took the child and went upon his wey
¶ The Sergeant come to the lord ageyn
And of Grisildis wurdis and of hir cher
He told him from point to point in short ⁊ pleyn
And him presentid with his doughtir dere
Sumwhat this lord had ruth in his maner
But natheles his purpos held he stille
As lordis don whan they wil haue her will
¶ And badde this Sergeaunt fulle priuely
He shuld wel softe this child winde ⁊ wrapp
With al the circumstaunce tendirly
And cary it yn a cofir or in a lappe
But on peine his hede of forto shapp
Þat noman shuld know of his intent
Ne whens he cam ne whider þat he went
¶ But at Boleyn to his suster dere
Þat tho of Pauy was Countesse
He shuld hir take and shew hir þis matier
Beseching hir to do hir bisinesse
Þis child to fostir in alle gladnesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hide
From euery wight for ought þat might betide
¶ This Sergeant goth and hath fulfillid þis thing
But to this Marqueis now return we
For now goth he fulle of ymaginyng
If by his wyue he might ought see
And by hir wurdis parceyue that she
Were chaungid / but he couth neuꝰer finde
But euer in one elike sadde and kinde
¶ As glad as humble as bisy in ꝸseruice
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to him in euery maner wise
Ne of hir douȝtir no wurd spak she
None accident for none aduersite
Was sene in hir / ne neuer hir douȝtꝰer name
Nempned she for ernest ne for game
¶ In this estate passid ben fourꝰer yere
Ere she with child was but as god wold
A manchild she bare be this waltere
Wel gracious and feire to beholde
And when folk to hir fadir it told
Not only he but al the cuntre mery
Was for the child / ⁊ god they þank ⁊ hery
¶ Whan it was two yere olde ⁊ fro þe brest
Departid fro the norice / on a day
Þis Marqueis cauȝt yit anothir lyst
To tempt his wyue ofter if he may
O . nedeles was to tempt hir or assay
But weddid men known no mesure
Whan they finde a pacient creature
¶ Wyue coth this Marqueis ye haue herd or þ9
My peple sicurly werieth oure mariage
And namely sith my sonne born is
Now it is wurs then euer in oure age
Þe murmur sleth myn hert ⁊ my corage
For to myn eris cometh þe voice so smert
It wil nygh destrue alle myn hert
¶ Now sey men þus when walter is gon
Þan shal the blood of Ianicle succede
And be oure lord for othir haue we non
Such wurdis seyn my peple it is no drede
Wele aught I . of such murmur take hede
For certeinli I drede such sentence
Þouȝ they not plainli speke in audience
¶ I wold lyue in peas if that I myght
Wherfore I am disposid veraly
As I his sustir ꝸserued be nyght
Right so I think to ꝸserue him priuely
Þis warne I you that ye not sodeinly
Oute of yourselue for no wo outray
Beth pacient and therof I you pray
¶ I haue coth she seid / and euer shalle
I wil desire none othir thing certeyn
But as you list not greueth me at alle
Þouȝ that my douȝtir ⁊ my sonne be sleyn
At your comaundement this is to seyn
I . haue no part of children tweyne
But first sekenes and aftir wo ⁊ peine
¶ Ye be my lord do with your ovne thing
Right as you list and aske no rede of me
For as I left at home alle my clothing
When I come first to you . right so coth she
Lefte I wille and alle my libertee
And took your clothing wherfore I you prey
Do your wille I . wille to it obeye
¶ And certis if I hadde prescience
Your wille to know ere ye your lust me told
. I . wold it done withouten neccligence
But now I woot your lust ⁊ what ye wold
Alle your plesaunce firme and stable I . hold
And wist I that my deeth wold do yow ease
Gladly wold I suffre it you to pleas
¶ Deth may make no comparison
Vnto your loue / and when this Marqueys say
Þe constaunce of his wyue / he cast his hede dou
And his iyen to . and wundrid houȝ she may
In such penaunce suffre alle this array
And furth he goth with drery countinaunce
But to his hert it was a gret penaunce
¶ This egre Sergeant in the same wise
Þat he hir doughtir caught / right so he
Or wurs / if he couth wurs diuise
Hath caught hir child that was ful of beaute
And euer in one so pacient was she
Þat she no chere made of heuynesse
But kissith hir sonne ⁊ aftꝰer gan him blesse
¶ Saue this she preid him if þat he might
Hir litle sonne he wold on erth graue
His tendre lymmes delicat to sight
From foulis and from bestis to saue
But she none ansuere of him might haue
He went his wey as he nothing rought
And into Boleyn tendirly it brought
¶ This Marqueis wundird euꝰer lengꝰer þe mor
Vpon hir pacience / and if that he
Ne hadde veraily knowen therfore
Þat parfitly hir childirn loued she
He wold haue wend of sum subtilite
And of malice and cruelle corage
Þat she had suffrid this with sad visage
¶ But he knew that next himselue certeine
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of women wold I aske feyne
If thees assaies might not suffice
What couth a . sturdy husbond diuise
To preue hir wyuehood ⁊ hir stedfastnes
And be continuyng in sturdinesse
¶ But ther ben folc of such condicion
Þat when they haue a certeine purpos take
They can not stint of their entencion
But as they were bounden to a stake
They wold not of that purpos slake
Right so this Marqueis hath fully purposid
To tempt his wyue as he furst was disposid
¶ He waitith if by wurdis or countinaunce
Þat she to him were chaungid of corage
But neuer couth he finde variaunce
She was euer one in hert ⁊ in visage
And euer the further that she was in Age
The more truer if it were possible
She was to him and more penyble
¶ For which it semeth þus þat of hem two
Þer was but one / for as walter lest
Þe same lust was hir plesaunce also
And god be thankid alle fille for the best
She shewid wel for no worldli vnrest
A wyue as for hir selue nothing shuld
Willen in effect but as hir husbond wold
¶ The Sclaundir of walter ful wide sprad
Þat of a cruelle hert wickidly
For he a poure woman weddid had
Hath murthird both his children priuely
Which murmur was among hem comonly
No wondir was / for to the popis[]spopisere
Þer cam no wurd / but that they murthird wer
¶ For such as of his peple ther before
Had loued him wele / sclaundir of his name
Made hem that they hatid him therfore
To be a murtherer it is an hatefulle fame
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruelte wold not stinte
To tempt his wyue was al his intent
¶ Whan this doughter xij . yere was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtile wise
Enfourmed of his wille sent his message
Comaunding him such Bullis to diuise
As to his cruel purpos may suffice
Houȝ that the poep[]poepfor his peples rest
Badde him wedde anothir wyue if þat him lest
¶ I . sey he badde thei shulden countirfete
The popis[]popis Bullis making mencion
Þat he had leue his first wyue to lete
As by the popis[]popis dispensacion
To stint al rancour and discencioūn
Atwene the peple and him þus spak þe Bull
Which they haue publisshid at the fulle
¶ The rude peple as no wundir is
Wend ful wel it had ben right so
But when tiding9us cam to Grisild of this
I . deme that hir hert was fulle woo
But she was elike sadde euermoo
Disposid was this humble creature
Þe aduersite of fortune forto endure
¶ Abiding euer his lust and his plesaunce
To whom she was youen hert and alle
As to hir worldly sufficiaunce
But shortly furth his storie telle I shall
Þis Marqueis writen hath in speciall
A . lettir / in which he shewith his intent
And secretly he it to Boleyn sent
To the Erle of Pauy / which that he had so
¶ Weddid his sustir / he preide spīnally
To bring him ayen his children two
In honurable estate alle openly
But one thing he him preid alle uttirly
Þat he to no wight thouȝ thei wold inquer
Shuld not telle whoos children thei wer
But sey that the maiden shuld weddid be
¶ Vnto the Marqueis of Saluce anone
And as the erle was preid so did he
For at the day y sette he on his wey is gone
Toward Saluce / and lordis manyone
In riche array this maiden forto guyde
Hir yong brothir riding right by hir side
Arraied was toward this mariage
Þis maiden fressh ful of gemmes clere
Hir brothir that vij yere was of age
Arraied eke was fresshh on his maner
And in gret noblesse and in glad cher
Toward Saluce shaping her iourney
From day to day thei riden furth her wey
¶ Among alle this aftir his wickid usage
Þis Marqueis yit his wyue to tempt more
To the uttermast pref of hir corage
Fulli to haue experience and lore
If that she were as stedfast as bifor
He on a day in open audience
Wel boistousli hath seid hir this sentence
¶ Certis Grisild I had enough plesaunce
To haue you to my wyue for your goodnes
And for your trouth ⁊ your obeisaunce
Not for your linage ne for your riches
But it is now known in verai sothnes
Þat in gret lordship if I welle aduise
Þer is gret souereinte in sundry wise
¶ I . may not do as euery ploughman may
My peple me constreineth forto take
Anothir wyue / and crien daie be daie
And eke the popis rancour forto slake
Concentith it that dar I vndirtake
And truli thus much wil I you sey
My new wyue is comyng by the wey
¶ Be strong of hert and voide anone hir place
And that ilk dowair that ye brouȝt to me
Take it ayen I graunt it of my grace
Retourneth to your fadirs hous coth he
Noman may haue alwey prosperite
With euen hert I rede you to endure
Þe strook of Fortune or of aduenture
¶ And she ayen ansuerd in pacience
My lord coth she I woot and wist alway
Hough that bituene your magnificence
And my pouerti no man can ne may
Make any comparison it is no nay
I held me neuer digne in no maner
To be your wyue ne yit your chamberer
¶ And in this hous ther as ye me lady made
Þe high god take I for my wittenesse
So wisly he my soule mut glade
I . held me neuer lady ne maistresse
But humble ꝸseruant to your wurthinesse
And euer shal while my lif may dure
Aboue euery worldly creature
¶ That ye so long of your benyngnite
Haue holden me in honure and nobley
Where I nas wurthy forto be
Þat thank I god and you whom I prey
Foryild it you / ther is no more to sey
Vnto my fadir gladly wille I wend
And with him duelle vnto my lyues ende
¶ Ther as I was fostird a child ful smalle
Til I . be deed my lif ther wille I lede
A widou clene in hert body and alle
For sith I yaue to you my maidenhede
And am your true wyue it is no drede
God shilde such a lordis wyue to take
Anothir man to husbond or to make
¶ And of your new wyue god of his grace
So graunt you welth and prosperite
For I wille gladli yilde hir my place
In which I was blisfulle wont to be
For sith it like you my lord coth she
Þat whilom were alle myn hertis rest
Þat I shalle go / I wille whan you lest
¶ But there as ye me profir such dowair
As I furst brought it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrechid clothis nothing feir
Which to me now were ful hard to finde
O . god houȝ gentil and houȝ kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
Þat day that made was oure mariage
¶ But soth is seid / algate I finde it true
For in effect it is nowe preued by me
Loue is not olde as whan it is newe
For certis lord for none aduersite
To dye in this caas it shalle not be
Þat in eny wurd or werk I shal repent
Þat I you yaue myn hert in good intent
¶ My lord ye woot that in my fadirs place
Ye did me stripe out of my pour wede
And richeli ye cladde me of your grace
To you brought I not ellis out of drede
But feith nakidnesse and maidenhede
But here ayen youre clothing I restore
And eke my wedding Ring for euermor
¶ The remenant of your Iuellis redy be
Withyn your chambre dar I . sauely seyn
Nakid out of my fadirs hous coth she
I . come / and nakid I mut turne ageyn
Alle your plesaunce wil I folon feyn
But yit I . hoop it be not your intent
Þat I smocles out of your palais went
¶ Ye couth not do so dishonest a thing
Þat ilk wombe in which oure children lay
Shuld tofore the peple in my walking
Be sene al bare wherfore I you pray
Lat me not go like a worme by the wey
Remembre you myn ovne lord so dere
I was your wyue thouȝ I vnworthy wer
¶ Wherfore in guerdon of my maidenhede
Which that I brouȝt and not ageyn bere
As vouchesaue to yeue me to my mede
But such a smocke as I was wont to wer
Þat I therwith may hille the wombe of her
Þat was your wyue / and here I take my leve
Of you myn ovne lord / lest I you greue
¶ The smocke coth he that thou hast on thy bakke
Lat it be stille and bere it furth with thee
But wel vnnethe that wurd he spacke
But went his wey for routh and pite
Beforn the folk hirselue stripid she
And in hir smocke with hede and foot al bare
Toward hir fadir hous is she fare
¶ The folk folowid weping in her wey
And fortune euer they curs as thei gon
But she from weping kept hir eyen drey
Ne in this time wurd ne spak she none
Hir fadir that this wurd herd anon
Cursid the day and time that nature
Shope him to be a lyues creature
¶ For out of dout this olde poure man
Was euere suspect of hir mariage
For euer he demed sith it began
Þat whan the lord yfillid had his corage
Him wold think it was a disparage
To his estate so lowe for to alight
And voide hir as sone as euer he might
¶ Ayenst his doughtir hastily goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comyng
And with hir olde cote as it might be
He couerid hir wel sore weping
But on hir bodi might he it not bring
For rude was the cloth ⁊ more of age
By daies fele than hir mariage
¶ Thus with hir fadir for a certeine space
Duellith this flour of wyueli pacience
Þat neuer by hir wurd ne by hir face
Beforn the folk ne in their absence
Ne shewid she that to hir was don offence
Ne of high estate in remembraunce
Ne had she as by hir countinaunce
¶ No wundir is for in grete estate
Hir goost was euer in plaine humilite
No tendir mouth ne hert dilicate
No pompe ne semblaunt of rialte
But fulle of pacience benyngnite
Discrete and prideles ⁊ euer honorable
And to hir husbond euer meke and stable
¶ Men speken of Iob and most of his humbles
As clerkis whan hem list can wele endite
Nameli of men but in sothefastnesse
Þough clerkis preise women but a lite
Þer can noman in humbles him acquite
As women can / ne ben halue so true
As women ben / but it be fallen newe
¶ From Boleyn is this erle of pauy com
Of whom the wurd sprong to more ⁊ lesse
And to the peples eris alle and sōmme
Was couth eke a newe Marqueses
He with him brouȝt in pompe ⁊ such riches
Þat neuer was sene with mannes iye
So noble array in alle west lumbardie
¶ The Marqueis that shoop ⁊ knew alle this
Ere that the erle was come shoop his message
And sent for this poure Grisildis
And she with humble chere ⁊ glad visage
Not with swollen hert in hir corage
Come at his hest and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerentli and wiseli she him grette
¶ Gresild coth he my wille is uttirly
Þat maiden that shal weddid be to me
Receiued be tomorou as rially
As it is possible in myne house to be
And eke that euery wight in his degre
Haue his estate in sitting and seruice
And also plesaunce as ye can best diuise
¶ I haue no woman sufficient certeyn
Þe chambirs to array in ordinaunce
Aftir my lust and therfore wold I feine
Þat youres were alle such gouernaunce
Ye knowe eke of olde alle my plesaunce
Þouȝ your array be badde and euel besey
Do ye your deuoir at the leest weye
¶ Not onli lord that I am gladde coth she
To do your lust but I desire also
You forto pleas and ꝸserue in my degre
Withouten feintise and shal euermoo
Ne neuer for no wele ne for no wo
Ne shal the gost withyn myn hert stint
To[]Toyou to loue best with alle my true intent
And with that wurd she gan the hous to diȝt
And tabils to sette and beddis to make
And peined hir to do alle that she might
Praiyng the chambereschambererschamberers for goddis sake
To haste hem and fast swepe and shake
And she the most ꝸseruisable of alle
Hath euery chambir arraied and the halle
¶ About vndern gan this erle to alight
Þat with him brought thees noble children twey
For which the peple ranne to se that sight
And his array so richely beseye
And then at erst among hem thei gan sey
Þat walter was no fool thouȝ þat him lest
To chaunge his wyue / for it was for þe best
For she is feirer as thei demen alle
Þan is Grisilde / ⁊ more tendir of age
And feirer frute betuene hem shuld falle
And more plesaunce / for hir linage
Hir brothir so feire was of his age
Þat him to se the peple had cauȝt plesaunce
Comending now the marqueis gouꝰernaunce
¶ O stern peple vnsadde and vntrue
Euer vndiscrete and chaunging as a phane
Deliting euer in rumour that is newe
For like the Mone euer ye wex and wane
Euer fulle of clapping dere ynough a Iane
Your dome is fals your constance euel preueth
A fulle greet fool is he that on you leueth
¶ Thus seiden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gasid up and dou
For thei were gladde right of the noueltee
To make a new lady of their toun
Nomore of this make I mencion
But to Grisild ageine wil I me dresse
And telle hir constaunce and hir bisines
¶ Ful bisy was Grisild in euery thing
Þat to the fest was aꝑperꝑpertinent
Right nouȝt abasshid was she of hir cloþing
Þough it were rude ⁊ sumdele to rent
But with glad chere she to the gate is went
With othir folk to grete the Marqueses
And aftir dooth she furth hir bisynesse
With ful glad chere the gestis she receiueth
And buxumly / euerich in his degre
Þat noman defaut ther perceyueth
But euer they wundir what she might be
And that in so poure array was forto se
And couth such honure and reuerence
And wurthily they preisen hir prudence
¶ In alle this mean while she ne stent
Þis maiden and eke hir brothir to comende
With alle hir hert and benyngne intent
So wele / that noman couth hir price amende
But at last whan thees lordis
To sitte a doun / anone he gan to calle
Grisild / as she was bisy in the halle
¶ Grisild coth he as it were in his pley
Hough likith you my wyue in hir beaute
Right wel coth she my lord / for in good fey
A feirer saugh I neuer none than is she
I prey to god so yeue you prosperite
And I hoop that he wil to you send
Plesaunce enough vnto your lyues ende
¶ But one thing I you besech and warn also
Þat ye ne pricke with no tormenting
Þis tendir maiden as ye haue don me
For she is fostird in hir norisshing
Wel tendirly in yo[]yohir yong pleying
She couth not aduersite endure
As couth a poure fostird creature
¶ And whan this Walter saugh hir pacience
Hir gladde cheer and no malice atte alle
And he so ofte hadde done hir offence
And she euer constant and sadde as a walle
Continuyng euer hir innocence ouer alle
This sturdie marqueis gan his hert dresse
To rue upon hir wyueli stedfastnes
¶ Þis is enough Grisild myn coth he
Be no more agast ne euel apaide
I haue thi feith and thi benyngnite
As wel as euer was woman assaide
In gret estate and pourli arrayde
Now know I dere wyue thi stedfastnes
And hir in armes took / ⁊ gan hir kisse
¶ And she for wundir toke therof no kepe
She herd not what thing that he seid
She ferd as she had stert out of hir slepe
Til she out of the masidnes abreid
Grisild coth he be god that for us deide
Þou art my wyue ⁊ none othir I haue
Ne neuer had as god my soul saue
¶ This is thi douȝtir which þou hast supposid
To be my wyue / ⁊ none othir feithfulli
And this shal be myn heire as I haue euꝰer disposid
Þou bare hem in thi bodi truly
At Boleyn haue I kept hem sicurly
Take hem ayen for thou might not sey
Þat thou hast lorne any of thi children tuey
¶ And folc that othir voise haue seid of me
I warn hem wele I haue don this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But forto assay thi womanhede
And not to sle my children god forbede
But forto kepe hem pryue and stille
Til I thi purpos knew and al thi wille
¶ And whan she this herd on swone dou she fallith
For pitous ioye / and aftir hir swonyng
She both hir yong children to hir callith
And in hir armes pitousli weping
Enbracith both ful tendirly keping
Wel like a modir with hir salt teris
She bathid both hir visage and hir heris
¶ O . such a pitous thing it was to se
Hir swonyng and hir pitous voice to her
Gramerci my lord god / ⁊ thank you qd she
Þat ye haue saued my children dere
Now recke I neuere to be dede riȝt her
Sith I stond in your fauoure and grace
No force of deth ne when my spirit pace
¶ O . tendre O . dere O . yong children myne
Your wofull modir wend stedfastly
Þat cruel handis outhir sum venynvermynevenyn vermyne
Had eten you / but god of his mercy
And your benyngne fadir þat tendirly
Hath don you kepe / ⁊ so that same stound
Alle sodeinly she sank doun to ground
¶ And in hir swone so sadli holdith she
Hir children two / when she gan hem enbrace
And with gret sleight and difficulte
Þe children from hir armes thei gan race
O . many a tere O . many a pitous face
Doun ranne of hem that stoden hem beside
Vnneth about hir mighten thei abide
¶ Walter hir uptoke and hir sorou slakith
She arisith up abasshid from hir traūns
And euery wight hir ioye ⁊ fest makith
Til she hath caught ayen hir countenaūnce
Walter hir doth so feithfulle plesaunce
Þat it was deintee to sene the chere
Betuene hem two now they be mete in fer
The ladies when they her time say
Han taken her lene ⁊ into chambir gone
And stripen hir out of hir rude array
And in a cloth of gold that bright shone
With a Corone of many a riche stone
Vpon hir hede / they hir to halle brought
And there she was honourid as she ought
¶ Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man ⁊ woman doth his might
Þis day in myrth and reuell to dispend
Till on the skye shone the sterris bright
For more solempne in euery mannes sight
Þis fest was / and gretter of costage
Þan was the reuelle of the mariage
¶ Ful many a yere in high prosperite
Lyuen thees two in concord and in rest
And richeli his doughtir then maried he
Vnto a lord of the wurthyest
Of alle ytaile / and then in peas ⁊ rest
His wyues fadir in his court he kepith
Til that his soule out of his bodi crepith
¶ His sonne entrith into his heritage
In rest and peas aftir his fadirs daye
And fortunate was eke in mariage
All put he not his wyue in assaye
This world is not strong it is no nay
As it hath ben in olde times yore
And herkneth what the Auctour seith þꝰerfore
¶ This storie is seid / not þat wyues shuld
Folou Grisild as in hir lyuynghumilitelyuyng humilite
For it importable is þouȝ thei wold
But that euery wight in his degre
Shuld be constant in alle aduersite
This storie which he with hiȝ stile enditith
With pacience he Grisilde acquitith
¶ For sith a woman was so pacient
Vnto a mortal man / wel more we ouȝt
Receyue in gree that god us sent
For gret skillis he preueth þat he bouȝt
