Thou welle of merci sinfulle soulis cure
In whom that god for bounte choos to won
Thou humble and high ouer euery creatur
Thou nobledist so ferfurth oure nature
That no disdeyn the maker had of kinde
His sonne in blood and flessh to cloth ⁊ winde
¶ Withyn the Cloistre of thy blisfull sides
Took maidens shappe / the etꝰernall loue ⁊ peas
That of the trinite cumpas lord and guyde is
Whom erth and see out of relece
Ay herien / and thou virgine wemmeles
And bare in thy body and duellist maiden pur
The creature aboue euery creature
¶ Assemblid is in thee Magnificence
With merci goodnesse and with such pite
That thou art the bonn of excellence
Not only helpist that preyen vnto thee
But oftentime of thy benygnite
Ful frely ere that men thyn help besech
Thou goist beforn / and art their lyues leche
¶ Now help thou meke and blisfulle feir ⁊ maide
Me flemed wrecche in this desert of galle
Thenk on the woman of Canace that said
That whelpis eten sum of the crūnmes alle
That from their tables and bordis falle
And though that I vnwurthy sonne of Eve
Be sinfulle / yit accept my bileue
¶ And for that feith is dede withouten werkis
So forto wurche yeue me witte and space
That I be putte from place that most derk is
O thou that art so feire and fulle of grace
Be myn Aduocate in so high a place
Ther as withouten ende is songen Osanna
Thou cristis modir doughtir of Anna
¶ And of thy light my soule in prison light
That troublid is by the contagion
Of my body / and also by the wight
Of erthly lust and fals affeccion
O. haven o refute o. saluacion
Of hem that ben in sorou and in distres
Now help for to my werk I wil me dresse
¶ Yit prey I you that reden that I write
Foryeue me that I do no diligence
This ilk story subtily to endite
For both haue I the wurdis ⁊ the sentence
Of hem that the Seintis reuerence
The story wrote / and folou her legend
I prey you that wille my werk amend
¶ First I wold you the name of Seint Cecily
Expound as men may in hir story se
It is to sey in englissh hauenes lilye
For pure chastnesse of virginite
Or for the wittnesse had of honestee
And gounꝰeraunce conscience and good fame
The swete sauourd lily was hir name
¶ Or Cecilie is to sey the wey to blynde
For she ensample was by good teching
Or ellis Cecilie as I writen finde
Is ioyned by a maner cōmioynyng
Heuen and lia and hier in figuring
The heuen is sette for thought of holynesse
And lia for hir lasting bisynesse
¶ Cecily may also be seid in this maner
Wantyng of blindnesse for hir gret light
Of sapience and for hir thewis cler
Or ellis lo this maidens name bright
Of hir assiaunce cometh of which be right
Men might the heuen of peple hir calle
Ensample of good and wise werkis alle
¶ And lia peple in englissh is to seye
And right as men may in this heuen se
The snne and mone with sterris euery wey
Right so gostly in this maiden fre
Is sene the feith of high magnificence
And also of good helth and Sapience
And sondry werkis bright of excellence
¶ And right as thees Philosophres write
That heuen is swift rounde and brennyng
Right so was she feire Cecily the whyte
Fulle swift and bisy in good wurkyng
And rounde and hole in good ꝑperseuering
And brennyng euer in charite so light
Now haue I declarid you what she hight
¶ Here begynneth the tale of the Secunde Nonne
This maiden bright Cecilie as hir lif seith
Was come of Romains of noble kinde
And fostird up euer in the feith
Of crist and bare his gospel in hir mynde
She neuer cessid as I writen finde
Of hir prayers / and god to loue ⁊ drede
Beseching him to kepe hir maidenhede
¶ And whan this maide shulde to a man
Be weddid / that was full yong of age
Which that clepid was Valerian
And day was comen of hir mariage
She fulle deuout and humble in hir corage
Vndir hir robe of gold that sate fulle feire
Next hir flessh she werid the heire
¶ And whils thei maden melodie
To god allone thus in hert sang she
O. lord my soule and eke my body guye
Vnwemmed / lest that it confoundid be
And for his loue that died upon a tre
Euery secunde or third day she fast
And bidding hir orisons ful fast
¶ The nyght come and to bedde must she gon
With hir husbond / as ofte is the maner
And priuely seid she to him anon
O swete and welbeloued spouse dere
Ther is a counseil and ye wold it here
Which right fayn I wold to you seye
So ye ensure it not to bewreye
¶ Valarine gan fast vnto hir swere
That for no case ne thing þat might be
He shuld for nothing bewreyen hir
And than at erst thus to him seid she
I haue an Aungel which that loueth me
That with gret loue whethir I wake or slepe
Is redy euer my body forto kepe
¶ And if that he may fele out of drede
That ye wil me gouꝰerne nothing amys
He wil you loue and kepe til ye be dede
For your clene living and your goodnesse
And bring you streight vnto heuen blesse
He wille you loue for youre clennesse
And shew you of his ioye and of his blesse
¶ Valerian correctid as god wold
Ansuerd ayen / if I shalle trust thee
Lat me that Aungel se and him behold
And if that it a veray Aungel be
Than wille I do as thou hast praid me
And if thou loue anothir man for soth
Right with this swerd than I wil sle you both
¶ Cecilie ansuerd anone in this wise
If that ye list that Aungel shul ye se
So that ye trow on crist and you baptise
Goth furth to Via Apia coth she
That from this tovne stant but Myles thre
And to pore folkis that ther duelle
Sey hem thus right as I shal you telle
¶ Telle hem that I Cecile you to hem sent
To shew you the good Vrban the olde
For secret nedis and for good intent
And when that ye Seint Vrban haue behold
Telle him the wurdis which that I you told
And when that he hath y purgid you of syn
Then shul ye se the Aungel or ye twynne
¶ Valerian is to the place y gone
As him was taught by his lernyng
He found this holi man Vrban anone
Among the Seintis buriels loutyng
And he anone withouten tariyng
Didde his message / and whan he it told
Vrban for ioy gan his handis uphold
¶ The teris from his eyen lete he falle
Almighti lord o. Ihu crist coth he
Sower of counseil chast and hierd of us all
The frute of that ilk sede of chastite
That thou hast sowe in Cecile / take to thee
Lo like a bisy bee withouten gile
Thee ꝸserueth ay thine own thrall Cecile
¶ For thilk spouse that god toke but now
Ful like a fiers leon she ascendith here
As meke as any lambe vnto you
And with that wurd anone ther gan apper
An old man cladde in clothis clere
And had a book of lettirs of gold in hond
And gan beforn Valerian to stond
¶ Valerian as dede fille doun for drede
When he him saugh / and him vp hent tho
And on his book right thus he gan to rede
O. lord one feith one god withouten moo
O. cristendom / and fadir of alle also
Abouen alle and ouꝰeralle euery where
Thees wurdis alle with gold writen wer
¶ Whan this was radde then seid this old man
Beleuest thou this thing sey ye or nay
For soth I do with alle the hert I can
I leve alle this thing I dar wele say
Vndir the heuen no wight think it may
Thoo vanysshid the old man he nyst wher
And pope Vrban him cristned right ther
¶ Valerian goth home and seint Cecily
Withyn his chambre he hath found stand
This Aungel that hadde of Roos and of lilie
Crownes two / which he bare in hond
And first to Cecilie as I vnderstond
He yaue that one / and aftir gan he take
That othir to Valerian hir make
¶ With clene body and vnwemmed thouȝt
Kepe ay wele thees crownes coth he
From Paradise to you haue I hem brouȝt
Ne neuermore shul they roten be
Ne lese their sauour trustith me
Ne neuer wight shal sene hem with his iye
But if that he be chast from vilany
¶ And thou Valerian for thou so sone
Assentid to alle good counseile also
Seye what thou list and thou shalt haue thy bone
I haue a brothir coth Valerian thoo
That in alle this world I loue noman so
I pray you that my brothir may haue grace
To know the trouth as I do in this place
¶ Theaungel asuerd god likith your request
And bothe with the palme of martirdome
Ye shullen come to the blisfulle fest
And with that wurd then Tiburce come
And when he the sauour vndirnome
Which that the Rosis and the lilies cast
Withyn his hert he gan to wundir fast
¶ And seid in this time I wundir of the yer
Whenes this swete sauour cometh so
Of Rosis and lilyes that I smelle here
For though I had hem in myn handis two
The sauour myght in me no depper go
The swete smelle that in myn hert I finde
Hath chaungid me alle into anothir kynde
¶ Valerian seid two crownes haue we
Snow white and Rose rede that shynen cler
Which that thyn iyen haue no might to se
And as thou smellist hem thurgh my preyer
So shall thou se hem leve brothir dere
If it so be thou withouten slouth
Beleue aright and know veray trouth
¶ Tiburce ansuerd seitow this to me
In sothnesse or in dreme herken ye this
In dremes coth Valerian haue we be
Vnto this time brothir myn y wis
But now at erst oure trouth duelling is
Hough wostou coth Tiburce and what wise
Coth Valerian / that I shalle the diuise
¶ Theangel of god hath me the trouth taught
Which that thou shalt if thou wilt reney
Thine ydols / and be clene and ellis nought
And of the miracles of these crownes twey
Seint Ambrose in his preface lust to sey
Solempnely this doctour dere
Comendith it and seith in this maner
¶ The palme of martirdom forto receyue
Seint Cecile fulfillid of goddis yifte
The world and eke his chambre gan she weyve
Witnesse Tiburce and Cecilies shrift
The which god of his bounte wold shifte
Crownes two of floures wele smelling
And made thangel hem the crownes to bring
¶ The maid hath brought thees men to blis aboue
The world hath wist what it is wurth certeyn
Deuocion of chastite shewing in loue
Thoo shewid him Cecile open and pleyn
That alle ydols nys but thing in veyne
For they be dombe and therto they ben deef
And chargid him his ydols forto lefe
¶ Who that this trowith not a beest is he is
Coth Tiburce tho if I shalle not lye
She gan then kis his brest when she herd this
And was fulle glad he couth trouth espye
This day I take thee for myn allye
Seid tho this blisfull maiden dere
And aftir that she seid as ye may her
¶ Lo right so as the loue of Crist coth she
Made me thy brothirs wyue / right in þat wise
Anone for myn allie here take I thee
Syn thou wilt thyn ydols despice
And to ihu crist to do seruice
And make thee clene so that thou maist bihold
Thaungels face of which thy brothir told
¶ Tiburce ansuerd and seid brothir dere
First telle me whithir I shal and to what man
To whom coth he / come furth wtith right good cher
I wille thee lede vnto the pope Vrban
To Vrban brothir myn Valerian
Coth tho Tiburce / wiltou me thidir lede
Me thinkith that it were a wundir dede
¶ Remembrist thou not Vrban coth he tho
That so ofte is dampned to be dede
And wonneth in halkis to and fro
And dar not ones putte furth his hede
Men shuld him brenne in fire that is so rede
If it so were that men might him aspie
And us also that bere him cumpany
¶ And wille ye seken thilk diuinite
That is y hidde in heuen priuely
Algate y brent in this world shal we be
To whom Cecile ansuerd boldily
Men might drede wele and skilfully
This lif to lese myn ovne dere brothir
If this were parfit lyuyng and none othir
¶ But ther is bettir lif in othir place
That neuer shal be lost ne drede not thee
Which goddis sonne tolde us thurgh his grace
Right as a man hath Sapiencis thre
Memorie engine and intellectualite
And so euer in obeying of diuinite
Thre persones right wele ther may be
Tho gan she him bisily to preche
With many pointis of oure lordis passion
Hough crist come into erthe and his peines teche
To do mankinde plaine remission
To bye mannes soule hough he was bovn
Alle thees thingis she to Tiburce told
That was y bounde in synne and caris colde
And aftir this Tiburce in good intent
Which thankid god with hert glad ⁊ light
To Pope Vrban with Valerian he went
Parfit in his lyuyng as goddis knight
And aftir this Tiburce gat such a sight
With thaungel of god iin euery bone
That he god axid / it was spedde ful sone
¶ It were fulle hard by ordre forto seyn
Hough many wundirs god for him wrouȝt
But at last to short telle short and pleyn
The sergeant of the toun of Rome hem souȝt
And hem beforn Almeche the ꝓprouost brouȝt
Which hem opposid and knew their intent
And to the ymage of Iubiter he hem sent
¶ And seid whoso wille not do sacrifice
Swappe of his hede this is my sentence her
Anone thees martirs that I you diuise
One Maximus that was an Officer
Of the Prefectis and of the Croniculer
Hem hent ⁊ when he the Seintis furth ladde
Himseluen wept for pite that he hadde
¶ Whan Maximus had herd the Sentence lore
He gat hem of the tormentours leve
And lad hem in his ward withouten more
And with her preching or that it were eve
They gan fro the tormentours to reve
And fro Maximus and his folk echone
The fals feith / and to trow on god allone
¶ Cecile come whan that it was nyght
With ꝓprophetis that hem cristned alle in fere
And aftir whan the day was woxen light
Cecile seid with a sobre chere
Now cristis owne knightis leve ⁊ dere
Castith all awey werkis of derknesse
And armeth you in armure of lightnesse
¶ Ye haue forsoth done a gret bataile
Your lif is done your feith haue ye conꝸserued
Goth to the crowne of lif that may not faile
To the rightfull Iuge which ye haue serued
Tofore him ye ben feithfulli preꝸserued
And whan this thing was seid as I diuise
Men ladde hem furth to do their sacrifice
¶ But when they were vnto the place brouȝt
Forto telle shortly the conclusion
They wold accept the sacrifice right nought
But on her knees they seten hem adoun
With meke hert and sadde deuocion
And losten both her hedis in that place
Their soulis went vnto the king of grace
¶ This Maximus that saugh this thing betide
With pitous tale told it anone right
That he saugh her soulis to heuen glide
With Aungels fulle of clerenesse and of light
And with his wurdis conuertid many a wight
For which Almacheus did him so bete
With whippis of lede til he his lif gan lete
¶ Cecile him toke and buryed him anone
By Tiburce and Valerian wel softly
Withyn hir buriyng place vndir the stone
And aftir this Almacheus hastily
Badde his Ministirs fecchen al openly
Cecile / so she might in his presence
Do sacrifice and Iubiter incense
¶ But they conuꝰertid thurgh hir wise lore
Wepten sore and yaue good credence
Vnto hir wurdis ⁊ criden euermore
Crist goddis son withouten difference
Is veray god / this is alle oure sentence
That hath so good a ꝸseruaunt him to ꝸserue
Thus with one voice we trow though we sterve
¶ Almacheus that herd of this thing
Bad fecche Cecile þat he might hir se
And aldir first lo this was his axing
What manꝰer woman artow coth he
I am a gentil woman born coth she
I ax thee coth he though it the greve
Of thy religion and of thy beleue
¶ Ye haue begnne your question folily
Coth she that wold answers conclude
And one demande ye ax lewdely
Almache ansuerd vnto that similitude
From whens cometh thine ansuering so rude
From whens coth she when that she was freined
Of conscience and of good feith vnfeined
¶ Almacheus seid takistow none hede
Of thine ansuer and she seid him þis
Your might god coth she litle is to drede
For euery mortalle mannes power ne is
But like a bladdir ful of winde y wis
For with a nedil point when it is blow
May alle the bost of it be leid fulle low
¶ Full wrongfully began thou coth she
And yit in wrong is thy ꝑperseueraunce
Wostou not hough oure mighty pirincꝭes fre
Ben thus comaundid ⁊ maken ordinaunce
That euꝰery cristen wight shal haue penance
But if he his cristendom withsey
And gone all quite if he wil it reney
¶ Your Pirincis arn to god of heuen lothe
For ye that known wele oure Innocence
Ye make us gilty and is not sothe
Coth tho Cecile and of a wood sentence
For as moch as we done reuerence
To crist and for we bere a cristen name
Ye putte on us a crime and eke a blame
¶ But we that known wele that name so
For vertuous we may it not geyn sey
Almache ansuerd chese one of these two
Do sacrifice or cristendom renay
That thou may now escape by that wey
At the which the holy blisfulle maide
Gan forto laugh / and to the Iuge seid
¶ O. thou Iuge confucion in nycete
Wilditou that I reneyed Innocence
To make me a wicked wight coth she
Lo he dissimilith here in audience
He starith and wodith in his aduꝰertence
To whom Almacheus seid o celi wrecch
Thou wost not hough ferre my power may strecch
¶ Hath not oure mighti prince to me yeuen
His mighty power and his auctorite
To make folk both forto dye and lyuen
Why spekistou so proudly vnto me
I speke it not but stedfastly coth she
Not proudly / for I sey as for my side
I hate it dedely that soule vice of pride
¶ And if thou drede not a soth to here
Then wil I shew al openly be right
That though hast made a gret lesing her
Thou seist thi pirincis haue yeue the might
Both forto sle ⁊ quyken ayen a wight
Thou that ne mayst lyue but as a Reve
And hast therto nowthir power ne leve
¶ Thou mayst se thy pirinces haue the makid
Ministir of deth / for if thou speke of moo
Thou liest for thy power is full nakid
Do wey thy boldnesse seid Almaceus tho
And sacrifice to oure goddis thou do
I ne recke no wrong that thou me ꝓprofre
For I can suffre it as wel as a Philosophre
¶ But thilk wrongꝭes may I not endure
That thou spekist of oure goddis hye
Cecile ansuerd and seid o nyce creatur
Thou seid no wurd sith thou spak to me
That I ne knew therwith thi nycete
And that thou were in euery maner wise
A lewde Officer and a veyne Iustise
¶ Ther lackith nothing to thine uttir iyen
That thou ne art blinde for thing we sen alle
Ther is a stone that men may wel aspien
That ilk stone a god thou wil it calle
I rede thou lete thine hand upon it falle
And tast it wel a stone thou shal it finde
Sith thou seest not with thine iyen blinde
¶ It is a shame that the peple shalle
So scorn thee and laugh at thi foli
For comonli women woot it wel ouꝰeralle
That mighti god is in his heuens his
And thees ymagis wele thou maist aspie
To thee ne hem may they not profite
For in effect they be not wurth a myte
¶ This and such othir wurdis seid she
And he wax wroth and bad they shuld hir lede
Home til hir hous and in hir hous coth he
Brenne hir in a fire with flammes rede
And as he badde right so was don in dede
And in a Batth they gan hir fast sette
And night and day gret fire thei vndir bette
¶ The long night and eke the day also
For alle the fire and eke the Bathis hete
She sate al cold and felt of it no wo
Nought made hir one drope to swete
But in that Bath hir lif must she lete
For this Almache with fulle wickid intent
To sle hir in the Bath his sond he sent
¶ Thre strokis in the necke he smote hir tho
Þe tormentour bode for no maner chaunce
He might not smyte alle the necke in two
And ther was that time made in ordinaunce
That nen shuld do no man such penaunce
The fourth stroke to smyte soft ne sore
This tormentour durst smyte no more
¶ But halue dede with hir necke y corven ther
He lete hir lye and in his wey he went
The cristen folk which that about hir were
With shetis home full feir they hir hent
Thre daies lyued she in this torment
And neuer cessid hem the feith to teche
That she had fostird to hem did she pꝰerche
¶ And hem she yaue hir moebles and hir thing
And to the Pope Vrban betoke hem tho
And she seid thus I ax of heuen king
To haue respite thre daies and no mo
To recomaund me or that I go
And to these soulis that I might Wurch
Here of myn hous parfitly to haue a church
¶ Thus Seint Vrban with Diacons piriuely
The body fette and buried it be night
Amongis othir Seintis fulle honestly
And hir hous the church of Seint Cecile hight
Seint Vrban it halowd as he wele myght
In which vnto this day in noble wise
Men done to crist and to his Seinte ꝸseruice
The prolog of the Chanons yoman
whan endid was the lif of seint Cecile
Or we hadde riden fully fyue myle
At Boughton vndir Ble us gan a take
A man that clothid was in clothis blake
And vndir that he hadde a white surplice
His hakenay that was alle of pomely grice
Was so biswette that wondir was to se
It semed he had prikid mo then myles thre
The hors also that his yoman rood upon
So swette that vnneth he might gone
Aboute the pewtrell stood the fome fulle hye
He was of fome al fleckid as a pye
A male twyfold on his cropur lay
It semed that he caried but litle array
Al light for somer rood this wurthy man
And in myn hert wundir I began
What that he was tille that I vndirstood
Hough that his cloke was sowid to his hood
For which when I had long auised me
I demed him sum chanon forto be
His hatte hyng at his backe doun by a lace
For he had ryden more then trotte or pace
He had prikid like as he wer wood
A cloot leef he had vndir his hood
For swete and forto kepe his hede from hete
But it was ioye forto sene him swete
His forhede droppid as a stillatory
That wer fulle of planteyn or of ꝑperitory
And whan that he come he began to cry
God saue coth he this feire cumpany
Fast haue I prikid qd he for your sake
Because that I wold you ouertake
To riden in this mery cumpany
His yoman was also fulle of curtesy
And sirs now in the morou tide
Out of your hostry I saw you ride
And I warned here my lord ⁊ my souꝰereyn
Which that to ride with you is full feyn
For his disport / he loueth daliaunce
Frend for thy warnyng god yeue þe good chance
Seid oure host certis it wold wele seme
Thy lord right wise and so I may wel deme
He is fulle iocunde also dar I wele lay
Can he ought telle a mery tale or twey
With which he may glade alle this cupany
Who sir my lord ya ya withouten lye
He can of mirth and eke of Iolite
Alle as he ritte also trustith me
And ye him knew as wele as do I
Ye wold wundir hough wel and thriftily
He couth wurch and that in sundry wise
He has taken on him many a diners apprice
Which were ful herd for many that is here
To bring about they ben therof to lere
As homely as he ritte amongꝭes you
If ye him knew it wold be for your prow
Ye nold not forgon his acqueintaunce
For mochel good I dar leyn in balaunce
Alle that I haue in my possession
He is a man of high discrecion
I warn you wele he is a passing man
Wele coth oure host I pray the tel me than
Is he a Clerk or none telle what he is
Nay he is gretter then a clerk y wis
Seid the yoman / and in wurdis few
Host of his craft sumwhat I wil you shew
I sey my lord can mochel sotilte
But alle his craft ye may not wit at me
And sumwhat help I yit to his wurchyng
That alle this ground that we ben on riding
Til that we come to Cauntirbury toun
He couth it alle clene turn up so doun
And pave it alle with siluer and with gold
And whan this yoman thus hadde told
Vnto oure host he seid ey bndicite
This thing is wundir merueilous to me
Sith that thi lord is of so high prudence
Because of which men schuld him reuꝰerence
That of his wurschip he reckith so lite
For his ouꝰersloppe is not wurth a myte
As in effect to him so mut I go
It is alle baudy and al torn also
Why is thy lord so sluttissh I the prey
And is of power bettir clothis to beye
If that his dede accorde with thy speche
Telle me that and that I thee biseche
Why coth the yeman wherto ax ye me
God help me so for he schal neuer the
But I nyl not avow that I sey
And therfore kepe it secret I you prey
He is to wise in feith as I beleue
What that is ouerdone it wil not preve
And right as clerkis seyn it is a vice
Wherfore in that I hold him lewde ⁊ nyce
For whan a man hath ouer gret a witte
Ful ofte it happith him mys vse it
So doth my lord and that me greueth sore
God it amende I can seye now no more
Therof no force yoman coth oure host
Syn of the cūnnyng of thi lord thou wost
Telle hou he doth I prey thee hertily
Sithen that he is so crafti and so sly
Where duelle ye if it to telle be
In the subarbis of a good toun coth he
Lurking in hiernes and in lanes blinde
Where thise Robbers and theues be kinde
Holden her pryuee ferfulle residence
As they that dar not schewen her presence
So faren we if I shalle sey the soth
Yit coth oure host lat me talke to thee
Why artow so discolourd of thy face
Petir coth he I prey god yeue it sory grace
I am so usid in the fire to blow
That it hath chaungid my colour as I trow
I am not wont in mirrours to prye
But swink and lerne to multiplye
We blundirn euer and poure in the fire
And for alle that we failen of oure desire
For euer we lacken oure conclusion
To much folk we ben but Illusion
And borowen gold sumtime a pound or two
Or ten or twelue and many sūnmes moo
And make hem wene at the lest wey
That of a pound we couth make twey
Yit is it fals / and ay we haue good hoop
It forto do and aftir that we groop
But that science is so ferre us beforn
We mown not alle though we had it sworn
It ouꝰertake / it slidith awey so fast
It wille us make beggers atte last
¶ Whils this yoman was thus in this talking
This chanon drue him nere and herd all þing
Which that yoman spak / for suspecion
Of mennes speche euer hadde this Chanon
For Caton seith he that gilty is
Demeth althing be spoken of him amys
Be cause that he gan so nygh hem drawe
Was to his yoman / and herd alle his sawe
And thus he seid vnto his yoman tho
Hold now thy pees and speke wurdis no mo
For if thou do thou shalt it dere abye
Thou sclaundirst me here in this cumpany
And also discouerist that thou shuldist hide
Than coth oure host telle on what so betide
Of alle this threting recche the not a myte
In feith coth he no more I do but lite
¶ And whan this Chanon saugh it wold not be
But this yoman wold telle his priuite
He fledde awey for verray shame
A ha coth the yoman here shall rise a game
Alle that euer I can anone I wille telle
Sith he is gone secche hym the fend of helle
For neuer heraftir wille I with him mete
For peny ne pound that I you bihete
He that first me brought vnto that game
Or that he deye sorou haue as he ⁊ shame
But yit for alle my smert and alle my gref
And for alle my labour sorou ⁊ mischef
I couth it neuer lete in no maner wise
Now wold god my witte might it suffice
To telle alle that longith to that art
But nenꝰertheles yit wille I telle a part
Syn my lord is gone I wille not spare
Such thing as I knowe I wille declare
The tale of the Chanons yoman
with this chanon duellid haue I this vij yer
And of his science am I neuer the nere
Ther I was wont to be right fressch ⁊ gay
Both of clothing and of othir good array
Now it may I were an hose upon myn hede
And where my colour was both fressh ⁊ rede
Now is it wanne and of leden hue
Who that it usith most sore may him rue
And of my swink yit blerid is myn iye
Lo such auauntage it is to multiplye
That sliding science hath made me so bare
That I haue no good where so I fare
And yit am I enditid also therby
Of gold that I haue borowid therfor truly
That whils I lyue quite it may I neuer
Lat euery man bewar by me for euer
What manꝰer man that castith him therto
If he continue I hold his thrift y do
For so help me god therby shal he not wynne
But empty his purs and make his wittꝭes thyn
And when he thurgh his madnes and foly
Hath lost his owne good thurgh Iopardy
Than he excitith othir men therto
To lese her good as himselue hath do
For vnto shrewis it is Ioye it is and ease
To haue her felows in peine and disease
Thus was I ones lerned of a clerc
Of that no charge I speke now of oure werk
When we ben there as we shulle exercise
Oure eluyssh craft / we semen wundir wise
Oure termes ben so clergiall and so queynt
I blow the fire till that myn hert feint
What shuld I telle euery proporcion
Of thingis which that we wurch upon
As on fyue or six vncis may wel be
Of siluer or of sum othir quantite
And bisy me to telle you the names
Of Opiment brent bones Iren squames
That into poudre grounden be ful smalle
And in an erthen potte putte is alle
And salt is put yn and also papere
Beforn thees poudirs that I speke of her
And wele y couꝰered with a lampe of glas
And of mochel othir thing what that ther was
And of the potte and the glas engluting
That of the ayre might pas nothing
And of the easy fire and smart also
Which that was made of the care ⁊ wo
That we had / in oure matiers sublimyng
And amalganyng and Calcenyng
Of quiksiluer clepid mercury crude
For alle oure sleightis we can not conclude
Oure orpiment and sublimed mercury
Oure grounde litarge eke and oure purphiry
Of eche of thees of vncis a certeine
Nought helpith us / oure labour in veine
Ne nouthir oure spiritis ascencion
Ne oure matiers that lien alle fix adon
Mown in oure wurching nothing us auaile
For lost is alle oure labour and trauaile
And alle the cost that we theron ley
Alle is gone in twenti deuell wey
Ther is also many anothir thing
That to oure craft is apꝑperteynyng
Though I by ordre here reken ne can
As bool armoniak vertgrece Boras
And sundrie vessels made of erth and glas
Oure vrinallis and oure discenciories
Viols Arcetis and Sublimatories
Concurbitis and Alembikis eke
And such othir dere ynough a leke
Nought nedith it now to rehercen hem all
Watirs Rubising and bullis galle
Arsnk Sal armoniak and Bremstone
And herbis couth I telle many one
As Egrimoyn Valerian and lunary
And othir such if that me lust to tary
Oure lampes brennyng both night and day
To bring about oure craft if that we may
Oure fourneux also of Calcinacion
And eke of watirs albificacion
Vnsleckid lyme chalk / and gleire of an eye
Poudirs diuerse asshis dunge pisse and cleye
Serid pokettis Sal petir and vitriole
And diuerse fires made of wode and cole
Sal tartary Sal Alcali and Sal pꝰerparate
And combust matirs and coagulate
Cley made with hors dunge mannes her ⁊ oyle
Of tartre alym glas brent wurt and argoyle
And of Siluer Citrinacion
Oure simenting and fermentacion
Oure Iggettis trestis and many mo
I wil you telle as me was taught also
The foure spiritis and the bodies seuen
By ordre oft as I herd my lord hem neven
¶ The first spirit quiksiluer clepid is
The secunde orpiment / the third y wis
Sal armoniak and the fourth bremstone
The bodies seuen lo hem here anone
Sol gold is / and luna siluer we clepe
Mars Iren mercurius quiksiluer we threpe
Saturnus lede and Iubiter is tynne
And venus Copir be my fadir kynne
This cursid craft whoso wille exercise
He shal no good haue that may him suffice
For alle the good he spendith ther aboute
He lese shalle / therof haue I no doute
Whoso that lust to outen his foly
Lat him come furth and lerne to multiply
And euery man that hath ought in his cofre
Lat him appere and wexe a philosophre
Ascaunce that craft is so light forto lere
Nay nay god wote albe he monke or frere
Preste Chanon or eny othir wight
Though he sitte at his book both day and nyght
In lernyng of this eluyssh nyce lore
Alle is in vayne / and parde mochel more
Is to lerne a lewde man this subtilite
Fy speke not therof it wille not be
Alle couth he lecture or couth he none
As in effect he shalle fynde it allone
For both two by my saluacion
Concluden as in multiplicacion
Eliche wele / whan they haue alle do
This is to sey thei failen both two
Yit for I make to mochel rehersaile
Of watirs corisyues and of limaile
And of bodies mollificacion
And also of theire induracion
Oyles ablucion and metalle fusible
To tellen alle it wold passen a bible
Þat owher is / wherfore as for the best
Of alle these names now wil I me rest
For as I trow I haue told you enough
To reise the fend loke he neuer so rough
A nay lat be / the philosophirs stone
Elixer clepid we sithen euerichone
For had we him then were we sure enough
But to god of heuen I make avough
For alle oure craft when we haue alle y do
And alle oure sleight he wil not come us two
He hath us made to spend mochel good
For sorou therof we wex almost wode
But that good hoop crepith in oure hert
Supposing euer though we sore smert
To be releued by him aftirward
Supposing and hoop ben scharp and hard
I warne you wele it is to seche euer
That future temps hath made men disseuꝰer
In trust therof fram alle that euꝰer thei had
Yit of that art thei couth not wex sadde
For vnto hem it is a bittir suete
So semeth it / for had thei but a schete
Which that thei might wrapp hem In a night
And a bake to walk in on day light
Thei wolden it selle to spend on this craft
Thei can not stint tille nothing is laft
And euꝰermore wher that euer thei gone
Men may hem know by smelle of Bremston
For alle thei stinken as a gote
Her sauour is so Rammyssh and so hote
That though a man a myle from hem be
The sauour wil infect him trust me
Lo thus by smelling and threde bare array
If that hem lust these folk thei know may
And if a man wille ax hem priuely
Why they ben clothid so vnthriftily
Right anone they wille rovne in his ere
And sey if that they aspied were
Men wold hem sle because of her science
Lo thus these folk betrayen Innocence
¶ Passe ouer this I go my tale vnto
Ere then the potte be in the fire y do
Of metallis / with a certeine quantite
My lord hem tempreth ⁊ noman but he
Now he is gone I dar seye boldily
For as men seyn he can do craftily
Algate I woot wel he hath such a name
And yit fulle ofte he renneth in the blame
And wote ye hough full oft it happenth so
The potte to brekith and farwel alle is ago
These metalles ben of so gret violence
Oure wallis may not make hem resistence
But if thei were wrought of lyme and stone
They percen so and thurgh the walle thei gon
And sum of hem sinken into the grounde
Thus haue we lost be times many a pounde
And sum ar scaterd alle the flore aboute
And lepen into the roof withouten doute
Þough the fend not in our sight him shew
I trow that he with us be that shrew
In helle wher that he is lord and sire
Ne is ther no more wo ne angre ne Ire
When that oure potte is broke as I haue seid
Euery man sitte and halt him euel apaid
Sum seid it was long on the fire making
Sum seid it was long on the hard blowing
Than was I ferd for it was myn office
Straw coth the third for ye ben lewde ⁊ nyce
It was not tempred as it ought to be
Nay coth the fourth stint and herken to me
Because oure fire was not y made of beche
Þat is the cause and none othir to seche
I can not telle wheron it is a long
But wel I woot gret strife is vs among
What coth my lord ther is no more to done
Of these perils I wille bewar eft sone
I am right sicur that the potte was crasid
Be as be may be ye nothing amasid
As usage is lat swepe the flore as swithe
Plukke up your hertis and be both glad ⁊ blith
The mullok on an hepe y swept it was
And on the flore casten was a Canvas
And alle this mullok in a Syve y throwe
And siftid and y pluckid many a throw
Parde coth one sumwhat of oure metalle
Yit is ther here / although we haue not alle
And though this thing mishapt hath as now
Anothir time it may be wele y nowe
Vs must putte oure good in aduenture
A merchaunt parde may not alwey endur
Trust me wele / in his prosperite
Sumtime his good is drowned in the see
And sumtime cometh it sauf to the lond
Peas coth my lord the next time I wil fond
To bring oure craft alle in anothir plite
And but I do sirs lat me bere the wite
Ther was defaut in sum thingis wel I wote
And anothir seid the fire was to hote
But be it hote or cold I dar sey this
Þat we concluden eueremore amys
We faile of that which that we wold haue
And in oure madnesse euꝰermore we rave
And when we ben togidirs euerichon
Euery man semeth as wise as Salomon
But al thing which that semeth as the gold
It is not gold as I haue herd it told
Ne euery appul that is feire at iye
Is not good what so men clapp or cry
Right so lo farith it amongis us
He that semeth wisist by Ihus
Is most fole when it cometh to pref
And he that semeth truest is most thef
That shul ye know or that I fro you wend
By than I of my tale haue made an ende
Ther is a chanon a man of Religion
Among us wold infect alle a toun
Þough it were as gret as euer was Niniue
Rome Alexander Troy or othit thre
His sleightis and his infant falsnesse
Ther couth noman it write as I gesse
Though that he might lyue a thousend yer
In alle this world of falnesse nowher his per
For in his termes he wil him so bewinde
And to speke his wurdis in so sleighty a kinde
When that he comon shal with eny man wight
That he nyl make him dote anone right
But if it be the fend as himseluen is
Fulle many a man hath he begilid or this
And yit wille if he may lyue a while
And yit men ryden and gone ful many a myle
Him forto seche and forto haue his acqueyntance
And not knowing his fals gounꝰeraunce
And if you list to yeue me audience
I wille you telle here in your presence
But ye wurshipfulle Chanons religious
Ne demeth not that I sclaundre your hous
Al though my tale of a Chanon be
Of euery ordre sum shrewis ther ben ꝑperde
And god forbede that alle a cumpany
Shuld rue a singuler mannes foly
To sclaundir you is nothing myn intent
But to correct that that is miswent
This tale was not al only told for you
But also for othir mo ye woot wel how
That among cristis appostles twelue
Ther was no traitour but Iudas himselue
Than why shuld alle the remenant haue blame
That giltles were / by you sey I the same
Saue only this if ye wil herken to me
If eny Iudas in your couent be
Remene him betime I wille you rede
If shame and lose may cause eny drede
And beth nothing displeasid I you prey
But in this case herkenth what I sey
¶ In london was a prest that was an annueler
That theryn hadde duellid many a yere
Which was so plesaunt and so ꝸseruisable
Vnto the good wyue when he was at table
That sche wold suffre him nothing to pay
For bord or cloth went he neuer so gay
And spending siluer had he right enough
But therof no force I wille procede as now
And telle furth my tale of the Chanon
That brought this prest to his confucion
¶ This fals Chanōmn come upon a day
Vnto the prestis chambre where he lay
Beseching him to lene him a certeyn
Of gold / and he wold quite to him ayen
Leneth me a marc but dayes thre
And at my day I wille it quite thee
Anothir day hang me by the hals
And if so be that thou fynd me fals
This prest him toke a marc and that as swithe
And this Chanon him thankid many a sithe
And toke his leue and went furth his wey
And atte the third day brought his money
And to this prest he toke this money ageyn
Therof this prest was fulle glad and feyn
Certis coth he nothing it noyeth me
To lene a man a noble two or thre
Or what thing were in my possession
When that he is true of his condicion
That in no wise breke he wil his day
To such a man I can neuꝰermore sey nay
What coth this Chanon shuld I be vntrue
Nay that were thing y fallen of the new
Trouth is a thing that I wille euer kepe
Vnto the day in which that I shalle crepe
Into my graue / and ellis god forbede
Beleueth this as secur as the Crede
God I thankit and in good time be it seid
Þat ther was neuꝰer man yit euel paid
For gold ne siluer that he to me lent
Ne neuer falshood to him in hert I ment
And sir coth he now of my priuite
Sithen ye so goodlich haue ben to me
And kidde to me so gret a gentilnesse
Sumwhat to quite with your kindenesse
I wille you shew if that ye lust to lere
And teche vnto you anone right here
Hough I can wurche in philosophie
Taketh good hede ye shul se wel at iye
That I wille do a maistrie or that I go
Ye coth the prest ye sir and wil ye so
Mary therof I pray you hertily
At your comaundement sir truly
Coth the Chanon and ellis god forbede
Lo hough this theef couth his ꝸseruice bede
Ful soth it is that such profird ꝸseruice
Stinkith as wittnesse these olde wise
And that wel sone I wille it verifie
In this Chanon is root of alle trechery
That euꝰermore delite hath and gladnesse
Such fendly thoughtis in his hert to impꝰersse
Hough cristis peple he may to mischeve bring
God kepe us from his fals dissimiling
What wist this prest with whom that he delt
Ne of his harme comyng nothing he felt
O celi prest o cely Innocent
With couetise anone thou shalt be blent
O thou graceles ful blind is thy conceit
For nothing artow ware of that gret deceit
Which that this fox y shapen hath to the
His wily wrenchis thou maist not fle
Wherfore to go to the conclusion
That referrith vnto thy confusion
Vnhappy man anone I wille me hye
To telle thine vnwitte and thy foly
And eke the falsnesse of that othir wrecch
As ferfurth as my connyng way strecch
¶ This Chanon was my lord as ye wold wene
Sir host in feith and by the heuen quene
It was anothir chanon and nothing he
Can an hundrith fold more subtilte
He hath betraied folk many a store time
Alle his falsnes it dullith me to Rime
Euer whan I speke of his falshede
For shame of him my chekis wexen rede
Algatis they begynnen forto glow
For rednes haue I none right wel ye know
In my visage for fumes diuerse
Of metallis whiche ye haue herd me reherse
Consumed and wastid haue my redenesse
Now takith hede of this Chanons cursidnesse
Sir coth he to the prest lat your man gone
Into the toūnn for quiksiluer that we had anon
And lat him bring vncis two or thre
And when he cometh fast shull ye se
A wundir thing which ye saugh neuer or this
Sir coth the prest it shalle done y wis
He badde his man fecch him his thing
And he al redy was at his bidding
And went him furth ⁊ come anon ageyn
With this quiksiluer shortly forto seyn
And toke this vncis thre to the Chanon
And he it leid feire and wele a doun
And bad the ꝸseruaunt colis forto bring
That he anon mighte go to his worchinge
The colis right anon were in fette
And this chanon anone toke out a croslette
Of his bosum / and schewid it to the prest
This Instrument coth he which thou seest
Take it in thyn hond and putte thiselue theryn
Of quiksiluer an vnce and here begynne
In the name of crist to wex a Philosophre
Ther ben welle few which that I wold ꝓprofre
To shewen hem somuch of my science
For ye shulle sene here by experience
That this quyksiluer I wille mortifie
Right in your sight anone withouten lye
And make it as good siluer and as fine
As ther is any in your purs or myne
Or ellis where / and make it molliable
Than may ye hold me fals and vnhable
Neuꝰer among good folk est to appere
I haue here a poudre that cost me ful der
Shal make alle good / for it is cause of alle
My connyng which that I you shew shalle
Voidith your man and lat him be therout
And shittith the dore whils that we ben about
Oure priuite / that noman us aspye
Whils that we wurch in this philosophie
¶ Right as he bad as was it fulfilid in dede
This ilke ꝸseruaunt anone right oute yede
And his maistir shette the dore anone
And vnto their labour spedely thei gone
This prest at this cursid chanons bidding
Vpon the fire anone he sette this thing
And blue the fire and bisied him ful fast
And this chanon into the Crosselet cast
A poudre / I note wherof that it was
Y made / other of chalk or of glasse
Or of sumwhat ellis dere enough a flye
To blind with the prest and bad him hye
The colis forto couchen alle aboue
Vpon the crosselet in token that I thee loue
Coth this Chanon thine handis two
Shal wurche alle this thing that shal be do
Gramercy sir coth the prest and was ful glad
And couchid the colis as the Chanon badde
And whils he bisy was this fendly wrecch
This fals Chanon the foule fend him fecch
Out of his bosum toke a bechyn cole
In which ful sutile was made an hole
And theryn was putte of siluer lymayle
An vnce and stoppid was withouten faile
This hole with wex to kepe the lymaile In
And vndirstondith that this fals gynne
Was not made there but it was made before
And of othir thingis I shalle telle you more
Here aftir / which that he with him brought
Or he come there / to begile him he thought
And so he didde or they went a twynne
Til he had betrayed him he couth not blynne
It dullith me when that I of him speke
On his falshode fayne wold I be wreke
If that I wist hough / but he is here and ther
He is so variaunt he abidith nowhere
But takith hede now sirs for goddis loue
He toke his cole of which I spak aboue
And in his hand he bare it priuely
The whilis the prest he couchid bisily
Þe colis / as I told you or this
This Chanon seid frend ye don amys
This is noht couchid as it ought to be
But sone I shal amenden it coth he
Now lat me medle therwith a litle while
For of you haue I pite be seint Gile
Ye ben right hoot I se wel hough ye suete
Haue here a clothe and wipe awey the wete
And while this prest him wiped hase
This Chanon toke his cole I shrew his face
And leid it upon abouen the mydward
On the Crosselet and blue welle aftirward
Til that the colis gan fast brenne
Now geve us a drink quod the Chanon then
As swithe alle shal be wele I vndirtake
Sitte a doun and lat us mirthe make
And when the Chanons bechen cole
Was brent / alle the limayle out of the hole
Into the Crosselet anone it fille adoun
And so it nedis must by alle reson
He demed alle the colis eliche good
For of the sleight he nothing vndirstood
And whan this albemestre saugh his time
Arise up quod he sir prest and stond byme
And for I wote wel Ingot haue ye none
Go walkith furth and bringith a chalk stone
For I wille make it of the same shappe
As is an Ingot if I may haue happe
And bringith with you a bolle or a panne
Fulle of watir / and ye shulle se than
Hough that oure bisynesse shal happe ⁊ preve
And yit for ye shull haue no mysbeleue
Ne wrong conceit of me in your absence
I nyl not ben oute of youre presence
But go with you and come with you ageyn
The chambre dore shortly forto seyn
They shette ther and went furth her wey
And furth with hem they caried the key
And come ageyn without eny delay
What shuld we tarye alle the long day
He took chalke and schope it in the wise
Of an ingot as I shalle you diuise
I sey he toke out of his owne sleue
A teyn of Siluer euel mot he cheue
Which that was but of an vnce of weight
And takith now hede of this cursid sleight
He shope this Ingot in length and brede
Of the teyn withouten eny drede
So slily that the prest it not aspyed
And in his sleue ageyn he gan it hide
And from the fire he toke up matier
And into the yngot putte it with mery cher
And into the vesselle with watir he it cast
When that him list and bad the prest as fast
Loke what ther is / putte in thine hand and grope
Thou shalt finde ther siluer as I hope
What deuel of helle shuld it ellis be
Shauyng of siluer siluer is parde
He putte in his hond and toke up a teyn
Of siluer fine / and gladde in euery veyn
Was this prest when he saugh it was so
Goddis blissing and his modirs also
And alle halowen haue ye sir Chanon
Seid the prest / and I their malison
But and ye vouchesauf to teche me
This noble craft and this subtilite
I wil be your man in alle that euꝰer I may
Coth the Chanon yit wil I make assay
The secunde time that ye may take hede
And be expert of this in your nede
Anothir day use it in myne absence
This discipline and this crafty science
Lat take anothir vnce quod he tho
Of quyksiluer withouten wurdis moo
And do therwith as ye haue don or this
With that othir that now siluer is
This prest him bisyeth in alle that euer he can
To do alle that this Chanon this cursid man
Comaundith him and fast he blue the fire
Forto come to theffecte of his desire
And this Chanon right in the mene while
Al redy was the prest forto begile
And for a contynaunce in his hand he bare
An houstik take hede and be wel ware
In the ende of which an vnce and no more
Of siluer limaile and putte alle before
Was in his cole and stoppid with wex wele
Forto kepe in his limayle eueridele
¶ And whils this prest was in his bisinesse
Þis Chanon with his sticke gan him dresse
To him anone / and his poudre cast In
As he did ere / the deuel out of his skynne
Him turne / I pray to god for his falshede
For he was euer fals in wurde and dede
And with his sticke aboue the crosselett
Þat was ordeined with that fals iette
He stirrid the colis / tille relent began
Þe wex ageyn the fire as euery man
But it be a fole wote / as it must nede
And alle that in the hole was out yede
And into the Crosselet hastly it felle
The prest supposid nothing but welle
But bisied him fast and was wundre fayn
Supposing nought but trouth soth to seyn
He was so gladde I can not expresse
In no maner his mirth and his gladnesse
And the chanon he proferd efte sone
Body and good / ya ya coth the Chanon sone
Þough pore I be crafty thou shalt me finde
I warne thee yit is ther more behinde
Is ther eny copre here in seid he
Ye sir coth the prest I trow ther be
Ellis go by sūnm and that as swithe
Now sir go furth thy wey and hythe
He went his wey and with the copre he cam
And this Chanon in his hand it nam
And of that copre he weyed but an vnce
Alle to simple is my tunge to pronounce
His moustre his witte and his doublenesse
Of this Chanon the rote of Cursidnesse
He semed frendly to hym that knew him nouȝt
But he was fendly both in werk and thought
It hevyeth me to telle of his falsenesse
And neuerthelesse yit wille I it expresse
To that intent that men may beware by
And for none othir cause truly
¶ He putte this vnce of copre into the Crosselet
And in the fire anone he it sette
And kest in a poudre ⁊ made the prest to blow
And in his wurching forto stoupe lowe
As he did erst and alle nas but a Iape
Right as him list the prest he made his ape
And aftirward into the yngot he it cast
And in the panne he putte it at the last
Of watir / and in he putte his ovne hand
And in his sleue as heyehye beforn hand
Herd me telle / he hadde a siluer teyne
And he slily toke it out this cursid heyne
Vnwiting this prest of his fals craft
And in the pannes botum he hath it laft
And in the watir he rumblid to and fro
And wundir priuely he toke it up also
Þe copre teyne / not knowing to the pꝰerste
He hidde it and hent him by the breste
And to him spak and seid thus in his game
Stouping adoūnn be god ye ben to blame
Helpe me now as I did you while ere
Put in your hand and look what is ther
¶ This prest took up this siluer teyn anon
Þan seid this chanon now lat us gone
With these teynes which we han wrouȝt
To sum goldsmyth to wit if they be ought
For be my feith I nold for myn hood
But if they were siluer both fine and good
And that as sone proued it shal be
Vnto the goldsmyth with these teynes thre
They wenten and putt hem in assay
To fire and hamour might noman sey nay
But they were as they ought to be
This sottid prest who was gladder then he
Was neuer birde gladder ayens the day
Ne nightingale in the ceson of May
Was neuer none that list bettir to sing
Ne lady lustyer in hir Carollyng
And forto speke in loue and womanhede
No knight in armis to don an hardy dede
To stond in grace of his souereyn lady der
Than had this preste his craft for to lere
And to the chanon thus he spak and seid
For the loue of god that for vs deide
And as I may deserue it vnto you
What shal this receite cost tellith now
By oure lady coth the chanon it is dere
For I warn you saue I and a frere
In England ther can noman it make
No force coth he now sir for goddis sake
What shalle I paie tellith I you prey
I wis coth he it is fulle dere I you sey
Sir at one wurd if ye list it haue
ee shull paie .xl.li. so god me saue
And ne were the frendship that ye did or this
To me / ye shuld paie more y wisse
¶ This prest the sūnme of xl li. anone
Of nobles fette / and toke theym echone
To this prest for this ilke receite
And alle his wurching was fraude ⁊ deceite
Sir prest he seid I kepe to haue no loos
Of my craft for I wold it were kept cloos
And as ye loue kepith this secree
For and men knew alle my subtilite
Be god men wold haue so greet enuye
To me / because of my philosophye
I shuld be dede ther were none othir wey
God it forbede coth the preste I seye
Yit hadde I leuer spend alle the good
Which that I haue / and ellis were I wood
Þan that ye shuld falle in such mischefe
For your good wille sir haue ye good pref
Coth the chanon than / farwel and gramercy
He went his wey and neuer aftꝰer the prest him sye
¶ Aftir that day when the prest shuld
Maken assay at such time as he wold
Of this receit farwell it wold not be
Lo thus beiapid and begilid was he
Thus makith he his introduccion
To bring folke vnto their destruccion
Considrith sirs hough that in euꝰery estate
Bitwix men and gold ther is debate
So ferfurth that vnnethe ther is none
Þis multiplying blindith so many one
That in good feith I trow that it be
The cause grettist of this scarcyte
¶ These philosophirs speken so mystily
In this craft that men can not come therby
For eny witte that men han now a dayes
They may wel chittre and Iangle as Iayes
And in her termes sette lust and peyne
But to their purpos shul they neuer atteyn
A man may lightly lerne if he haue ought
To multiply / and bring his good to nought
Lo such a lucre is in this lusty game
A mannes myrth it wil turne all to grame
And to empty also gret and heuy pursis
And make folk to purchace many cursis
Of hem that hath therto their good y lent
O fy for shame thei that haue ones be brent
Alas can they not fle the fires hete
Ye that it vsen I rede you it to lete
Lest ye lesen alle / for bettir than neuꝰer is late
Neuer to thryue were to long a date
Though ye prolle euer ye shul it neuer fynde
Ye ben as bold as bayard the blynde
Þat blundirth furth / and perils cast he none
He is as bold to rynne ayens a stone
As forto go besidis in the weye
So farn ye that multiplye I seye
If that your iyen can not sene aright
Look that your iyen mynde lacke not his sight
For though ye loke neuer so brood and stare
Ye shulle not wynne a myte in that chaffare
But wasten alle that ye may Rappe ⁊ rynne
Withdrawe the fire lest it to faste brynne
Medle no more with that art I mene
For if ye don your profit is gon full clene
And right anone I wille you tellen here
What the philosophirs seyn in this matier
¶ Lo thus seith arnold of the newe toun
As his Rosarie makith mencion
He seith right thus withouten eny lye
Ther may noman mercurie mortifie
But it be with his brothirs knowleching
Hough that he which that seid this thing
Of Philosophirs fadir was hermes
Seith hough that the dragon doutles
Ne deyeth not but if he be slayne
With his brothir and that is forto seyn
By the dragon mercury and none othir
He vndirstode that bremston was his broþꝰer
That out of Sol and luna were drawe
And therfore seid he take hede to my sawe
Lat noman bisy him this art forto seche
But he that the intencion and speche
Of philosophirs vndirstond wele can
And if he do he is but lewde man
For this science and connyng coth he
Is of the secrete of Secretis fulle secre
¶ Also ther was a disciple of Plato
That his maistir that time seid vnto
As his boke Somer wille bere wittnesse
And this was his demaunde in sothfastnesse
Telle me the name of thy pryues stone
And plato ansuerd vnto hym anone
Take the stone that men titans name
Which is coth he magnacia the same
Yea seid this disciple Sir is it thus
This is ignotum perignocius
What is magnacia sir I you prey
It is a watir that is made I you sey
Of elementis foure coth Plato
Telle me the roche good sir coth he tho
Of that watir if it be your wille
Nay nay coth Plato for certeyn þtat I nylle
The Philosophirs were sworn echone
That they shuld neuer discouer it to none
Ne write it in no book it no manere
For vnto crist it is so leue and dere
That he ne wille that it discouerid be
But where it likith vnto his deite
Man to inspire and eke to defende
Whan that him likith lo this is the ende
¶ Than conclude I thus syn that god of heuen
Ne wille not that the Philosophirs neven
Hough that a man shal come vnto this stone
I rede as for the best to lat it gone
For whoso makith god his aduersary
As forto wurch eny thing in contrary
Vnto his wille / certis neuer shal he thryue
Though he multiplie terme of his lyue
And ther a point for endid is my tale
God send euery true man boot of his bale
Here begynneth the ꝓprolog of þe doctorur of phisik
when that this yoman his tale endid hadde
Of this fals chanou that was so badde
Oure host gan to sey truly and certeyn
This prest was begilid sothely forto seyne
He wenyng forto be a Philosophir
Till he right no gold left in his cofir
And truly this prest had a lithir iape
This cursid chanou put in his hood an Ape
But alle this wille I passe ouer as nowe
Sir Doctour of Phisic I prey you
Telle us a tale of sum honest matier
It shalbe done if that ye wille it here
Seid this Doctour / and his tale began anon
Now good men coth he herkneth euerichon
The tale of the doctour of phisik
xher was as tellith us Titus Lyuous
A knight that clepid was Virginous
Fulfillid of honour and wurthinesse
And strong of frendis and of gret riches
A doughtir he hadde only by his wyf
And never had he moo in alle his lif
Feir was this maide in excellent beaute
Aboue euery wight that men may se
For Nature hath with souꝰereyn diligence
Fourmed hir in so greet excellence
As though she wold sey I nature
Thus can I fourme and peinte a creature
Whan that me list / who can me countirfete
Nought Pigmalion though he alwey forge ⁊ bete
Or graue or peynt for I dar wele seyne
Appollo zipherus shuld wurch inveyne
To graue or peynt or forge or bete
If they presumed me to countirfete
For he that is the fourmour principalle
Hath made me his vicar generalle
To fourme and peint eche erthly creatur
Right as me list for alle is in my cure
Vndir the Mone that may wane and wax
And for my work nothing wille I ax
My lord and I ben fully accorde
I made hir to the wurship of my lord
So do I alle myn othir creatures
Of what colour they ben or what figures

l.seg: Thus semeth that nature wold seye

div.l: Thus semeth that nature wold seye
This mayde was of age xij. yere and twey
In which that nature hath such delyte
For right as she can peinte as lily white
And ruddy as Rose / right with such peyntur
She peyntid hath this noble creatur
Or she was born / vpon hir lymmes fre
Were alle so bright as such colours shuld be
And Phebus dyed hadde hir tresses grete
Like to the stremes of his bourned hete
And if that excellent were hir beaute
A thousand fold more vertuous was she
In hir ne lackith no condicion
Þat is to preyse as by discrecion
As wele in body and gost chast was she
For which she flourid in virginite
With alle humilite and abstinence
With alle attemꝑperance and pacience
With mesure eke of bering of array
Discrete she was in answere alway
As wise as Pallas darre I seyn
Hir facond eke fulle womanly ⁊ pleyn
No countirfetid termes hadde she
To seme wise / but aftir hir degre
She spak / and alle hir wurdis mor ⁊ lesse
Sownyng in vertu and in gentilesse
Shamefast she was in maidens shamefastnesse
Constant in hert and euer in bisynesse
To dryue hir oute of alle slogardy
Bachus hadde of hir mouth no maistry
For wille and thought don Venus increse
As men in fire wille casten oyle or grece
And of hir owen vertu vnconstreyned
She hath fulle ofte time hir seke feyned
For that she wold fle the cumpany
Where like was to treten of foly
As at festis reuels and at daunces
That ben occasions of daliaunces
Such thingis maken childre forto be
To sone ripe and bold as men may se
Which is ꝑperilous and hath ben yore
For al to sone may she lern lore
Of boldnesse / when she is a wife
And ye Maistressis in your olde lif
That lordis doughtirs haue in gouꝰernaunce
Ne takith of my wurd no displesaunce
Thingis that ben sette in gouꝰernyngis
Of lordis doughtirs for two thyngis
Outhir for ye haue kept your honestee
Or ellis ye haue fallen in freelte
And knowen wel y nough the olde daunce
And can forsake fully myshaunce
For euꝰeremore / therfore for Cristis sake
Kepeth welle tho that ye vndirtake
A theef of veneson that hath forlaft
His licorousnesse and alle his theues craft
Can kepe a Forest best of any man
Now kepeth hem wele for and ye will ye can
Look wele that to no vice ye assent
Lest ye be blamed for your ill entent
For whoso doth / a traytour is certeyn
And taketh hede of this that I shal seyn
Of alle treson the souereyn pestilence
Is whan a wight betrayeth Innocence
Ye fadirs and ye modirs eke also
Though ye haue children be it one or two
Your is the charge of alle her suffraunce
Whils they ben vndir your gouernaunce
Beth war that by ensample of your lyvyng
Outhir by neccligence in chastising
That they ne perissh / for I dar wel sey
If that they don ye shull fulle sore abeye
Vndir a Shepherd fulle soft and neccligent
The wulf hath many a shepe and leon to rent
Sufficith one ensample now as here
For I mut turne ayen to my matier
¶ This mayde of which I telle my tale expꝰersse
She kept hir selue she nedid no maistresse
For in hir lyuyng maidens myght rede
As in a book euery good wurd and dede
That longith to a mayde so vertuous
She was so prudent and so bountevo9us
For the which out sprang on euery side
Both of hir beaute and of hir bountee wide
That thurgh the lond they preysid hir echon
That loued vertu saue enuye allone
That sory is of euery mannes wele
And gladde is of euery mannes sorou ⁊ vnhele
The doctour maketh this discripcion
¶ This mayde went on a day in to the toun
Toward the temple with hir modir dere
As is of yong maydens the manere
Now was ther a Iustice in the tovn
That gouꝰernour was of that Regioun
And so bifell this Iuge his eyen cast
Vpon this maide avisyng hir fulle fast
As she cam forby ther the Iuge stode
Anone his hert chaungith and his mode
So was he caught with beaute of this maide
And to himselue fulle priuely he said
This maid shal be myn for any man
Anone the fend into his hert ranne
And taught hym sodenly by what sleight
This maide to his purpos wynne he myght
For certis by no force ne by no mede
Him thought he was not hable forto spede
For she was strong of frendis and eke she
Conformed was in such souꝰereyn beaute
That welle he wist he might hir neuꝰer wyn
As forto make hir with hir body synne
For which with greet deliberacion
He sent aftir a clerk into the tovne
The which he knew for subtile ⁊ for bolde
This Iuge vnto the clerk his tale hath tolde
In secret wise ⁊ made him to assure
He shuld telle it to no creature
And if he dide he shuld lese his hede
Whan assentid was this cursid rede
Gladde was the Iuge ⁊ made good cher
And yave him yiftis precious and der
Whan shapen was alle this conspiracy
From poynt to point hough that his lechery
Perfourmed shuld be fulle subtily
As ye shulle here aftirward openly
Home goth this clerk that hight Claudius
This fals Iuge that hight Apius
So was his name it was no fable
But known for an historiall thing notable
The sentence of it soth is out of dout
This fals Iuge goth now fast about
To hast his delite alle that he may
And it bifille sone aftꝰer on a day
This fals Iuge as tellith us the storye
As he was woned in his Consistorye
And yaue his domes upon sundry wise case
This fals clerc come furth a well good pase
And seid lord if that it be youre wille
As doth me right vpon this pitous bille
In which I pleyn upon Virgineus
And who that will sey it is nat thus
I wille preue it and finde good wittenesse
That soth is that my bille wille expresse
The Iuge answerd to this in his absence
I may not yeve diffinitiue sentence
Lat don him calle and I wille gladly her
Thou shalt haue right and no wrong her
¶ Virgineus cam to witte the Iugis wille
And right anone was redde this cursid bille
The sentence of it was as ye shulle her
To you my lord sir Apius so dere
Shewith your poure ꝸseruant Claudius
Hough that a knyght callid Virgineus
Ayens the lawe ayens alle equite
Holdith expresse ayens the wille of me
My ꝸseruaunt which that is my thralle by right
Which fro myn hous was stole in a nyght
While she was fulle yong I wille it preve
By wittenesse lord so that ye not greve
She is not his doughtir what so he sey
Wherfore my lord Iuge to you I ge prey
Yilde me my thralle if that it be your wille
Lo this was alle the sentence of the bille
¶ Virgineus gan upon the clerc biholde
But hastily eer he his tale hadde told
He wold haue defendid him as shuld a knight
And by wittenes of many a true wight
That alle was fals that seid his Aduersary
This cursid Iuge wold no lenger tary
Ne here a wurd more of Virgineus
But yaue his Iugement and seid thus
I deme anone this clerc his ꝸseruant haue
Thou shalt no lenger in thyn house hir saue
Go bring hir furth and putte hir in oure warde
This clerc shal haue his thralle thus I awarde
And when this wurthy knight Virgineus
Thurgh thassent of the Iuge Apius
Must by force his dere doughtir yeven
Vnto the Iuge / in lechery forto lyuen
He goth him home and sett him in his halle
And lete anone his dere doughtir calle
And with a face dede as aysshen colde
Vpon hir humble face he gan beholde
With fadirs pite stiking thurgh his hert
All wold he not from his purpos conuert
Doughtir coth he Virginea by thy name
Ther ben two weyes outhir deth or shame
Þat thou mut suffre alas that I was bore
For neuer thou offendidist wherfore
To deye with a swerd or with a knyfe
O dere doughtir ender of my lif
Which I haue fostird up with such plesaunce
Þat thou ne were out of my remembraunce
O doughtir which that art my last wo
And in lif my last ioye also
O gemme of chastite in pacience
Take thou thy deth for this is my sentence
For loue and not for hate thou must be dede
My pitous hond mut smyte of thine hede
Alas that euer Apius thee say
Thus hath he falsly Iugid thee to day
And told hir alle the caas as ye before
Haue herd / it nedith not to telle it more
¶ O mercy dere fadir coth this maide
And with that wurd she both hir armes leyd
About his necke as she was wont to do
The teris brest out of hir eyen two
And seid good fadir shalle I dye
Is ther no grace is ther no remedy
No certis dere doughtir myn coth he
Þan yeue me leve fadir myn coth she
My deth to compleyn in litle space
For parde Iessa yaue his doughtir grace
Forto compleyn or he hir slough alas
And god it woot nothing was hir trespas
But that she ranne hir fadir first to se
To welcum him with gret solempnite
And with that wurd she fille in swone anon
And aftir whan hir swonyng was gone
She roos up and to hir fadir seid
Blissid be god that I shalle deye a maide
Yeue me my deth or that I haue a shame
Doth with your child your wille in goddis name
And with that wurd she prayeth fulle ofte
That with his swerd he sauld smyte softe
And with that wurd on swone doun she felle
Hir hede of smote and by the toppe it hent
And to the Iuge he yaue it to present
As he sate in his dome in Consistorye
Whan the Iuge it saugh as seith the story
He badde take him and hang him as fast
But yit anone alle the peple In thrast
To saue the knight for ruthe and for pite
For know was the soule Iniquite
The peple anone had suspect in this thing
By maner of this clerkis chalenging
Þat it was by thassent of Apius
They wist wele that he was lecherous
For which vnto this Apius they gone
And cast him in prison right anone
Where as he slough himselue and Claudius
Þat ꝸseruaunt was vnto this Apius
Was demed forto hang upon a tre
But Virgineus of his greet pite
Prayd for him that he was exilid
And ellis certis he hadde ben begilid
The remenant were hangid more ⁊ lesse
Þat concenting were to his cursidnesse
¶ Here may men se hough syn hath his merit
Beware for no man woot hough god wille smyte
In what degre ne in what maner wise
The worme of conscience wille arise
Of wickid lif / though it so preuey be
Þat noman woot of it but god and he
Whethir he be lewde man or lered
He note hough sone that he may be ferid
Therfore I rede you this counseil take
Forsakith synne or synne you forsake
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature

(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
