¶ Thus hath this widow hir litle son tauȝt
Oure blissid lady cristis modir dere
To wurship ay . and he forgat it nought
For celi child wil alwey sone lere
But euꝰer when I remembre on this matier
Seint Nicholas stant euer in my presence
For he so yong to crist didde reuerence
¶ This litle child his litle book lernyng
As he sate in the Scole at his Prymerꝰer
He alma redemptoris herd syng
As childirn lerned their Antiphoner
And as he durst he drue him nere ⁊ nerꝰer
And herkned ay the wurdis and the note
Til he the first uerse coude al be rote
¶ Nought wist he what this latine was to sey
For he so yong was and tendre of age
But on a day his felow gan he prey
To expoūnn him this song in his langage
Or telle him why this song was in usage
Thus preid he him to construe and declar
Ful oftentime upon his knees bare
¶ His felow which that elder was then he
Ansuerd him thus / this song I haue herd sey
Was made of oure blissid lady fre
Hir to salue and also forto prey
To be oure help and oure socour when we deye
I can no more . expoūnn in this matier
I lern song I can but smalle gramer
¶ And is this song made in the reuerence
Of cristis modir seid this innocent
Now certis I wille do my diligence
To cnne it alle / or cristmasse be went
Though I for my Primer shalbe shent
If that I shalle thrice withyn an hour
I wil it cnne oure lady to honourꝰer
¶ His felow taught him homward piriuely
From day to day til he coude it be root
And then he song it wele and boldly
From wurd to wurd acording wtith the note
Twise a day it past thurgh his throte
To Scoleward and homward whe he went
On cristis modir sett was his intent
¶ As I haue seid thorout the Iury
This litle child as he cam to and fro
Ful merily wold he syng and crye
O . alma redemptoris euermo
The swetnesse his hert percid so
Of cristis modir / that to hir to prey
He can not stint going by the wey
¶ Oure first fo the Serpent Sathanas
That hath in the Iuwes hert his waspis nest
Vp swalle and seid O . hebraic peple alas
Is this to you a thing that is honest
That such a boy shal walken as him lest
In your dispite / and singen of such sentence
Which is ayens oure lawis reuerence
¶ From thensfurth the Iuwes han conspirid
This innocent out of this world to chace
An homicide therto haue they hirid
That in an Aley hadde a pryue place
And as the child gan forby to pace
This cursid Iuwe him hent ⁊ held him fast
And cutte his throte ⁊ in a pitte him cast
¶ I sey that in a wardrope they him thrue
Wherꝰer as the Iuwes purgen her entraile
O . cursid folk of herodis alle newe
What may your euyll intent you auayle
Murdir wil out certeyn it is no faile
And namely ther as the honour of god shal sprede
The blood out crieth of their cursid dede
¶ O martir steudid vnto virginite
Now maistow sing folowing euer in one
The white lambe celestiall coth she
Of which the good Euangelist Seint Iohn
In Pathmose wrote which seiþ þei gan gan
Beforn this lambe and sing a song al new
That neuer flesshly thei no woman knew
This poure widow awaitith al that nyght
Aftir hir litle child but he come nought
For which as sone as it was day light
With face pale of drede and bisy thouȝt
She hath at Scole and ellis wherꝰer him souȝt
Tille finaly she gan so ferre aspye
That he last was sene in Iury .
¶ With modirs pite withyn hir brest inclosid
She goth as she were out of hir mynde
To euery place wher she hath supposid
By liklihode hir litle child to finde
And euer on crist modir meke and kynde
She cried / and at last thus she wrought
Among the cursid Iuwes she him sought
¶ She freyneth and she praieth pitously
To euery Iuwe that duellith in that place
To telle hir if hir child went forby
They seiden nay / but ihu of his grace
Yaue in hir thought withyn a litle space
That in that place aftir hir son she cride
Wherꝰer he was cast in a pitte beside
¶ O . gret god that ꝑperfourmist thi laude
By mouth of innocentis lo her þi might
The gemme of chastite this Emeraude
And also of martirdom the Ruby bright
Ther he with throte y corue lay upright
He alma redemptoris gan to syng
So loud that alle the place began to ringe
¶ The cristen folk that thurgh þe strete went
In come forto wundir upon this thing
And hastily they for the Prouost sent
He come anone without euy tariyng
And heryeth crist that is oure heuen king
And also his modir honour of mankynde
And aftir the Iuwes lete he bynde
¶ This child with pitous lamentacion
Vptaken was . singing his song alwey
And with greet honour and procession
They him cary vnto the next Abbey /
His modir swonyng by the bere lay
Vnneth might the peple that was þerꝰer
This yong Rachel bring from his bere
¶ With torment and with shenfull deth echon
This Prouost doth the Iuwes forto sterue
That of this mordrꝰer wist and that anon
He nold no such cursidnesse obꝸserue
Euel they shul haue that euyl deꝸserue
Therfore with wild hors he did hem draw
And aftir that did hang hem by the lawe
¶ Vpon this bere lith this . Innocent
Vpon the chief auter while þe masse last
And aftir that the Abbot with his couent
Haue spedde hem forto bury him ful fast
⁊ þen þei holiwatꝰer on hiꝰer cast
And yit when cast was the holy watir
The child song Alma redemptoris matꝰer .
This Abbot which that was an holy man
¶ As monkis ben or ought forto be
This yong child to coniure began
And seid . O . dere child I hals thee
In uertue of the holy Trinite
Telle me what is thy cause forto syng
Sith that thy throte is cutte to my semyng
¶ My throte is cutt vnto my necke bone
Seid this child / and as by wey of kynde
I shuld haue deyed longtime agon
But ihu crist as ye in bokis finde
Wil that his glorie last and be in mynde
And for wurship of his modir dere
Yit may I sing O . alma loude and clerꝰer
¶ This welle of mercy cristis modir swete
I loued alwey as aftir my c̄etcūnnyng
And when that I my lif shuld forlete
To me she come and bad me to syng
This antym verily in my diyng
As ye haue herd what I haue song
Me thought she leid a . greyn on my tong
¶ Therfore I sing and sing mut certeyn
In honour of that blisfulle maiden fre
Till fro my tung be taken awey the greyn
And aftir this seid She vnto me
My litle child now wille I fecche thee
When the greyne is fro thi tung y take
Be not agast I wylle thee not forsake
¶ This holy monk þis Abbot him mene I .
His tung out caught and toke awey þe greyn
And yaue up the gost fulle softily
And whan the Abbot had this wundir seyn
His salt teris triclid doun as Reyne
And groueling he fil flat upon the grōmnd
And stille he lay as he had ben bounde
¶ The Couent also lay doun on þe pauemēmt
Weping and heriyng cristis modir dere
And aftir that they risen ⁊ furth þei went
And took awey this martir from his bere
And in a Tumbe of marble stones clere
Enclosid they his litle body swete
Ther he is now god graunt us forto mete
¶ O yong Hugh of lincoln also .
With cursid Iuwis as it is notable
For it is but a litle while a go .
Pray eke for us we sinful folk vnstable
That of his merci god so mꝰerciable
On us his gret mercy multiplye
For the reuerence of his modir Marye

l.hi: The Prolog of Chaucers tale of ꝸser Thopas

div.l: When endid was þis miracle euꝰery man
Alle sobur were wundir it was to se
Til our host iape tho began
And than atte erst he lokid upon me
And seid thus / what man artow qd he
Thou lokist as thou woldist finde an hare
For euer upon the grounde I . se the stare
¶ Approch nere and look up merily
War you sir and lat this man haue place
He in the wast is shapen as wele as I
This were a . puppet in armes to enbrace

l.hi: For eny woman smalle and feir of face .

div.l: He semeth eluyssh as by his countenaunce
For vnto no wight doth he daliaunce
¶ Sey now sumwhat sith othir folk haue seid
Telle us a tale of myrth . and that anon
Host coth I . ne beth not euel appaid
For othir tale certis can I . none
But of a . Ryme I lerned long agone
Ye that is good coth he shulle we it here
Sum deintee thing me think be thy cher
The tale of Sir Thopas
LIsteth lordes / in good entent.
And I wil telle vꝰerrayment
Of myrthe / and of solas
Al of a knyght was fair and gent
In bataille / and in tornament
His name / was sir Thopas
¶ Yborn he was / in fer contree
In fflaundres / al biyonde the see
At Poperyng in the place
His fader was / a man ful free
And lord he was / of that contree
As it was / goddes garace
¶ Sire Thopas wax / a doghty swayn
Whit was his face / as Payndemayn
His lippes reed as Rose
His rode is lyk / Scarlet in grayn
As I yow telle / in good certayn
He hadde a semely nose
¶ His heer his berd / was lyk Safrown
That to his girdel / raughte adown
His shoon / of Cordewane
Of Brugges / were his hosen brown
His Robe was / of Syklatown
That coste many a Iane
¶ He koude hunte / at wilde deer
And ride an hawkyng for Ryuer
With grey goshauk on honde
Ther to he was / a good Archier
Of wrastlyng was ther noon his pier
Ther any Ram shal stonde
¶ fful many mayde / bright in bour
They moorne for hym / ꝑperamour
Whan hem / were bet to slep
But he was chaast and no lechour
And swete / as is the brambel flour
That bereth the rede hepe
¶ And so it fel / vp on a day
For sothe / as I yow telle may
Sire Thopas / wolde out ryde
He warth vp on / his Steede gray
And in his hand / a launcegay
A long Swerd / by his syde
¶ He priketh thurgh / a fair fforest
Ther Inne / is many a wilde best
Ye bothe / bukke and hare
And as he priketh / North ⁊ Est
I telle it yow / hym hadde almest
Bitydde / a sory care
¶ There spryngen herbes / grene ⁊ smale
The Licorys / and Cetewale
And many a clowe Gylofre
And notemuge / to putte in Ale
Wheither it be / moyste / or stale
Or / for to leye in cofre
¶ The bryddes synge / it is no nay
The Sꝑperhauk and the Popyniay
That ioye / it was to here
The thurstelcok made eek his lay
The wodedowue / vp on the spray
She sang ful loude ⁊ clere
¶ Sire Thopas fil / in loue longynge
Al whan he herde / the thrustel synge
And pryked / as he were wood
His fayre Steede / in his pirikynge
So swatte / þtat men myghte hym wrynge
Hys sydes / were al blood
¶ Sire Thopas eek / so wery was
For prikyng on the softe gras
So fiers / was his corage
That doun he leyde hym / in the plas
To make his Steede / som solas
And yaf hym / good forage
¶ O Seinte Marie / benedicite
What eyleth / this loue at me
To bynde me / so soore
Me dremed / al this nyght ꝑperdee
An Elf queene / shal my lemman be
And slepe / vnder my gore
¶ An Elf queene / wol I haue ywys
For in this world / no womman is
Worthy to be my make //
in towne ;
Alle othere wommen / I forsake
And to an Elf queene / I me take
By dale / and eek by downe
¶ In to his Sadel / he clamb anoon
And priketh ouer / style and stoon
An Elf queene / for tespye
Til he so longe / hath riden ⁊ goon
That he foond / in a pryuee woon
The contree of ffairye //
So wylde ;
ffor in that contree / was ther noon
Neither wyf ne childe ~
¶ Til þtat ther cam / a greet geaunt
His name was / sire Olifaunt
A ꝑperilous man of dede
He seyde child / by Termagaunt
But if thow pryke / out of myn haunt
Anon I sle thy Steede
¶ With Mace ~
¶ Heere is this queene / of ffairye
With harpe ⁊ pipe / ⁊ Symphonye
Dwellyng in this place
¶ The child seyde / als mote I thee
Tomorwe / wol I meete thee
Whan I haue myn Armowre
¶ And yet I hope / ꝑper ma fay
That thow shalt wtith this launcegay
Abyen it ful sowre
¶ Thy Mawe ~
Shal I percen / if I may
Er it be fully pryme of day
ffor here shaltow ben slawe
¶ Sire Thopas / drow abak ful faste
This geant at hym stones caste
Out of a fel Staf slynge
¶ But faire escapeth / child Thopas
And al it was / thurgh goddes graas
And thurgh his fair berynge
3et lesteth lordes / to my tale
Murier than the nyghtyngale
I wol yow rowne
How sire Thopas / with sydes smale
Prikyng ouer hyll and dale
Is come agayn to towne
¶ Hys murye men / comanded he
To make hym / bothe game and glee
ffor nedes moste he fighte
With a geant with heuedes thre
For ꝑperamour / and Iolitee
Of oon / that shoon ful brighte
¶ Do come he seyde / my Mynstrales
And Gestours / for to tellen tales
Anon / in myn Armyng
Of romances / that been reales
Of Popes / and of Cardynales
And eek / of loue likyng
¶ They fette hym first swete wyn
And mede eek in a Maselyn
And real Spicerye
Of gyngebred / that was ful fyn
And lycorys / and eek Comyn
With Sugre / that is trye
¶ He dide next his white leer
Of clooth of lake / fyn ⁊ cleer
A breech / and eek a Sherte
And next his Sherte / an Aketoūn
And ouer that an haubergeoūn
ffor ꝑpercyng of his herte
¶ And ouer that a fyn hauberk
Was al ywroght of Iewes werk
fful strong it was of plate
And ouer that / his cote Armour
As whit as is / a lilie flour
In which / he wol debate
¶ His sheeld was al / of gold so reed
And ther Inne was / a bores heed
A Charbocle / by his syde
And there he swoor / on Ale and breed
How þtat the geant / shal be deed
Bityde / what bityde
¶ Hise Iambeux were / of quyrboily
His swerdes shethe / of Yuory
His helm / of laton bright
His Sadel was / of Rewel bon
His brydel / as the Sonne shon
Or as the moone light
¶ His spere was / of fyn Cipres
That bodeth werre / and no thyng pes
The heed / ful sharp ygrounde
His Steede was / al dappel gray
It goth an Ambel / in the way
fful softely / and rounde //
In londe ~
¶ Lo lordes myne / here is a fit
If ye wole / any moore of it
To telle it wol I fonde
NOw hoold youre mouth ꝑper charitee
Bothe knyght and lady free
And herkneth to my spell
Of bataille / and of chiualry
And of ladyes / loue drury
Anon / I wol yow tell
¶ Men speken / of Romances of pris
Of Hornchild / and of Ypotys
Of Beves and Sir Gy
Of Sire lybeux / and playn damorur
But sire Thopas / he bereth the florur
Of real Chiualry
¶ His goode Steede / al he bystrood
And forth vp on his wey he glood
As Sparcle / out of the bronde
Vp on his Creest he bar a tour
And ther Inne stiked / a lilie flour
God shilde / his cors fro shonde
¶ And for he was / a knyght auntrous
He nolde slepen / in noon hous
But liggen in his hode
His brighte helm / was his wonger
And by hym / bayteth his destrer
Of herbes / fyne and goode
¶ Hym self / drank water of the well
As dide the knyght Sir Percyuell
So worly vnder wede
Til on a day
¶ Nomore of this for goddis dignite
Qoth oure host / for thou makist me
So wery of thy veraye lewdenesse
That al so wisly god my soule blesse
Myn eris aken of thy drasty speche
But such a ryme the deuel I beteche
This may wel be ryme dogrell coth he
Why so coth I why wiltow lett me
More of my tale then anothir man
Sith that it is the best ryme that I can
Be god coth he for pleynli at one word
Thy drasty ryme is not wurth a tord
Thou dost not ellis but dispendist tyme
Sir at one wurd thou shat no lengꝰer ryme
Lat se wher thou canst telle ought in gest
Or telle sumwhat in prose atte lest
In which ther may be sum myrth or doctrine
Gladly coth I by goddis swete pyne
I wil you telle a litle thing in prose
That aught to like you as I suppose
Or ellis certis ye ben to dangerous
For it is a moralle tale vertuous
Al be it told sumtime in sondry wise
Of sundry folk as I shalle you diuise
Al thus ye wote that euery Euangelist
That tellith us the peyne of ihu crist
Ne seith not all thyng as his felow doth
But nathelesse yit is their sentence soth
And alle acorden as in her sentence
Al be ther in her tellyng difference
For sum of hem sey more ⁊ sum lesse
When they his pitous passiou expꝰersse
I mene of marke mathue luke ⁊ Iohn
But doutles her sentence is but one
Therfore lordingꝭes alle I you beseche
If that ye think I vary in my speche
As thus / if that I telle sum what more
Of ꝓprouerbis then ye haue herd before
Comprehendid in this litle tretice her
To enforcen with theffect of my matier
And though I not the same wurdis sey
As ye han herd yit to you alle I prey
Blameth me not for as in my sentence
Ne shulle ye not finden no difference
Fro the sentence of this tretice lite
Aftir the which this mery tale I write
And therfore herkneth what that I sey
And lat me telle alle my tale I you prey
Here endith Chaucers tale of sir Thopas
A . doughty knyght in alle his dede
God help us alle and seint Thomas
And graunt us his grace wele to spede . Amen

ab.hi: The tale of Melibeus and prudence

div.ab:
Yong man callid Melibeus mighty
and riche begatt upon his wif callid
Prudence a doughtir that cleped
was Sophy /

It befil upon a day þat for his
disport he is went into the feldis him to pley

his wif and eke his doughtir haþ he left wiþyn
his hous of which the doris were fast y shet

And thre of his olde foon han aspied it ⁊ sett
ladders to the wallis of his hous ⁊ by þe wyn
dowis ben thei entrid

and bett / his wif ⁊ wou
did hir doughtir with fyve mortal woundis in
fyve sundry placis /

this is to seyn in hir fete
in hir hondis / in hir mouth in hir nose ⁊ in hir
hede . and left hir for dede ⁊ wenten awey .

¶
And when Melibeus retourned home into
his hous and sigh alle this mischeve / he like a madde
man rentyng his clothis gan to wepe and cry

¶
Prudence his wif as ferfurth as she durst besouȝt
hym of his weping to stent /

But not for then
he gan to crie ⁊ wepe euꝰer leng the more /

This
noble wif Prudence remembrid hir upon þe sen-
tence of Ouyde in his book þat is cleped þe Remedi
of loue . wher as he seith /

he is a fool þtat disturbith
þe modir to wepe for þe deeþ of hir child till she
haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn time /

And
þen shal a man do his diligence wtith amiable wordꝭes
hir to recumfort ⁊ prey hir to stint of hir we-
ping /

For which resou þis noble wif prudence
suffrid hir husbond to wepe and cry for a certeyn
space /

And when she saugh hir time she seid to
him in this wise // Alas my lord qd she why make
ye yourselue so like a fool //

Forsoth it apꝑperteyneth
not to a wiseman to make such sorow //

youre
douȝtꝰer wtith the grace of god shal warissh ⁊ escape

And al wer it so þtat she riȝt now wer dede ye ne
ouȝt as for hir deth destrue yourselue /

Seneca
seith // The wiseman shal not take to gret discu
fort for the deþe of his children /

but certꝭes he shuld
suffre it pacientli as wel as he abidith þe deth of
his ꝓpropre ꝑpersone

¶ This Melibeus ansuerd Anon
and seid / what man coth he shuld of his weping
stint þtat haþ so gret a cause to wepe //

Ihu crist
oure lord him selue wept for the deþ of lazarus
his frend //

Prudence ansuerd / certis wel I wote
Attempre weping is not defendid to him that is
soroufull amongꝭes folk in sorow / but is rathir gron
did him to wepe /

The apostle poule vnto the Ro
mayns writith / Men shull reioyse wtith hem þat
maken ioye and wepe with such folk as wepen

And though attempre weping be grauntid Out
ragious weping certis is defendid /

Mesure of
weping shuld be considird aftꝰer the lore as techiþ
vs Seneca //

When that thy frend is dede coth he
lat not thyn eyen be to moist of teris ne to moch
drye Al though the teris come to thyn eyen lat
hem not falle //

And when thou hast forgone thy
frend do diligence to gete anothir frend / ⁊ þis is
more wisdom then forto wepe for thy frend the
which thou hast lore / For theryn is no bote //

And þer-
fore if ye gouern you by sapience putt awey sorou
of your hert //

Remembrith you that Ihūns Sirac
seith in his age // A man that is ioyous ⁊ glad īn hert
it conꝸserueth and florisshith him in his age // But
sothly sorouful hert makith his bones drye /

he sieþ
also thus that sorou in hert sleth ful many a man

Salamou seith þat riȝt as motthis in þe Shepis
flece anoyeth the clothis and the small wormes
to the tree . Right so anoyeth sorou in hert /

Wherfor
we ought as wel in the deth of oure children as
in the losse of oure goodis temporall haue paciēms

Remembrith you upon pacient Iob when he had
lost hs children and his temporall substance . ⁊ in
his body endurid ⁊ receyued ful many a . greuous
tribulacioūn . then seid he þus

Oure lord hath be-
raft it me / Right as oure lord wold so is don blissid
be name of oure lord

¶ To this forseid þingꝭes
ansuerd Melibeus vnto his wif Prudence / Alle
your wurdis coth be soth and þerto profitable
But truly myn hert is troublid wtith this sorow so
greuously þat I ne woot what to done /

¶ Lat cal
qd prudence your true frendis alle ⁊ your linage
which that ben wise Telle hem your case and
herkneth what they sey in counseilling And gouꝰer-
neth you aftꝰer their sentence /

Salamou seyth
wirk al thy thingis by counseil ⁊ thou shat neuꝰer
repent thee /

¶ Than by counseil of his wyf
prudence this Melibeus lete calle a gret congre-
gaciou of folk

as Surgiens phisiciens olde folk
and yong // And sum of his old enemyes reconsilid
as by her semblant to his loue ⁊ to his grace /

⁊
therwithall ther come sum of his neighbours þtat
did him reuꝰerence more for drede then for loue As
it happith often /

Ther come also many a ful sub-
tile flaterer and wise aduocatꝰer lerned in law /

⁊
when thise folk assemblid wer this melibeus in
fulle sorouful wise shewid hem his case

And by þe
manꝰer of his speche is semed wel that in hert he bar
a cruell ire to do vengeance upon his fone And
sodeynli desirid that the werre shuld begynne //

But natheles yit askid he their counseill upon þs
matier /

¶ A . Surgien by licence ⁊ assent of such
as weren wise uprose ⁊ to melibeus seid as ye may
here . /

Sir coth he as to no Surgiens apꝑperteyneþ þtat
we do to euery wight the best that we can where
as we ar witholden / And to oure pacientꝭes that we
do no damage //

Wherfore it happith many times and
ofte þat when two men haue woundid euerich oþir
One famous Surgien helith hem both /

Wherfor
to oure art it is nat ꝑpertinent to norissh werre ne pes

Be like a wood leon fool hardy
I woot wele she wil do me sle sum day
Sum neiȝbour / and then go my way
For I am ꝑperilous with knyfe in hond
Al be it that I dar not hir with stond
For she is bigge in armes be my feith
That shal he finde that to hir mysseith
But lat us pas ouer of this matier
My lord sir monk he seith be mery of cher
For ye shulle telle us a tale truly
Lo Rouchestir stondith here fastby
Ridith furth myn owne lord brekiþ not our game
But be my trouth I know not your name
Whethir I . shal calle you my lord Dan Iohn
Or dan Thomas or ellis Dan Albon
Of what hous be ye by your fadir kyn
I . vowe to god thou hast a . fulle feyr skyn
It is a gentle pasture ther thou gost
Thou art not like a . forpyned gost
Vpon my feith thou art sum officer
Sum wurthy Sexteyn or sum celarer
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Thou art maistꝰer when thou art at home
No poure cloistrer ne no novice
But gouꝰernour / and þat fulle wily . ⁊ wise
And therwith all of brawnes and of bones
A wel feir ꝑpersone for the nones
I . pray to god yeve him confuciou
That first thee brouȝt into Religiou
Thou woldist haue ben a trede foul ariȝt
Haddistow as gret leve as thou hast myȝt
To ꝑperfourme al thy lust in engendrure
Thou haddist begoten many a creatur
Alas why weristow so wide a . cope
God yeue me sorou but and I . wer pope
Not only thou but euery myghty man
Though he were shorn an high upon þe pan
Shuld haue a wif for al this world is lorn
Religiou hath take up alle the corn
Of treding and we borel men ar shrimpis
Of feble trees cometh wrechid ympis
This makith þtat oure childir be so sclendrꝰer
And feble / þat they may not wele engendrꝰer
This makith that oure wyues wil assay
Religious folk for they mai bettir pay
Of venus payment then may we
God woot no lūnsshborous paye ye
But be not wroþ my lord though I pley
Ful often in game a soth I haue herd sey
¶ This wurthy Monk took alle in pacience
And seid / I . wille do alle my diligence
As ferre as sowneth into honestee
To telle you a . tale . two or thre
And if you list to herken hidirward
I . wille you sey the life of seint Edward
Or ellis tregedis first wille I . telle
Of which I haue an hundrith in my Selle
Tregedis is forto tellen a . certeyn Story
As olde Bokes maken memorye
Of hem that stoden in grete prosperite
And beth y Fallen oute of high degree
Into misery / and enden wrecchidly
And they ben versified comunely
Of vj . fete that men clepen exametrou
In prose eke ben endid many one
And eke in metre in many sundrie wise
Lo this ought you enough suffice
Now herkneth if you lust forto her
But first I . you beseche in this matier
Thouȝ I be ordre telle not thees þingis
Be it of popis Emꝑperours or kyngis
And aftꝰer their age as men writen finde
But telle hem sum bifore ⁊ sum behinde
As it cometh now vnto my remembrance
Haue me excusid of myn ignoraunce
¶ The Monkis tale
I will bewaile in maner of Tregedy
The harme of hem þat stode in hiȝ degr
And felle so that ther nas no remedy
To bring hem oute of their aduersite
Wher For certeyn when Fortune list to fle
Ther may no man of hir the course wiþhold
Lat no man trust on blinde prosperite
Bewar by this ensample both yong ⁊ olde
At Lucifer though he an Angel were
And not a man at him I wille begynne
For though Fortune ne mai none Angel dere
From high degre yit felle he for his synne
Doun into helle where that he is ynne
O Lucifer brightist of Angels alle
Now artow Sathanas thou maist not twyn
Out of Misery / in which thou art y falle
¶ Also Adam in the felde of Damastene
With goddis own fingir wrouȝt was he
And not begoten of mannes sꝑperme vnclene
And welt alle paradise sauyng one tre
And neuꝰer worldly man of so high degre
As Adam was till he for his gouꝰernaunce
Was dryuen out of his high prosperite
To labour and to helle and to myschance
Lo Sampson which was annunciat
By the Angel long ere his natiuite
And was to god almighty consecrate
And stood in noblesse whils he mighte se
Was neuer such anothir as was he
To speke of strength ⁊ therto hardines
But to his wyues told he his secree
Thurgh which he slue himselue by wickidnes
¶ Sampson this noble ⁊ mighti champion
Withouten wepen saue his handis twey
He slough and alto rent the leon
Toward his weddyng walkynge by the weye
His fals wife couth him so pleas ⁊ prey
Til she his counseil knew ⁊ she vntrue
Vnto his foos his counseil can bewrey
And him forsook and toke anothir newe
¶ An hundrith foxis took Sampson for Ire
And alle their tailes he togidir bond
And sette the foxes tailis alle on fire
For he in euery taile had putt a brond
And thei brent alle the cornes in the lond
And alle her Olyues ⁊ her Vines eke
An thousand men eke he slue wt his hond
And had no wepen but an Asse cheke
¶ Whan they wer slaine so thirstid him þtat he
Was welny lorn for which he gan to prey
That god wold of his mercy haue sum pite
And send him drink or ellis must he deye
And of this Asse cheke that was so drey
Out of a wang tothe anon ther sprang a well
Of which he drank enough shortly to sey
¶ Thus helpt him god as Iudicum can telle
By veray force at Gason upon a nyght
Maugre Philistience of that Cyte
The gatis of the toun he hath up plight
And on his bakke y caried hem hath he
High on an hille where as he men might se
O noble and mighti Sampson leve and dere
Ne haaddistow not told to women thy secree
¶ In alle this world ne had ben thy pere
This Sampson neithir sidre drank ne wine
Ne on his hede cam Rasour none ne shere
By precept of the Messager diuine
For alle his strength tho was in her his here
And fully twenty yere by yere
He hadde of Israel the gouernaunce
But sone aftir shalle he wepe many a tere
For women shal bring him to mischaunce
¶ Vnto his leman Dalida he tolde
That in his heris al his strengthe lay
And falsly to his fomen she him sold
And sleping in hir barme upon a day
She made to clipp and shere his here away
And made his fomen alle his craft aspyen
And when thei him found in such array
Thei bound him fast and putt out his eyen
¶ But or his here were clippid or y shaue
Ther was no bonde that hym might bynde
But now is he in prison putt in a Cave
Wher as thei made him at a quern grinde
O noble Sampson strengist of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse
Now maistow wepe with thine eyen blinde
Sith thou art fallen into wrechidnesse
¶ The ende of thees caitives as I shal sey
His fomen made a fest upon a day
And made him as her fool aforn hem pley
And this was in a temple of gret array
But at last he made a foule affray
For he ij. postis shook ⁊ made hem falle
And doun fille temple ⁊ alle ther it lay
And slue himselue ⁊ eke his fomen alle
¶ This is the ende of Princis euerichone
And eke a thousand bodies were y slayn
With falling of the gret temple of stone
Of Sampson wille I no more seyn
But war bi this ensample old ⁊ pleyn
That no men telle her counseil to her wyues
Of such thingis as thei wold haue secret feyn
If þat it touche her lymmes or their lyues
of Hercules that souꝰereyn conquerour
Signed his werkis and high renon
For in his time of strength he bar þe florur
He slough and beraft the skynne fro the leon
He of Centaurus leyde the bost a doun
He arpyes slough the cruelle birde felle
He golden Appuls raft from the dragon
He drue out Cerberus the hound of helle
¶ He slue the cruell tirraunt Buferous
And made his hors to frete him flessh ⁊ bone
He slue the veraie serpent venemous
Of Adeldis .ij. hornes brake he one
And he slue Cacus in a Caue of stone
He slue the geant Antius the strong
He slue the grisly bore and that anone
And bare his hede upon his nekke long
¶ Was neuer wiȝt sith the world began
That slue so many monstres as did he
Thurgh this wide world his name ran
What for his strength and for his bounte
And into euery Reame went he forto se
He was so strong that noman miȝt him lett
And at the worldis ende as seith Trophee
In stede of boundis he a piller sette
¶ A lemman hadde this noble champion
That hight Diganer as fressh as May
And as the clerkis maken mencion
She hath him sent a shert fressh ⁊ gay
Alas alas this shert and welaway
Envenymed was subtily with alle
That or he had worn it halue a day
It made his bones from his flessh to fall
¶ But naþeles sum clerkis hir excusen
By one that hight Nessus þtat it makid
Be as it may I nyl hir not accusen
But þat his flessh was of þe venym blakid
When þat this venym had him þus awakid
And þat he sigh none othir remedye
In hoot colis he hath himselue y rakid
For with venym deigned him not to dye
¶ Thus starve this wurthi mighti Hercules
Lo who mai trust on Fortune eny throwe
For him that folowid al this world of prees
Or he be ware is y leide fulle lowe
Ful wise is he that himselue can know
Bewar for when that Fortune list to gloos
Than waitith she hir man doun to throw
By such a weye as he wolde lest suppoos
the myȝty trone and the pꝰercious tresour
The gloryous ceptir and roial maieste
That hadde the kyng Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnnethe may discryued be
He twice wanne Ierusalem the Cite
The vesselle of the temple wtith him he ladde
At Babiloyn was his souereyn see
In which his glorie and his delite he hadde
¶ The feirist childirn of the blood roiall

l.seg: Among alle othir Daniel was one

div.l: Of ierusalem he didde do gelde anone
And made eche of hem to be his thrall
Among alle othir Daniel was one / Þtat was þe wisist child of euꝰerychon
For he the dremes of the king expowned
Wher as in Caldy clerc was ther none
That wist to what fine his dremes sowned
¶ This proude king lete make a Statue of gold
Thre score cubitis long ⁊ vij. in brede
To which ymage both yong and olde
Comaundid he to loute and to haue in drede
Or in a fourneux fulle of flammes rede
He shuld be brent that wold not obeye
But neuer wold assent to that dede
Daniel / ne his yong felowis tweye
¶ This king was proude passing his degre
He went god that sittis in maieste
Had not ben so greet a lord as he
But sodeinli he lost his dignite
And like a beste him semed forto be
And ete heye as an Oxe ⁊ lay ther out
In reyn with wilde bestis walkid he
Til certeine yeris were comen about
¶ And like an Egles fethirs was his heris
His nailis like birdis clawis were
God releued him at certeine yeris
And yaue him witte / ⁊ then wtith many a ter
He thankid god / and euer his lif in fere
Was he to do amyseamysseamysse or more trespace
And or that time he leid was on his bere
He knew that god was ful of might ⁊ grace
¶ His sonne which that hight Balthezar
That held the reame aftir his fadirs day
He by his fadir coude not bewar
For proude he was of hert and of arraye
And eke an ydolestꝰer was he aye
His high estate assurid him nothing
But Fortune cast him doun þer he lay
And sodeinli his reame gan diuide
¶ A fest he made vnto his lordis alle
Vpon a time he made hem blithe be
And than his Officers gan he to calle
Go bringith furth the vessellis qd he
Which that my fadir in his prosꝑperite
Out of the temple of Ierlm beraft
And to oure high goddis thank we
Of honure that oure eldres wtith us laft
¶ His wyue his lordis and his concubines
Ay drinken while þat their appetite last
Out of thees noble vessels sondrie wines
And on a walle he his eyen cast
And saugh an hand armles þat wrote fast
For fere of which he quoke ⁊ sighid sore
This hand that Balthezar made sore agast
Wrote Mane techil phares and no more
¶ In alle that lond Magicien was ther none
That couth expoun what this lettꝰer ment
But Daniel expoundid it anone
And seid king god to thi fadir sent
Glorie and honure reame and rent
And he was proud ⁊ god nothing he dradde
And therfore god gret wreche on him sent
And him beraft the reame that he hadde
¶ He was out cast of mannes cumpanye
With Assis then was his habitacioun
And ete heye as a beste in wete and drye
Til that he knewe by grace and by reson
That high god of heuen hath dnacion
Ouer euery reame and euery creatur
And then had he of him compassion
And him restorid his ream and his figur
¶ Eke thou art his sonne and proude also
And knowist alle thees thingis priuely
And rebellist to god and art his fo
Thou drankist eke of his vessels boldly
Thy wyue eke and thy wenchis synfully
Drank of the same vessellis sundry wynes
And heryd fals goddis cursidly
Therfore to thee shapen gret pine is
This hand was sent from god þtat on þe wall
Wrote Mane techil phares trust to me
Thy reigne is done thou weldist it not at all
Diuidid is thy ream and it shal be
To Medes and to Perces youen qd he
And that same nyght the king was slaw
And Darius occupieth his degre
Though he therto had nouthir riȝt ne lawe
¶ Lordinges here by may ye ensamples take
Hough that in lordship is no sicurnesse
For when Fortune wil a man forsake
He berith awey his reame ⁊ his richesse
And eke his frendis both more and lesse
And when a man hath frendis þurgh Fortune
Mishappe wille make him enemyes I gesse
This prouerbe is fulle true and fulle commune
cenobia of Palamerꝰer the quene
As writen ꝐPerciens of hir noblesse
So wurthy was in Armes ⁊ so kene
That no wight passid hir in hardynesse
Ne in linage ne in othir gentilnesse
Of the kingis blood of Perse is she descendid
I sey she had not most feirnesse
But of hir shappe she miȝt not be amendid
From childhood I finde that she fledde
Office of woman / and into wood she went
And many a wilde hertis blood she shedde
With Arrows brood that she to hem sent
She was so swift that she anon hem hent
And whom that she inkid she wold kille
Leons and Leopardis and Beris al torent
And in hir Armes welde hem at hir wille
¶ She durst wilde bestis dennes seke
And renne in the mounteyns alle þe night
And slepe vndir a bussh she couth eke
Wrastle by veraye force and myght
With eny man / were he neuer so wiȝt
Ther myght nothing in hir armes stond
She kept hir maidenhede from euery wiȝt
To no man deigned she to be bond
¶ But at last hir frendis haue hir maryed
To Odynak a prince of that Cite
Al were it so that she him long taried
And ye shulle vndirstond houȝ that he
Hadde such fantasies as had she
But naþeles when thei wer knytt in fer
Thei lyued in ioye and in felicite
For eche of hem hadde othir lefe ⁊ der
¶ Saue one thing that she nold neuer assent
By no wey that he shuld by hir lye
But ones / for it was hir plaine intent
To haue a child the world to multiplie
And also sone that she might espye
That she nas with child wtith that dede
Then wold she suffre him do his fantasy
Eft sone / and but ones out of drede
¶ And if she were with child at thilk cast
No more shuld he pley thilk game
Til fourty dayes weren fully past
Then wold she suffre him do the same
Al were this Odynak wilde or tame
He gat no more of hir for but this she seid
It was to wiuis lechery and shame
In othir wise if that men with hem pleid
¶ Two sonnes by this Odynak had she
Which she kept in vertus and lecture
But now into oure tale turn we
I sey that this wurshipfull creatur
And wise therwith and large of mesur
So penyble in werre and curteis eke
Ne more labour might in werre indur
Was none / though al this world shuld seke
¶ Hir riche array miȝt not be tolde
As wel in vesselle as in clothing
She was cladde alle in perry ⁊ in gold
And yit she laft not for none hunting
To haue of sundry folkis knowyng
Whan that she leisour had ⁊ forto intende
To lern bokis was alle hir likyng
Hough she in vertue myght hir lif dispende
¶ And shortly of this forto entrete
As doughty was hir husbond as was she
That thei conquerd many reames grete
In the orient with many a feir Cite
Apꝑpertinent vnto the maiestee
Of Rome / and with strong hond held he faste
Ne neuer might their fomen don hem fle
As long as Odynakes dayes last
¶ Her batails whoso lust hem forto rede
Ageyn Saphie the king and othir mo
And hough that al the ꝓprocesse fille in dede
Why she conquerd and what title had þꝰerto
And aftir of hir mischeve and of hir wo
Hough she was bisegid and y take
Lat him vnto my maistir Petrak go
That wrote enough of this I vndirtake
¶ Whan Odynak was dede she mightily
The reames held / and with hir ꝓpropr hond
Ageyn hir foos she faught truly
That ther nas king ne pirince in al þtat lond
That he nas glad if he that grace fond
That she ne wold upon his lond werrey
With hir thei made alliaunce by bond bond
To ben in peas / and lat hir ride and pley
¶ Themꝑperour of Rome that time Claudius
Ne him beforn the Romaine Galien
Ne durst neuer ben so coragious
Ne none hermyn ne none Arrabien
That durst ones toforn hir be sene
Within the feld that durst wtith hir fiȝt
Lest that she wold wtith hir hond hem slene
Or with her meynee putt hem to fliȝt
¶ In kingis habit went hir sonnes two
As heiris of hir Reines alle
And Hermanno and Tyntalite boþe two
Their names wer as ꝐPercious hem call
But ay hath Fortune in hir hony galle
This myghti quene may no while endur
Fortune out of hir reame made hir falle
To wrecchidnesse and to mysse auentur
¶ Aurelius when that the gouernaunce
Of Rome / come into his handis twey
He shoop upon this quene to do vengeānnce
And with his legions he took the weye
Toward Cenoby shortly forto seye
He made hir fle and at last hir hent
And fetird hir and also hir childre twey
And wanne the lond ⁊ home to Rome he went
¶ Among othir thingis that he wanne
Hir Cheir that wrouȝt was with gold ⁊ perree
This gret Romaine this Aurelian
Hath wtith him ladde for men shuld it se
Beforn his triumphe walkith she
With golden cheynes on hir nekke hangig
Crowned she was and aftir hir degre
And fulle of perree chargid hir cloþing
¶ Alas Fortune she þat wlomwhylomwhylom was
Dredefulle to kyngis and to Emꝑperoures
Now gaurith alle the peple on hir alas
And she that helmed was in sterk stoures
And wanne beforn strong townes ⁊ toures
Shal on hir hede now bere a vitrimte
And she that bare the Ceptre fulle of floures
Shalle bere a distave hir costis forto quite
o noble o wurthy Petre glorie of Spayn
Whom Fortune held so high in maieste
Wele aught men thy pitous deth complayn
Thy bastard brothir made thee to fle
And aftir that a sege by subtilite
Thou were betrayed and lad to his tent
Where as he with his own hand slue thee
Succeding in thy reame and in thy rent
¶ The feld of snow with the blacke Egle þꝰer yn
Caught with the lyme rodde colourd as the glede
He brue this cursidnesse and this synne
The wickid nest was wirker of this nede
Not Charlis Olyuer that ay took good hede
Of trouth and honure / but Armorak
Glembon Olyuer corrupt for mede
Brought this wurthy king in such a brak
¶ Wurthy Petre kyng of Cipre also
That Alizaundre wanne by high maistrye
Ful many an hethen wroughtist thou much wo
Of which thine own liegis hadde enuye
And for nothing but for thy cheualrye
Thei in thy bedde haue slayn thee by þe morow
Thus can Fortune gouꝰerne thee and guye
And out of ioye bring thee into sorowe
¶ Of Myleyn gret Barnabe Viscount
God of delite and scourge of Lumbardye
Whi shuld I not thy fortune account
Sith in estate thou clymben wer so hye
Thy brothir son that was thy double allye
For he thy Nevew was ⁊ sonne in lawe
Withyn his prison made thee to dye
But why ne hough note I. ho that thou wer slaw
¶ Of Hugh Erle of Pyse the langour
Ther may no tung telle for pite
But litle out of Pise ther stant a tour
In which toure in prison putte was he
And with him ben his litle children thre
The eldist scarceli fyue yere was of age
Alas Fortune it was grete crueltee
Such birdis forto putte in a cage
¶ Dampned he was in that prison to dye
For Roger which that busshop was of Pise
And on him a fals suggestion did aspye
Thurgh which the peple gan on him rise
And putt him in prison in such wise
As ye haue herd / ⁊ mete and drink he had
So smalle that it may vnneth suffice
And ther with all it was ful poure ⁊ bad
¶ On a day fille that in an houre
Whan that this was wont to be brouȝt
The Iayler shett / the doris of the tour
He herd it wele but he ne saugh it nouȝt
And in his hert anone ther fille a thouȝt
That they for hungre anone wold don him dye
Alas coth he alas that I was wrouȝt
Ther with the teris fille from his ize
¶ His yonger son iij. yere was of age
Vnto him seid fadir why do ye wepe
When wille the Iayler bring oure potage
Is ther no morcel brede that ye do kepe
I am so hungry that I mai not slepe
Now wold god I myght slepe euer
Then shuld no hungir in my wombe crepe
¶ Ther is no thing saue brede þtat me wer leuꝰer
Thus day be day the child gan to crye
Til in his fadir barm a doun it lay
And seid fadir farwel I must dye
And kist his fadir and died the same day
And when his woful fadir dede it say
For wo his armes two he gan to bite
And seid Fortune alas and welaway
¶ Thy fals wilis my wo I. may wite
His children sigh that for hungre it was
That he his armes gnew ⁊ eke for wo
And seid fadir do not so allas
But rathir ete the flessh upon us two
Oure flessh thou yauest us take it us fro
And ete enough riȝt thus to him they seid
And aftir that withyn a day or two
¶ They leid hem doun in his lapp ⁊ deide
Himselue dispeirid eke for hungre starve
Thus endid is the mighti Erle of Pise
His high estate Fortune from him carve
Of this tregedie it aught enough suffice
Whoso wil here it in a lenger wise
Redith the grete Poete of Ytaile
That hight Daunt for he gan it diuise
From point to point not one wurd wil he fail
Al though that Nero were vicius
As any feend that lyth ful lowe adown
Yet he as telleth vs Swetonius
This wide world hadde in subieccioun
Bothe Est and West North and Septemtrioun
Of Rubies Saphires and of perles white
Were alle hise clothes browded vp and doun
For he in gemmes greetly gan delite
Moore delicat moore pompous of array
Moore proud was neuere Emperour than he
That ilke clooth that he hadde weryd o day
After that tyme he nolde it neuere see
Nettes of gold threed hadde he greet plentee
To fisshen in Tybre whan hym liste pleye
Hise lustes were al lawe in his decree
For Fortune as his freend hym wolde obeye
He Rome brende for his delicacie
The Senatours he slow vp on a day
To heere how that men wolde wepe and crye
And slow his brother and by his suster lay
His moder he made in pitous array
For he hire wombe slytte to biholde
Where he conceyued was so weilaway
That he so litel of his moder tolde
No teere out of hise eyen for that sighte
Ne cam but seyde a fair womman was she
Greet wonder is how that he koude or myghte
Be domesman of hire dede beautee
The wyn to bryngen hym comanded he
And drank anoon noon oother wo he made
Whan myght is ioyned vn to crueltee
Allas to depe wol the venym wade
In youthe a maister hadde this Emperour
To teche hym lettrure and curteisye
For of moralitee he was the flour
As in his tyme but if bookes lye
And whil this maister hadde of hym maistrye
He maked hym so louyng and so souple
That longe tyme it was er tirannye
Or any vice dorste in hym vncouple
This Seneca of which that I deuyse
By cause Nero hadde of hym swich drede
For he fro vices wolde hym ay chastise
Discretly as by word and nat by dede
Sire wolde he seyn an Emperour moot nede
Be vertuous and hate tirannye
For which he in a bath made hym to blede
On bothe hise armes til he moste dye
This Nero hadde eek of acustumance
In youthe agayns his maister for to rise
Which afterward hym thoughte a greet greuance
Ther fore he made hym dyen in this wise
Because he ofte wolde hym chastyse
But nathelees this Seneca the wise
Chees in a bath to dye in this manere
Rather than han another tormentrise
And thus hath Nero slayn his maister deere
Now fil it so that Fortune liste no lenger
The hye pride of Nero to cherice
For thogh that he was strong yet was she strenger
She thoghte thus by god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfild of vice
In heigh degree and Emperour hym calle
By god out of his sete I wol hym trice
Whan he leest weneth sonnest shal he falle
The peple roos vp on hym on a nyght
For his defaute and whan he it espied
Out of his dores anon he hath hym dight
Allone and there he wende han been allyed
He knokked faste and ay the moore he cryed
The faster shette they the dores alle
Tho wiste he wele he hadde hym selfe mysgyed
For drede of this hym thoughte that he dyed
And wente his wey no lenger dorste he calle
The peple cryde and rombled vp and doun
That with hise erys herde he how they seyde
Where is this false tirant this Neroun
For fere almoost out of his wit he breyde
And to hise goddes pitously he preyde
For socour but it myghte noght bityde
For drede of this hym thoughte that he deyde
And ran in to a gardyn hym to hyde
And in this gardyn foond he cherles tweye
That seten by a fyr greet and reed
And to thise cherlis two he gan to preye
To sleen hym and to girden of his heed
That to his body whan that he were deed
Were no despit ydoon for his defame
Hym self he slow he koude no bettre reed
Of which Fortune lough and hadde a game
Was neuere Capitayn vnder a kyng
That regnes mo putte in subieccioun
Ne strenger was in feeld of alle thyng
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne moore pompous in heigh presumpcioun
Than Oloferne which Fortune ay kiste
So likerously and ladde hym vp and doun
Til that his heed was of er that he wiste
Nat oonly that this world hadde hym in awe
For lesynge of richesse or libertee
But made euery man reneyen his lawe
Nabugodonosor was god seyde he
Noon oother god sholde adoured be
Agayns this heste no wight dorste trespace
Saue in Bethulia a strong Citee
Where Eliachym a preest was of that place
But tak kepe of the deeth of Oloferne
Amydde his oost he dronke lay a nyght
With Inne his tente large as is a berne
And yet for al his pompe and al his myght
Iudith a womman as he lay vpright
Slepynge his heed of smoot and from his tente
Ful pryuely she stal from euery wight
And to the cyte she hath it sente
And with his heed vn to hir toun she wente
What nedeth it of kyng Anthiochus
To telle his hye Roial magestee
His hye pryde hise werkes venymus
For swich another was ther noon as he
Reed which that he was in Machabee
And reed the proude wordes that he seyde
And why he fil fro heigh prosperitee
And in an hill how wrecchedly he deyde
Fortune hym hadde enchaunted so in pride
That verraily he wende he myghte attayne
Vn to the sterres vp on euery syde
And in balance weyen ech montayne
And alle the floodes of the See restrayne
And goddes peple hadde he moost in hate
Hem wolde he sleen in torment and in payne
Wenynge that god ne myghte his pryde abate
And for that Nichanore and Thymothe
Of Iewes weren venquysshed myghtily
Vn to the Iewes swich an hate hadde he
That he bad greithe his Chaar ful hastily
And swoor and seyde ful despitously
Vnto Ierusalem he wolde eft soone
To wreken his Ire on it ful cruelly
But of his purpos he was let ful soone
God for his manace hym so soore smoot
With invisible wounde ay incurable
That in hise guttes carf it so and boot
That hise peynes weren inportable
And certeinly the wreche was resonable
For many a mannes guttes dide he peyne
But from his purpos cursed and dampnable
For al his smert he wolde hym nat restreyne
But bad anon apparaillen his hoost
And sodeynly er he was of it war
God daunted al his pride and al his boost
For he so soore fil out of his char
That it hise lymes and his skyn totar lacerauit
So that he neither myghte go ne ryde
But in a chayer men aboute hym bar
Al forbrused bothe bak and syde
The wreche of god hym smoot so cruelly
That thurgh his body wikked wormes crepte
And ther with al he stank so horribly
That noon of al his meynee that hym kepte
Wheither so he wook or ellis slepte
Ne myghte noght for stynk of hym endure
In this meschief he wayled and eek wepte
And knew god lord of euery creature
To al his hoost and to hym self also
Ful wlatsom was the stynk of his careyne
No man ne myghte hym bere to ne fro
And in this stynk and this horrible peyne
He starf ful wrecchedly in a monteyne
Thus hath this Robbour and this homycide
That many a man made to wepe and pleyne
Swich gerdon as bilongeth vn to pryde
The Storie of Alisandre is so commune
That euery wight that hath discrecioun
Hath herd som what or al of his fortune
This wide world as in conclusioun
He wan by strengthe or for hys hye renoun
They were glad for pees vn to hym sende
The pryde of man and beest he leyde adoun
Where so he cam vn to the worldes ende
Comparison myghte neuere yet ben maked
Bitwixe hym and another Conquerour
For al this world for drede of hym hath quaked
He of knyghthod and of fredom flour
Fortune hym made the heir of hire honour
Saue wyn and wommen no thyng myghte aswage
His hye entente in armes and labour
So was he ful of Leonyn corage
What prys were it to hym thogh I yow tolde
Of Darius and an hundred thousand mo
Of kynges Prynces Dukes Erles bolde
Whiche he conquered and broghte hem in to wo
I seye as fer as man may ride or go
The world was his what sholde I moore deuyse
For thogh I write or tolde yow euere mo
Of his knyghthode it myghte nat suffise
Twelf yeer he regned as seith Machabee
Philippes sone of Macidoyne he was
That first was kyng in Grece the contree
O worthy gentil Alisandre allas
That euere sholde fallen swich a cas
Empoysoned of thyn owene folk thow weere
Thy sys Fortune hath turned in to Aas
And for thee ne weep she neuer a teere
Who shal me yeue teeris to compleyne
The deeth of gentilesse and of franchise
That al this world weldid in his demeyne
And yet hym thoughte it myghte nat suffise
So ful was his corage of heigh emprise
Allas who shal me helpe to endite
False Fortune and poyson to despise
The whiche two of al this wo I wyte
By wisdom manhede and by greet labour
From humble bed to Roial magestee
Vp roos he Iulius the Conquerour
That wan al the Occident by land and see
By strengthe of hond or ellis by tretee
And vn to Rome made hem tributarie
And sith of Rome the Emperour was he
Til that Fortune weex his aduersarie
O myghty Cesar that in Thessalie
Agayn Pompeus fader thyn in lawe
That of thorient hadde al the chiualrie
As fer as that the day bigynneth dawe
Thow thurgh thy knyghthod hast hem take and slawe
Saue fewe folk that with Pompeus fledde
Thurgh which thow puttest al Thorient in awe
Thanke Fortune that so wel thee spedde
But now a litel while I wol biwaille
This Pompeus this noble gouernour
Of Rome which that fleigh at this bataille
I seye oon of hise men a fals traitour
His heed of smoot to wynnen hym fauour
Of Iulius and hym the heed he broghte
Allas Pompeie of Thorient conquerour
That Fortune vn to swich a fyn thee broghte
To Rome agayn repaireth Iulius
With his triumphe lauriat ful hye
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euere hadde of his heighe estat enuye
Ful pryuely hath maad conspiracie
Agayns this Iulius in subtil wise
And caste the place in which he sholde dye
With Boydekyns as I shal yow deuyse
This Iulius to the Capitolie wente
Vp on a day as he was wont to goon
And in the Capitolie anon hym hente
This false Brutus and hise othere foon
And stiked hym with Boydekyns anon
With many a wounde and thus they lete hym lye
But neuere gronte he at no strook but oon
Or ellis at two but if his storie lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wel louede estatly honestee
That thogh hise deedly woundes so sore smerte
His mantel ouer his hipes caste he
For no man sholde seen his pryuetee
And as he lay of dyyng in a traunce
And wiste verraily that deed was he
Of honestee yet hadde he remembraunce
Lucan to thee this storie I recomende
And to Sweton and to Valerius also
That of this storie writen word and ende
How that to thise grete Conquerours two
Fortune was first freend and siththe a foo
No man ne triste vp on hire fauour longe
But haue hire in awayt for euere mo
Witnesse on alle thise Conquerours stronge
This riche Cresus whilom kyng of Lyde
Of which Cresus Cirus soore hym dradde
Yet was he caught amyddes al his pryde
And to be brent men to the fyr hym ladde
But swich a reyn doun fro the welkne shadde
That slow the fyr and made hym to escape
But to be war no grace yet he hadde
Til Fortune on the galwes made hym gape
Whanne he escaped was he kan nat stente
For to bigynne a newe werre agayn
He wende wel for that Fortune hym sente
Swich hape that he escaped thurgh the rayn
That of his foos he myghte nat be slayn
And eek a sweuene vp on a nyght he mette
Of which he was so proud and eek so fayn
That in vengeance he al his herte sette
Vp on a tree he was as that hym thoughte
Ther Iuppiter hym wessh bothe bak and syde
And Phebus eek a fair towaille hym broughte
To drye hym with and therfore wax his pryde
And to his doghter that stood hym bisyde
Which that he knew in heigh sentence habounde
He bad hire telle hym what it signyfide
And she his dreem bigan right thus expounde
The tree quod she the galwes is to mene
And Iuppiter bitokneth snow and reyn
And Phebus with his towaille so clene
Tho been the sonnes stremes for to seyn
Thow shalt an hanged be fader certeyn
Reyn shal thee wasshe and sonne shal thee drye
Thus warned hym ful plat and ful pleyn
His doghter which that called was Phanye
An hanged was Cresus the proude kyng
His Roial trone myghte hym nat auaille
Tragedies noon oother manere thyng
Ne kan in syngyng crye ne biwaille
But that Fortune alwey wole assaille
With vnwar strook the regnes that been proude
For whan men trusteth hire thanne wol she faille
And couere hire brighte face with a clowde
hO qd the knight good sꝰer . nomor of þs
That ye haue seid / it is riȝt enough y wis
And mochel more / for litle heuynesse
Is right enough to mochel folke as I . gesse
I sey for me it is a greet disease
Wher as men haue ben in greet welth ⁊ ease
To here of their sodeyn falle alas
And when thei haue ben in gret estate
And clymben up and wexen fortunate
And there abiden in much prosꝑperite
Such thing is gladsum as þinkith me
And such thing were goodly forto telle
Ye qd oure host be seint poulis belle
Ye sey right soth this monk clappith loude
He spak houȝ fortune couꝰered with a cloude
I note ner what and also of tragedy
Right now ye herd / and parde no remedy
It nys forto bewaile ne compleyn
That tat is done / and als it is a peyn
As ye haue seid to heren of heuynesse
Sir monk no more of this so god you bles
Your tale anoyeth alle this cumpany
Such talking is not wurth a buttirflye
For theryn is no disporte ne game
Wherfor sir monk dan piers by yorur name
I pray you hertily telle us sumwhat ellis
For truly ner clynking of your bellis
That on your Bridle hangen on euꝰery side
By heuen king that for us alle dide
I shuld haue fallen doun for slepe
Al theigh the slough had be neuer so depe
Then had your tale be told in veyne
For certeynly as thees clerkis seyn
Where as a man may haue non audience
Nought helpith to tellen his sentence
And wele I woot the substaunce is in me
If eny thing shal wele reportid be
Sir sey sumwhat of hunting I you pꝰerye
Nay coth the monk I haue no lust to pley
Now lat anothir tellen as I haue tolde
Then spak oure host with rude spech ⁊ bolde
And seid to the Nonnes prest anone
Come nere sir prest come hidir sir Iohn
Telle us thing as may oure hertis glade
Be mery though thou ride upon a Iade
If he wil ꝸserue thee recke thee not a bene
Look that thine hert be mery euermoo
Yis host coth he so mote I ride or go
But I be mery y wis I wil be blamed
And riȝt anone he hath his tale attamed
And thus he seid to us euerichone
This swete prest this good man ꝸser Iohn

l.hi: ¶ The Nonnes prestis tale of the cokke
and the henne / Chauntcler and pertlot

div.l: A Pore widow sumdele stept in Age
Was whilom duelling in a narow cotage
Besidis a groue stonding in a dale
This widowe of whom I telle you my tale
Sith that day that she was last a wif
In pacience ladde a fulle simple lif
For litle was hir catelle and hir rent
But by husbondrie such as god hir sent
She found hir selue and eke hir douȝtꝰers two
Thre large Swyne had she and no moo
Thre kyne and eke a Shepe þt hiȝt Malle
Ful soty was hir boure and eke hir halle
In which she ete many a sclendre mele
Of poynant sauce she nedid neuer a dele
No deynte morcelle passid hir throte
Hir diete was accordant vnto hir cote
Repleciou ne made hir neuer seke
Attempre diete was alle hir phisike
With litle she toke hir sufficiaunce
The goute lettꝭes hir nothing to daunce
Ne poplexie ne shent not hir hede
Ne wine drank she neuer white ne rede
Hir bourd was ꝸserued most with white ⁊ blak
Milke and broun brede in which she fond no lak
Seynd bacou ⁊ sumtyme an egge or twey
For she was as it were in maner of a deye
A gardine hadde she enclosid all about
With Stickis / and a drie diche without
In which she had a Cocke þt hiȝt Chautcler
In al the lond of crowing nas his pere
His voice was merier þan þe mery Orgou
On the masse daies that in the church gone
Wel sicurer was the crowing in his loge
Then is a clocke or an Abbeyes Orlage
By nature he knewe eche ascencioūn
Of Equinoxiall in that Towne
For when xv. grees weren descendid
That knew he þat it might not be amendid
His Combe was redder then the fine corall
And bateild as it were A . Castel walle
Like Mure were his leggis and his tone
His Bille was blac as the gete stone
His nailis whittꝰer then the lili flour
And like burnissht gold was his colour
This ientle Cocke had in his gouꝰernauce
Vij . hennes / forto don him plesaunce
Which were his sustirs ⁊ his ꝑperamours
And wundir like to him as of colours
Of which the feirist hued vndir þe þrote
Was clepid feir damezell ꝐPertelote
Curteis she was discrete and debonayr
And cumpaynable and bare hirselue so fair
Sithen that day þtat she was . vij . niȝt olde
That truli she hath the hert in holde
Of Chauntcler loken in euery litth lith
He loued hir so þtat wel was hīn þꝰerwtith
But such a ioye it was to here hem sing
When þat the bright sonne began to spring
In swete accorde my leve is fare on lond
For that time as I haue vndirstond
Bestis and birdis couth speke ⁊ sing
And so bifelle that in the dawnyng
As Chauntcler among his wyues alle
Sate on his perche that was in the hall
And next him sate this feire ꝑpertelote
This Chauntcler gan grone in his þrote
As man that in his dreme was drechid sore
And when that Pertlot thus herd him rore
She was agast and seid hert dere
What ailith you to grone in this maner
Ye ben a very sleper fy for shame
And he ansuerd and seid þus madame
I pray you that ye take it not a grefe
Be god me mette þat I was in such mischef
That yit myn hert is sore affright
Now god qd he my sweuen he rede Ariȝt
And kepe my body out of foule prisou
Me dremed that I romed up and dou
Wtithyn our yerd / wher as I saugh a best
Was like an hounde ⁊ wold haue made arest
Vpon my bodi / and wold haue had me dede
His colour was betuyx white and rede
And tippid was his taile and boþe his eris
With blak vnlike the remaynant of his heris
His snoute smalle with glowing iyen twey
Yit for his loke for fere almost I deye
This causid me my gronyng doutles
Avoy qd she fy on you hertlesse
Alas qd she for by that god aboue
Now haue ye lost myn hert ⁊ al my loue
I can not loue a Coward be my feith
For certis what so eny woman seith
We all desiren if it might be so be
To haue husbondis hardy wise ⁊ fre
And secret and no negard ne no fole
Ne him that is agast of euery tole
Ne none Auauntour by that god aboue
Hough durst ye sey for shame vnto yorur loue
That eny thing might make you afferd
Haue ye no mannes hert and haue a berd
Alas and can ye be agast of Sweuens
Sweuens engendren of replecioūns
When humours ben to habundant in a wiȝt
Certis this dreme which ye haue had to nyȝt
Cometh of the greet superfluyte
Of your rede coler Sir parde
Which causith folk to dreme theyr dremes
Of Arrowis and of fires with rede lemes
Of rede Bestis that wille hem byte
Of contek and of whelpis gret and lite
Right as the humour of malencoly
Causith many men in slepe to crye
For fere of bestis and of Bullis blake
Or ellis blake deuels wil hem take
Of humours mo couth I telle also
That maken many men in slepe ful wo
But I wil pas as lightly as I can
Lo Catou that was so wise a man
Seith he not þus / ne yeue no fors of dremes
Now sir qd she when we fle fro þe bemes
For goddis loue takith sum laxative
Vp perile of my soule and of my live
I counsoil yow the best I wil not lye
But both of colre and of malencolye
Ye purge you / and for ye shul not tarye
Though that in this toun is none appoticary
I shal myselue two herbis techen you
That shalbe your helpꝰer and your prow
And in the gardine . ij . herbis shall I finde
Which haue of ꝓpropirte be their kynde
To purge you benethe and eke aboue
Forget not this for goddis owne loue
Ye ben fulle colorik of your complexiou
Be war that the Sonne in his ascenciou
Ne finde you replete of yorur humours hote
And if it so I dar wel leyen a grote
That ye shul haue a Fever terciane
Or an Ague that may be your bane
A day or two ye shul haue digestiues
Of wormes / or ye take your laxatiues
Of lauriol Centaury and of fimitere
Or ellis of Elbor that growith ther
Of Catapuce or of Gaytis beryes
Of herbe yve growing in our gardine þꝰer mery is
Pike hem upright as thei grow ⁊ ete hem yn
Be mery husbond by youre fadir kynne
Dredith no dreme I can sey you no more
Madame coth he gramercy of your lore
But natheles as touching daun Catou
That hath of wisdom such gret renou
Be god men mai in olde bokis rede
One of the gretist Auctor out of drede
Of many a man more auctorite
Then euer Catou was so mot I the
That alle the reuerce seyn of þis sentēmce
And wel founden by experience
That Dremes ben significacioūns
As wele of ioye as of tribulacioūns
That folk enduren in this life present
Ther nedith not to make this an argumēmt
The veray preef shewith it in dede
As one of the gretist Auctor out of drede
¶ Seith thus þat whilom two felows wēmt
On pilgrimage in fulle good intent
And happid so thei come into a toun
Where as ther was such congregaciou
Of peple and of streite herburgage
That thei found not as moch as a cotage
In which thei bothe might y logid be
Wherfore thei musten of gret necessite
As for that nyght depart of cumpanye
And eche of hem goth into his hostry
And toke his logging as it wold falle
That one of hem was loggid in a Stall
Ferre in a yerd / with Oxen of the plough
That othir man was loggid wel ynough
As was his auenture and his fortune
That us alle gouꝰerneth as in comune
And so bifell long ere it were day
This one mette in his bedde þerꝰer as he lay
Hough that his felow gan on him calle
And seid alas for in an Oxe Stalle
This nyght shal I be morthird þer I lye
Now help me dere brothir or I dye
In alle hast come to me he seid
This man out of his slepe for fer abreyd
But when that he was wakend out of slepe
He turned him and toke of this no kepe
Hym thought his dreme was not but vanite
Thus twice in his sleping dremed he
And at third time yit his felawe
Com as him þouȝt lo I am now slawe
Behold my blody woundis depe and wide
Arise up erly in the morou tide
And at westgate of the town qd he
A Cartfulle of dunge ther shaltou se
In which my body is hidde fulle piriuely
Do thilk Cart arresten boldily
My gold causid my mordre soth to seyn
And told him euery point hough he was slayn
With a fulle pitous face pale of hue
And trustiþ wele his dreme he found ful true
For on the morn as sone as it was day
To his felaws Inne he toke the way
And when he come vnto this Ox stalle
Aftir his felau he gan to calle
The hostiller ansuerd him anon
¶ ⁊ seid ꝸser yorur felow is gon
As sone as day he went out of tou
This man gan falle in gret suspeciou
Remembring on his dremes þtat he mette
And furth he goth no lenger wold he lett
Vnto the westgate of the tovn ⁊ fond
A dung cart as he went to dunge lond
That was y caried in the same wise
As ye haue herd the deedman diuise
And with an hardi hert he gan to crie
Vengeaunce ⁊ iustice upon this felonye
My felow mordird is this same night
And in this Cart he lith gaping upriȝt
The deedman that murthird was al new
O . blissfull god that art so iust and true
Lo houȝ thou bewreyest murthir alway
Murthir wille out that sene we day be day
Murthir is so wraþsum ⁊ so abhominable
To god that is so iust and resonable
That he ne wold it suffre y hidde to be
Though it abide a yere or two or thre
Murthir wille out this is my conclusioūn
And right anon ministirs of the towne
Haue hent the carter ⁊ him sore peyned
And eke the hostiller so sore constreined
Þat they confesse their wickidnes anone
And weren y hongid by the necke bone
Her mai men se þtat dremes ben to drede
And certis in the same boke I rede
Right in the next chapitꝰer I rede of þis
I gabbe not so haue I ioye or blis
Two men þat wold haue passid þe See
For certeyn cause into ferre cuntree
If that the winde ne had ben contrary
Þat made hem in a Citee forto tary
Þat stood fulle mery upon an hauen side
But on a day ayens the Euen tyde
The winde gan chaunge ⁊ blue as hi lest
Iolif and glad thei went vnto rest
And cast hem full erly forto seile
But herkne houȝ that one fil in gret ꝑpereil
That one of hem in sleping as he lay
Him mette a wundir dreme ayens þe day
Him þouȝt a man stood by his bedde side
⁊ him comaundid that he shuld abide
⁊ seid him thus if thou to morou wende
Thou shalt be drowned / my tale is at an ende
He woke and told his felow what he mett
And preid his his viage forto lette
As for that day he praid him to abide
His felau that lay by his bedde side
Gan forto laugh and scorned him ful fast
No dreme qd he mai myn hert agast
Þat I wille lette forto do my thingis
I sett not a Strawe by dremynges
For dremes ben vanitees and iapes
Men dreme alday of Owles and of Apes
And of many a maze therwithall
Men dreme of thingis þtat neuer was ne shall
But sith I se that þou wilt here abide
And thus forslouth wilfully thy tide
God woot it rueth me ⁊ haue good day
And thus he took his leue and went his way
And or that he hadde halue his course y seilid
I note why ne what mischaunce it eylid
But casuelli the Shippis bothum rent
And Shippe ⁊ man vndir the watir went
In sight of othir Shippis him beside
That with him sailid the same tide
And therfore he seid pertlot so dere
By such ensamples olde maistow lere
Þat many a dreme full sore is forto drede
Lo in the lif of seint kenelme I rede
Þat was kenulfis sonne the noble king
Of Metenrike / hough kenelme mett a þing
Alitle or he was murthrid on a day
His murthre in his auisiou he say
His Norice him expowned euerydele
His dreme / ⁊ bad him forto kepe him wele
From tresou / but he was but vij . yer olde
And therfore litle tale hath he told
Of any dreme / so holy was his hert
Be god I had leuer then my Shert
That ye had herd his legende as haue I
Dame pertlot I sey you certeinly
Macrobeus that wrote the auisiou
In Aufrik of the wurthi Ciprioūn
Affermeth dremes ⁊ seith þtat thei ben
Warnyng of thingis þtat men aftir sene
And furthirmor I pray you lokith well
The olde Testament of Daniell
If he hold dremes of any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and ye shullen se
Whethir dremes be sumtime I sey not all
Warnyng of thingis that shalle aftir falle
Look eke of Egipt the kyng Pharao
And his Baker and his Botiller also
Wher thei ne felt effect in dremes
Whoso wil seche the acte of sundry Remes
May rede of dremes many a wundre þing
Lo Cresus which that was of lyde king
Mette he not that he sate upon a tre
Which signified that he shuld anhangid be
Lo her Adromata Ectoris wife
That day that Ector shuld lete his lif
She dremed on the same nyght beforn
Hough the that the lif of Ector shuld be lorn
If that day he went into bataile
She warned him but it might not auaile
He went forto fight neuer the les
And ther he was slaine of Achilles
But that tale is alle to long to telle
And eke the time passith I mai not duelle
Shortly I seye as for my conclusiou
That I shal haue of this auisiou
Aduersite and I seye furthirmore
That I ne telle of laxatiues no store
For thei ben venemous I wote riȝt wele
I hem defy I loue hem neuer a dele
¶ Now lat us speke of mirth ⁊ stint al þs
Madame Pertlot so haue I ioye or blis
Of one thing god hath sent me large grace
For when I se the beaute of your face
Ye ben so scarlet rede about your iyen
It makith alle my drede forto dyen
For al so sicur as in Pricipio
Madame the sentence of this latine is
Woman is mannes ioye ⁊ mannes blis
For when I fele on nyght your soft side
Al be it that I mai not on you ride
For that oure perch is made so narow alas
I am so fulle of ioye and of solace
That I defye both sweuen ⁊ dreme
And with that wurd he fligh dou fro þe beme
For it was day / and eke his hennes alle
And with a chucke he gan hem forto calle
For he had founde a corn lay in the yerd
Roial he was he was no more afferd
He fetherid Pertlot twenty tyme
And trode as often or it wer fulli pirime
He lokith as it were a grymme leoūn
And on his toes he rometh up and doūn
Him deigned not to sette his fete on to grounde
Ay chukkid he when he a corne had founde
And to him then renneth his wivis alle
Thus roial as a prince in his halle
Leve I this Chauntcler in his pastur
And aftir wille I telle of his aduentur
¶Whan the Moneth in which the world began
That hiȝt Marche when god first made man
Was complete and passid were also
Sith March began thirti daies and two
Befille that Chauntcler in his pride
His seuen wyues walking be his side
Cast up his eyen to the bright Sonne
That in the signe of Taurus was y ronne
Thirti degrees and one ⁊ sum what more
He knew be kinde and by none othir lore
That it was pirime he knew the blisful steuen
The Sonne he saw was clumben upon þe heuen
Fourti degrees ⁊ one and more y wisse
Madame Pertlot my worldis blisse
Herken hough thees blisful birdis sing
And se the fressh flouris houȝ thei spring
Fulle is myn hert of reuell and of solace
But sodenly him fille a soroufull case
For euer the latter ende of ioye is sone ago
And comunely oftetime it fallith so
A cole fox fulle of sleight and of iniquite
That in the groue hadde woned yeris thre
By high ymaginaciou aforn cast
The same nyght thurgh the hegge he brast
Into the yerd ther Chauntcler the feir
Was wont with his wyues forto repeir
And in a bedde of wurtis stille he lay
Til it was past vndirn of the day
Waiting his time of Chauntcler to fall
As gladli done these homicides alle
That in await lyen to mordir men
O . fals mordrer roukyng in thy denne
O . new Scarioth and new Genilou
Fals dissimilour . O . greke Simon
That brought Troy alle vttirly to sorou
O Chauntclere accursid be that morow
That thou into the yerd fligh fro þe bemes
Thou were fulle wel y warned be thi dremes
That thilk day was ꝑperilous to thee
But that god aforn wotꝭes mut nedis be
Aftir the oppiniou of certeyn clerkis
Wittnesse on him that eny clerk is
That in Scole in greet altꝰercacioūn
In this matier and gret disputaciou
And hath ben of an hundrith þousand men
But I ne can not bult it to the brenne
As can the holy auctor Augustine
Or Boice or the busshop Bradwardine
Whethir that goddis wille aforn witing
Streyneth men nedly forto do a thing
Nedly clepe I simple necessite
Or ellis if the fre choice be graūntid me
To do that same thing or do it nouȝt
Thouȝ god forwoot it or it was wrouȝt
Or of his witing streyneth neuꝰer a dele
But by necessite Condicionell
I wil not haue to don of such matier
My tale is of a Cocke as ye shull her
That took his couseyl of his wif wtith sorow
To walk in the yerd on the morow
That he had mette his dreme þat I you told
Womens counseil ben ful often cold
Womans counseil brought us first to wo
And made Adam from Paradise to go
Ther as he was ful mery and wel at ease
But for I note whom I myght displeas
If I counseil of women wold blame
Passe ouꝰer for I seid it in my game
Rede Auctours wher they trete of such mater
And what they sey of women ye may here
Thees ben the Cockis wurdis ⁊ not myne
I can none harme of no women diuine
¶ Feir in the Sonde to bathe hir merily
Hath dame ꝑpertilot and hir sustirs . by
Ageyn the Sūnne / and Chauntcler so fre
Sang meryer then the Mermayd in þe see
For Phisialogus seith fulle wittirly
Hough that thei singen fulle merily
And so bifelle as he kest his iye
Among the wurtis upon a Buttirfly
He was ware of this Fox þat lay ful low
Nothing ne lust him then forto crow
But cried anon coc coc and up he stert
As man that is affraied in his hert
For naturaly a best desirith forto fle
From his contrarie if he mai it se
Though he had neuer sene it erst wtith hs iye
This Chauntcler when he him gan espye
He wold haue fled / but that the fox anone
Seid gentle sir alas / what wil ye done
Ben ye affraied of me that am your frend
Certis sir then be ye vnhende
If I to you wil harme or vilanye
I am not come your counseil to aspye
But truly the cause of my comyng
Was onli to herken hough þat ye sing
For truli ye haue as mery a steuen
As eny aungel hath þat is in heuen
Therwith ye haue in music more feling
Then had Boice or eny þtat couth sing
My lord your fadir god his soule blesse
And eke your modir of hir gentilnesse
Haue in myn hous y be to their gret ease
And certis sir / right same wold I you pleas
But for men speken of singing I wil sey
So mut I brouke myne iyen tweye
Saue ye I herd neuer man so syng
As didde your fadir in the mornyng
Certis it was of hert alle that he song
And forto make his voice the more strong
He wold so peine him þat wtith both his iyen
He must winke so loude he didde crien
And stond upon his tiptoos therwithall
And strecch furth his necke long ⁊ smalle
And eke he was of such discrecioūn
That ther nas noman in no regiou
That him in song or wisdom miȝt passe
I haue welle redde Dame Burnel at Nasse
Among his versis / that ther was a Cocke
For a prestis sonne yaue him a cnocke
Vpon his legge / while he was yong ⁊ nyce
He made him forto lese his benefice
But certeyn ther is no comparisou
Betuyx the wisdom and the discrecioūn
Of your fadir and of his subtilite
Now singith sir for seint Charite
Lat se can ye your fadir countirfete
This Chauntclere his wingis can to bete
As man that couth not his tresou aspie
So was he rauysshid with his flaterie
¶ Alas ye lordis many a fals flaterer
Is in your court / and many a lozenger
That pleas you wel more be my feith
Than he that sothfastnes vnto you seith
Redith Ecclesiastꝭes of such flaterie
Bewar ye lordis of their trecherie
This Chauntclere stood high upon hs toos
Strecching his necke and held his iyen cloos
And gan to crow loude for the nones
And daun Russel start up alle attones
And by the gargage hent Chauntclere
And on his backe toward the wood him bere
For yit was ther noman that his sued
O . destine that maist not be eschued
Alas that Chauntclere fille fro the bemes
Alas his wyue ne rought not of dremes
And on a friday fille alle this mischauce
O . venus that art goddesse of plesaunce
Sithen that thy ꝸseruaunt was þis chautcler
And in thy ꝸseruice didde alle his power
More for delite then the world to multiplie
Why woldistou suffre him on thi daie to dye
O . Gaufride dere maistir souereyn
That when the wurthy king Richard was slayn
With shotte compleindist his deth so sore
Why ne hadde I now thi sentence ⁊ thi lore
The friday forto chide as didden ye
For on a friday shortly slayn was he
Than wold I shew hough þtat I couth pleyn
For Chauntclers life and for his peyne
Certis such crye ne lamentaciou
Ne was of ladyes made when þtat / Iliou
Was wonne / and pirrus wtith his streiȝt swerd
Had hent king Pryam by the berd
And slough him as seith Enydose
As made alle the hennes in the close
When they had sene of Chauntcler a siȝt
But souereyn dame Pertlot shright
Well ludder then didde husdribaldis wif
When that hir husbond had lost his lif
And that the Romaines had hent Cartage
She was so fulle of torment and of rage
That wilfully into the fire she stert
And brent hirselue with a stedfast hert
O . wofull hennes right so criden ye
And when that Nero brent the cite
Of Rome / criden the Senatours wyues
For that her husbondis shuld lese her lyues
Withouten gilt Nero hath hem sleyn
Now wille I turne to my tale ageyn
¶ This cely widow and his doughtirs two
Herd the hennes crye and make wo
And out at doris sterten thei anone
And saugh the fox toward the groue gon
And bare upon his backe the Cocke awey
And criden out harow and welawey
A . ha . the fox . and aftir him they ranne
And eke with stavis many anothir man
Ran Colle oure dogge and talbot ⁊ garlond
And malkyn with hir distave in hir hand
Ran Cowe and Calue and eke the veray hoggꝭes
Sore afferd for barking of the doggis
And shouting of men and women eke
They ran so their hert they thouȝt to breke
They yelden as fendis done in helle
The doggis criden as men wold hem quelle
Out of the hyvis come the swarm of Bees
The gese for fere flighen into trees
So hidous was the noyse / a benedicite
Certis he Iacke Strawe and his meynee
Ne maden neuer shoutis halue so shrille
When that thei wolden eny flemyng kille
As that day was made upon the Foxe
Of bras thei brought bemes and of box
Of horn and bone in which thei popid
And therwithall thei strikid and þei houpid
It semed as the heuen shuld haue falle
Now good men I prey you herkneth alle
Lo hough fortune turneth sodeinly
The hope and the pride of hir enemy
This Cocke that lay upon the foxis bak
In alle his drede vnto the fox he spak
And seid sir if I were as she ye
Yit shuld I sey as wis god help me
Turn ayen ye proude chorlis alle
A veray pestilence upon you falle
Now am I come vnto this wood side
Maugre your hedis the Cocke shal her abide
I wille him ete and that anone
The fox answerd in feith it shal be don
And as he spak that wurd alle sodenly
This Cocke brak from his mouth delyuꝰerly
And high upon a tre he fligh anone
And when the fox saugh that he was gon
Alas coth he O chauntcler alas
I haue coth he done to you trespas
In as much as I made you afferde
When I you hent ⁊ brought out of the yerd
But sir I did it in no wickid intent
Cometh doun and I shal telle you what I mēmt
I shalle sey soth god help me so
Nay then coth he I shrew us both two
And first I shrew myselue both blood ⁊ bones
If thou begile me ofter then ones
Thou shalt no more with thy flatery
Do me sing and winke with myn iye
For he that winkith when he shuld se
As wisly god lat him neuer thee
Nay god yeue hym a myschaunce
That is so vndistrete of gouernaunce
That ianglith when he shuld hold his peas
Lo such it is forto be rechelese
And necligent and trust on flatery
But ye that hold this for a foly
As of a fox and of a Cok and of an henne
Takith the moralite ye good men
For seint poule seith al that writen is
To oure doctrine it is writen y wis
Takith the frute and lat the chaf be still
Now good god if that it be thy wille
As saith my lord / god make us al good men
And bring us alle to his high blisse / Amen
