div.l: (base) And that oure hoost wole of his curteisye
(base) I wole as now excuse thee of thy tale
(base) For in good feith thy visage is ful pale
(base) Thyne eyen daswen eek as that me thynketh
(base) And wel I woot thy breth ful soure stynketh
(base) That sheweth wel thow art nat wel disposed
(base) Of me certeyn thow shalt nat ben yglosed
(base) Se how he ganeth lo this dronken wight
(base) As though he wolde swolwe vs anon right
(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man by thy fader kyn
(base) The deuel of helle sette his foot ther yn
(base) Thy cursed breeth infecte wol vs alle
(base) Fy stynkynge swyn fy foule mote thee falle
(base) A taketh hede sires of this lusty man
(base) Now swete sire wol ye Iusten atte Fan
(base) Ther to me thynketh ye ben wel yshape
(base) I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a straw
(base) And with his speche the Cook wax wroth and wraw
(base) And on the Manciple bigan he nodde faste
(base) For lakke of speche and doun the hors hym caste
(base) Wher as he lay til that men vp hym took
(base) This was a fair chyuachee of a Cook
(base) Allas he nadde yholde hym by his ladel
(base) And er that he agayn were in his Sadel
(base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro
(base) To lifte hym vp and muchel care and wo
(base) So vnweldy was this sory palled goost
(base) And to the Manciple thanne spak oure hoost
(base) By cause drynke hath domynacioun
(base) Vpon this man by my sauacioun
(base) I trowe he lewedly telle wolde his tale
(base) For were it wyn or old or moisty Ale
(base) That he hath dronke he speketh in his nose
(base) And fneseth faste and eek he hath the pose
(base) He hath also to do moore than ynow
(base) To kepen hym and his capil out of the Slow
(base) And if he falle from his capil eft soone
(base) Than shal we alle haue ynow to doone
(base) In liftynge vp his heuy dronken cors
(base) Telle on thy tale of hym make I no fors

div.l: (base) But yet Manciple in feith thow art to nyce
(base) Thus openly repreue hym of his vice
(base) Another day he wole par auenture
(base) Reclayme thee and brynge thee to lure
(base) I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
(base) As for to pynchen at thy rekenynges
(base) That were nat honeste if it cam to preef
(base) No quod the Manciple that were a gret mescheef
(base) So myghte he lightly brynge me in the snare
(base) Yet hadde I leuere payen for the Mare
(base) Which he rit on than he sholde with me stryue
(base) I wol nat wrathe hym also mote I thryue
(base) That that I spak I seyde it in my bourde
(base) And wite what I haue here in a gourde
(base) A draughte of wyn ye of a rype grape
(base) And right anon ye shul seen a good Iape
(base) This Cook shal drynke ther of if I may
(base) Vp peyne of deeth he wol nat seye me nay
(base) And certeynly to tellen as it was
(base) Of this vessel the Cook drank faste allas
(base) What neded it he drank ynow biforn
(base) And whan he hadde powped in this horn
(base) To the Manciple he took the gourde agayn
(base) And of that drynke the Cook was wonder fayn
(base) And thanked hym in swich wise as he kowde
(base) Thanne gan oure hoost to laughen wonder lowde
(base) And seyde I se wel it is necessarie
(base) Where that we goon good drynke we with vs carye
(base) For that wol turne rancour and disese
(base) Tacord and loue a many a wrong appese
(base) O Bacus yblessed be thy name
(base) That so kanst turnen ernest in to game
(base) Worship and thank be to thy deitee
(base) Of that matere ye gete namoore for me
(base) Telle on thy Manciple I the preye
(base) Wel sir quod he now herkneth what I seye
(base) Here bigynneth the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the mooste lusty bachiler
(base) In al this world and eek the beste Archer

div.l: (base) He slow Phitoun the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge agayn the sonne vpon a day
(base) And many another noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wroghte as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he koude on euery Mynstralcye
(base) And syngen that it was a melodye
(base) To heren of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kyng of Thebes Amphioun
(base) That with his syngyng walled that Citee
(base) Koude neuere syngen half so wel as he
(base) Ther to he was the semelieste man
(base) That is or was sith that the world bigan
(base) What nedeth it hise fetures to discryue
(base) For in this world was noon so fair on lyue
(base) He was therwith fulfild of gentillesse
(base) Of honour and of parfit worthynesse
(base) This Phebus that was flour of Bachelrye
(base) As wel in fredom as in Chiualrye
(base) For his desport in signe eek of victorie
(base) Of Phitoun so as telleth vs the storie
(base) Was wont to beren in his hand a bowe
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a Crowe
(base) Which in a Cage he fostred many a day
(base) And taughte it speke as men teche a Iay
(base) Whit was this Crowe as is a Snow whit swan
(base) And contrefete the speche of euery man
(base) He kowde whan he sholde telle a tale
(base) Ther with in al this world no nyghtyngale
(base) Beter syngen þan eny nyȝtyngale
(base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel
(base) Syngen so wonder myrily and weel
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
(base) Which that he louede moore than his lyf
(base) And nyght and day dide euere his diligence
(base) Hire for to plese and doon hire reuerence
(base) Saue oonly that the sothe if I shal sayn
(base) Ialous he was and wolde han kept hire fayn
(base) For hym were looth byiaped for to be
(base) And so is euery wight in swich degree
(base) But al for naught for it auaileth noght
(base) A good wyf that is clene in werk and thoght
(base) Sholde nat be kept in noon awayt certayn
(base) And trewely the labour is in vayn

div.l: (base) To kepe a shrewe .for it wol nat be
(base) This holde I for a verray nycetee
(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues
(base) Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyues
(base) But now to purpos as I first bigan
(base) This worthy Phebus dooth al that he kan
(base) To plesen hire wenynge for swich plesaunce
(base) And for his manhode and his gouernaunce
(base) That no man sholde han put hym from hire grace
(base) But god it woot ther may no man embrace
(base) As to destreyne a thyng which that nature
(base) Hath naturelly set in a creature
(base) Take any bryd and put it in a Cage
(base) And do al thyn entente and thy corage
(base) To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke
(base) Of alle deyntees that thow kanst bithynke
(base) And kepe it also clenly as thow may
(base) Although his Cage of gold be neuer so gay
(base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold
(base) Leuere in a Forest that is rude and cold
(base) Gon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse
(base) For euere this bryd wol doon his bisynesse
(base) To eschape out of his Cage if he may
(base) His libertee this bryd desireth ay
(base) Lat take a Cat and fostre hym wel with Milk
(base) And tendre flessh and make his couche of silk
(base) And lat hym seen a Mous go by the wal
(base) Anon he weyueth Milk and flessh and al
(base) And euery deyntee that is in that hous
(base) Swich appetit hath he to ete a Mous
(base) Lo heere hath lust his domynacioun
(base) And appetit flemeth discrecioun
(base) A she wolf hath also a vileyns kynde
(base) The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde
(base) And leest of reputacioun that wol she take

l.hi: ¶ Here begynneth the ꝓprolog of þe ꝑpersons tale

div.l: BE that the Maunciple had hs tale endid
The Sonne fro the Southside is discēmdid
So low that he nas not to my sight
Degrees nyne and twenty as of hight
Tenne of the clokke it was as I gesse
For xj . fote a litle more or lesse
My shadow was as thilk time of the yer
Of such fete as my length ꝑpertid were
In vj . fete equall of proporciou
And therwith the Mones exaltaciou
I . mene libra alwey gan ascende
As we were entring at a Thorpis ende
Furthwith oure host as he was wont to gye
As in this case oure ioly cumpany
Seid in this wise / lordingis euerichon
Now lackith us no tale more then one
Fulfillid is my sentence ⁊ my decree
Who wil now telle a . tale lat se
Almost fulfillid is myn ordinaunce
I . pray to god yeue him right good chauce
That tellith this tale to us lustily
Sir prest coth he artow a vicary
Or artou parsou sey soth by thi fey
And bewar thou breke not oure pley
For euery man saue thou haþ told his tale
Vnbocle and shew us what is in thi male
For truly me thinkith be thi cher
Thou shuldist knytte up wel a gret matier
Telle me a . fable anone for cockis bones
This Parsou ansuerd him alle attones
Thou getist fable none y told for me
For Poul that writith vnto Tymothee
Repreueth hem that leven sothfastnesse
And tellen fables and such wrecchidnesse
Why shuld I . shewen draff out of my fist
When I . may shewen whete if that me list
For which I . sey if that thou list to here
Moralite and othir vertuouse matier
And then that ye wil yeue me audience
I . wille right faine at Cristis reuꝰerence
Do you plesaunce lefull as I . can
But trustith wel I . am a Southirn man
I . can not ieste vn ram ruf by letter
Ne god wote ryme hold I . but litle bettꝰer
And therfore if you list I . wille not glose
I . wille you telle a mery tale in ꝓprose
To knyt up al this fest ⁊ make an ende
And Ihu for his grace wilte me sende
To shew you the wey in this viage
Of thilk most parfit pilgremage
That hight Ierusalem celestialle
And if that ye vouchesaue anon I . shall
Begynne upon my tale / for which I prey
Telle your auise I . can no bettir sey
But neuer the lesse this meditaciou
I . putte it ay vndir the correcciou
Of Clerkis / for I . am not textid wele
I . take but the sentence trustith wele
Wherfore I . make a protestaciou
That I wille stond vnto correcciou
Vpoūn this wurd we haue assentid sone
For as it semed it was forto done
To ende in sum vertuous sentence
And forto yeue hym space ⁊ audience
We badde oure host he shuld to him sey
That alle we to telle his tale him prey
Oure host had the wurdis for us alle
Sir prest coth he now feir mot you falle
Seyth what you list and we shul goodly her
And with that wurd he seid in this maner
Tellith coth he youre meditaciou
But hastith you the Sūnne wille a dou
Beth fructuous and that in litle space
And to do wele god send you his grace

div.ab:
¶ State suꝑper vias ⁊ videte et interrogate de semitꝭes
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et
inuenietis refrigeriūn animabus vestris / ⁊ cꝰer Ier . 6o

oure swete lord god of heuen þtat noman wil
perissh / but wille þat we come alll to þe
knowlech of him ⁊ to the blisful lif þat
is ꝑperdurable

Amonestith us by the ꝓprophete Ieremye
þat seith in this wise /

Stondith upon the weyes
and seeth and axith of old pathis þat is to seyn of
old sentences which is the good wey

and ye shulle
finde refresshinge for your soulis

¶ Many ben þe weyes spirals that leden folk to oure lord god ⁊ to
þe ream of glorie /

Of which weyes ther is a full
noble wey ⁊ a ful couenable which mai not fayle
to man ne to woman þtat þurgh synne haþ misgone
from the right wey of Ierusalem celestiall /

⁊ this
wey is clepid Penitence / Of which men shuld gladli
enquere ⁊ herken with al her hert

to witt what is
penaunce ⁊ whens it is clepid penitence / and i houȝ
many maners ben þe accions or wurching of penitece

And hou many spicis þꝰer ben of penitence / And which
þingꝭes apꝑperteyn ⁊ behoue to penitence / And which þingꝭes
disturben penitence

¶ Seint Ambrose seiþ þat penitence is a pleynyng of man for þe gilt that he
hath don ⁊ purposith no more to do eny thing for þe
which him ouȝt to pleyn /

And sum Auctor seiþ þtat
penitence is þe weymenting of man þtat sorowiþ for
his synne ⁊ peyneth himselue for he haþ mysdone

Penitence with certeyn circumstancꝭes is veraye
repentaunce of man þtat holdith himselue in sorow
⁊ doth peine for his giltis /

And for he shal be vꝰeraye
penitent he shal first bewaile þe synnes þtat he haþ
done / and stedfastli purpos in his hert to haue shrift
of mouth ⁊ to do satisfaccion /

⁊ neuꝰer to do þing for
which him ouȝt more to bewayle or to compleyn / ⁊
to continue in good werkis / or ellis his repentance
mai not auayle /

for as seith Seint Ysydre / he is a
Iaper and a gabber ⁊ no vꝰerray repentant þtat eft sone
doþ þing for which him ouȝt to repent /

Wepyng /
and nat forto stint to do synne may not auayle /

but
neuꝰertheles men shulden hoop þtat at euery time þat a
man fallith be it neuꝰer so often / þtat he may aryse þurgh
penitence if he haue grace / but certeinli it is greet
deyute /

for as seiþ Seint Gregorie vnneþe arisiþ he
out of his synne þtat is chargid wtith þe charge of euel
vsage /

And þꝰerfore repentant folk þtat stinten forto
synne ⁊ forlete synne ere þtat synne forlete hem
holichurch holdith hem sicur of their sauacion

And he þtat synneth ⁊ vꝰerraili repentiþ him in hs last
holichurch yit hopith his saluacion bi þe gret mꝰercy
of oure lord / but takith the sicur wey /

¶ Now
sith I haue declarid you what þing is penitence / now
shul ye vndirstond þtat ther ben .iij. Accions of peni
tence /

The first is / if þtat a man be baptizid aftꝰer þtat
he haþ synned /

Seint Austine seiþ but he be peni
tent for his old sinful lyf he mai not begyn þe new
clene lif /

for certis if he be baptizid wiþout peni
tence of his old gilt he receyueþ þe mark of bap
tym but not þe grace ne þe remission of his synnes
til he haue repentaunce vꝰerraily

Anoþꝰer defaut is
þis / þtat men don deedli synne aftꝰer þtat thei haue recey
ued the baptym /

The þird defaut is þtat men falle
in venial synnes aftꝰer her baptym from day to day

þꝰerof seiþ Seint Austine / þtat penitence of good ⁊ humble
folk is as the penitence of euery day

¶ The tres
pace of penitence ben .iij / That one of hem is so
lempne / Anoþꝰer is comune / The third is pryuee

¶
Thilk penitence þtat is solempne is in . two maners
One is to be putt out of holichurch in lent for the
slauȝtꝰer of childirn ⁊ of such manꝰer þingis /

Anoþir
is when man haþ synned openli / of which synne
þe fame is openli spoken in þe cuntre / ⁊ þen holi
church bi iugement constreineþ him to do openli
penaunce /

Comune penaunce is þtat prestis enioyn
men commenli in certeyn case / as forto gone ꝑpera
uenture nakid in pilgrimage or barfoot /

Pryue
penaunce is þat men don alday for pryue synnes
of which we shryuen us piriuely ⁊ receyue pryue
penance

¶ Now shul ye vndirstond what be
houeþ ⁊ is necessary to vꝰerray ꝑperfit penitence and
þis stant on iij. þingis /

Contricion of hert Con
fession of Mouth and Satisfaccion /

for which
seith Seint Iohn Grisostom9 Penitence distreineþ
A man to accept benyngli euꝰery peyn þtat him is ēmioyned
wtith contricion of hert and shrift of Mouth and wtith
satisfaccion / ⁊ in werking of al manꝰer humilite /

⁊
þis is frutefull penitence ageyn .iij. þingis in þe
which we wratth our lord god /

þis is to seyn by
þe delite in thinking By recchillenes in spekyng
And bi wickid sinfull wirking /

And ageyn thees
wickid giltis is penitence / þtat mai be likned to a tre

And þe rote of þis tre is contricion þtat hidith hym
in þe hert of him þtat is vꝰerray repentant Riȝt as the
rote of a tre hidith him in the erþe /

Of þe rote of
contricion springiþ a stalk þtat berith braunchis ⁊
leues of confession and frute of satisfaccion

for
which crist seiþ in his gospel þtat doþ digne frute
of penaunce / for bi þis frute mai men know this
tree ⁊ nat bi þe rote þtat is hidde in þe hert of man
ne bi þe braunchis ne þe leues of Confession /

þꝰerfor
Crist seiþ þus / By þe frute of theym shul ye know
theym /

Of this rote eke springiþ a Sede of garace
the which Sede is modir of Sicurnesse / And þs Sede
and hiȝt the grace of god

This sede spiringiþ of
god þurgh the remembrance on the dai of dome ⁊
on the peines of helle

Of þis matier seiþ Sala
mon þtat in þe drede of god man forletiþ synne /

þe
hete of this sede is þe loue of god ⁊ þe desiring of
þe Ioy ꝑperdurable /

þis hete drawiþ þe hert of man
to god ⁊ makith him hate his synne /

for soþli þꝰer is
no þing þat sauourþ so wel to a child as þe mylk
of his norice / ne no þing is to him more abhoiable
þen þtat milke when it is medlid wtith oþꝰer mete /

Riȝt so
þe man þtat loueþ his synne him semeþ it is to him
most suete of eny þing /

But for þtat time þat he
loueþ sadly oure lord god ⁊ desirith the lif ꝑperdurable
þꝰer is to him no þing more abhominable /

for soþely
þe lawe of god is the loue of god / As þe ꝓprophete Da
uid seiþ / ¶ I haue loued thi lawe ⁊ hatid wickidnesse /

This tree sau saw the ꝓprophete Daniel in Spirit vp
on þe vision of Nabugodonor when he counseild
him to do penitence /

Penitence is þe tree of lif to
hem þtat it receyuen And he þtat holdiþ him in vꝰerray pe
nitence is blissid aftꝰer þe Sentence of Salamon /

In
þis penitence man shal vndirstond .iiij. þingis þtat is to
seyn what is contricion / And which ben þe causis þat
moven a man to contricion / And houȝ he shuld be
contrite And what contricion auailiþ to þe soule /

Than is it þus þtat contricion is þe vꝰerray sorou þtat ma
receyueþ in his hert for his synnes wtith sadde pur
pos to shryue him ⁊ to do fulle penance ⁊ neuꝰer more
to do synne /

And þis sorou shal be in þis maner as
seith Seint Bernard / It shal be heuy ⁊ greuous and
ful hard penance in hert /

first for a man haþ agilt
his lord ⁊ his Creatour / ⁊ more sharper ⁊ peynant
for he haþ agilt his fadir celestiall /

And yit mor sharp
⁊ peynant for he haþ wrathid him ⁊ agilt him þat
bought him ⁊ wtith his pꝰercious blood delyuꝰered him fro þe
bondis of synne ⁊ fro þe cruelte of the deuell ⁊ fro
the peynes of helle

¶ The causis þtat aught to
move a man to contricion ben //vj ffirst a manne
shal remembre him of his synnes /

but loke þtat þilk
remembraunce be to him no delite but gret shame
and sorou for his gilt for Iob seiþ / Synful men do
werkis wurthi of confession /

And therfor seiþ Ezechie
.I. wil remembre me all þe yeris of my lif in bittꝰer
nesse of myn hert /

And god seiþ in thapocalips / re
membreþ you from whens þtat ye ben falle / for befor
þtat time þtat ye synned ye were þe children of god ⁊
lymmes of þe ream of god /

but for your synne ye be
woxen thralle ⁊ foul and membres of þe deuel / hate of
Aungels / Sclaundre of holichurch / ⁊ food of þe fals
ꝸserpent ꝑperpetual matier of þe fire of helle /

And yitt
more foul ⁊ abhominable / for yei trespacen so oftyme
as doþ the hound þtat returneþ to ete his spuyng

And yit be ye fouler for your long continuyng i syn
⁊ your sinful usage / for which ye ben roten in yorur
synne as a beste in his dunge /

Such manꝰer of doutꝭes
maken a man haue shame of his synne ⁊ no delite
as god seiþ bi þe ꝓprophete Ezechie /

ye shul remembr
you of your weyes ⁊ thei shullen displeas you soþli
synnes ben the weyes þtat leden folc to helle

¶ Þe
secunde cause þtat ouȝt to make a man haue disdeyn
of synne is þis / as seiþ Seint Petir / who so doþ synne
is thralle of synne / And synne puttich a man in gret
þraldom

And þerfore seiþ þe ꝓprophete Ezechie / I went
soroufulle in disdeyn of myselue / Certis wel ouȝt
a man haue disdeyn of synne ⁊ wiþdraw him fro
þe thraldom ⁊ vileny

And lo what seiþ Senec
in this matier / he seiþ þus / þouȝ I wist þtat god ne
